DEBATE.TITLE: DEATH OF MR JAMES MARK BRADFIELD

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with deep regret that I inform the Senate of the death on 19 November 1989 of James Mark Bradfield, a former member of the House of Representatives for the division of Barton from 1975 to 1983.
—Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: X-rated and Violent Video Material
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate assembled in Parliament: The petition of citizens of Australia points out:

That all State Governments, States Attorneys-General, most women's groups and the majority of men in Australia, including significant numbers of Members of Parliament, are totally opposed to the importation and distribution of `X' and excessively violent `R'-rated video pornography in Australia.
That most `X'-rated material available in Australia is imported.
That the Federal Government, by its Customs power under the Constitution, and not the A.C.T. Government, is solely responsible for controlling the importation of this pornographic material.
That by continuing to allow the importation of such pornographic material, the Federal Government is neglecting its responsibility to the women, children and families of Australia.
Your petitioners, therefore, request the Senate to:
1. Ban `X'-rated pornographic material at the point of entry into Australia.
2. Exclude from the `R'-rating all gratuitously violent material.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Privacy Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled; the humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
The Hawke Labor Government's Privacy Amendment Bill concerning Credit Reference Reporting will:

(1) Prohibit many legitimate uses of credit information by organisations such as insurance companies, real estate agents, businesses selling goods on credit, and companies renting or leasing goods and equipment.
(2) Add to the cost of business and increase interest rates, and insurance charges and lead to over commitment by borrowers.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should: Reject Labor Government's Privacy Amendment Bill to enable businesses to have access to credit information they require to make sensible commercial decisions.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Romania
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

Romania, whose human rights record had been worse than that of South Africa's even before she embarked on a diabolic village destruction program, deservedly attracts worldwide condemnation. The systematic cultural genocide of the peoples affected must be prevented.
Therefore your petitioners humbly pray that:
1, the Australian Parliament establish whether or not Romania has satisfied fully her obligations under the Treaty of Trianon (1920) and the Peace Treaty of Paris (1947),
2, if found that Romania violates these agreements, the signatures representing Australia jointly or singularly be withdrawn from the thus invalidated documents,
3, Australia table her findings at the appropriate forums of the United Nations.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Alston (from 38 citizens) and Button (from 57 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Television Content
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate of the Commonwealth Parliament assembled. The petition of these residents of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal continues to regulate Australian content on television
That it increases the quota of first release prime-time drama to 365 hours a year per station, over the next three years
That it ensures the TV networks provide Australians with a variety of Australian television drama including serials, series and plays
That it increases the quota of children's programmes
That it encourages regional TV production.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the honourable members will oppose any deregulation of television content.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

(a) recognises the breach in the Berlin Wall for what it is-a powerful symbol of the triumph of freedom over oppression;
(b) welcomes the prospects of a more democratic future for the peoples of Eastern Europe;
(c) applauds the courage of those who defied repression and intimidation in the cause of greater political and economic freedom;

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-

(a) welcomes the pace of change in Europe which many commentators are hailing as the end of the Cold War, in particular the demolition of the Berlin Wall, the end of the old regimes in Poland, Hungary, Bulgaria and the German Democratic Republic, and the irrelevance of NATO and the Warsaw Pact;

TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I inform the Senate that Senator Walsh will be absent from the chamber for Question Time this week because of illness. Any questions in this chamber which would normally be directed to Senator Walsh in relation to his portfolio or those he represents should be directed to me.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. I refer to the indictment of the Government's accord with the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) which is contained in the current monthly bulletin of the Business Council of Australia (BCA), and in particular to these comments in the conclusion of that article:

QUESTION.PARA: The increasingly obvious failure of the Accord, however, is that Australia has failed to pull down growth in nominal wages and our productivity growth has been stifled.

Has the Minister noted the BCA conclusion that the price of the Government's special relationship with the trade union movement is that it has allowed the ACTU to `determine the nature and pace of labour market reform'? Has the Government any intention of heeding the Business Council's advice to wrest the initiative from the unions in this vital area of macro-economic reform; and if so, what is proposed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did see in a newspaper a headline to the article in question which clearly reflected the view of the BCA and Senator Chaney has elaborated on what that view is. Government and people concerned about economic issues in Australia at the present time are bombarded with advice from all sources.
—But you need so much.

—In that process of bombardment of advice, the Opposition's Foster's package got a fair backhander from most of the economic commentators. Senator Stone knows that full well. If Senator Stone can find a serious economic commentator to support the Opposition's package as a solution to any of these things, he should bring him forward, because Senator Stone has caught himself up in this debate, and I thought that his interjection from that point of view was slightly misplaced. In relation to the BCA comment, in terms of the general advice which the Government has been given on this issue, the Macquarie Bank, for example, in its statement, goes out of the way to make a point about the importance of the accord to Australian industry and to the economy generally in the last few years. It has apparently a different view from the BCA on this particular issue.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Chaney singled out the question of nominal wage rates. The Government has never suggested that nominal unit labour costs are irrelevant to economic policy or that they are not important to a country's competitiveness. But nominal unit labour costs are not the only factor determining competitiveness. Competitiveness measures based on nominal unit labour costs are misleading. Other factors, including the exchange rate, flexible labour and management practices, investment in new capital equipment and so on, and quality and reliability issues, are also important.

One sees this reflected, if I might say so, in an address by the Leader of the Opposition to the New South Wales Chamber of Commerce and Industry Conference in Sydney on 13 November of this year. Mr Peacock enlightened that august body with this view:
Using figures on manufacturing unit labour costs from the OECD . . . the competitiveness of Australian manufacturing will have declined by 49 percent between 1982 and 1990.

That may be true, using that measure alone, but of course there are numerous other measures, and if Mr Peacock has been wandering around this country, where we have had the highest level of productive activity in manufacturing for years, where we have had the highest growth in investment for years, and in particular where we have had a much improved export performance by the manufacturing--

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, come on!

—No. Senator Chaney raised this issue, and if he does not like the answer I suggest that he get out of the kitchen. Senator Chaney raised this question of nominal wage rates, and he is going to have to cop the answer whether he likes it or not. Mr Peacock says this to the New South Wales Chamber of Commerce and Industry. It does leave a slightly glib taste in the mouth, as does everything Mr Peacock says. He has not had his eyes open if he can make a statement like that, except perhaps when he is looking in a mirror, which is probably the only time he has his eyes fully open. The Leader of the Opposition is going around the country talking this sort of stuff which he knows to be rubbish, because the preferred measure in relation to competitiveness of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development in fact indicates a 12 per cent improvement in the competitiveness of Australian manufacturing over the period from 1982 to 1990.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Chaney, huffing and puffing, went on to ask me a question about the Business Council. He asked who determines the agenda in terms of restructuring, workplace reform and so on.

TALK.START.PARA: —The ACTU.

—Part of the answer to that question, as somebody interjected, is the ACTU. Many employers in this country will acknowledge that the ACTU has played an imaginative leadership role in respect of award restructuring and so on. If honourable senators have any doubt about that, they should look at the firms, which are singled out by economists and commentators, which have tackled this issue. They stand out because they have been able to tackle these issues because of corporate management leadership.
—Able to get around the ACTU. That is the issue. People have to get over the ACTU.

—Senator Lewis, as shadow Minister for industry over many months-the third time around or whatever-was singularly unsuccessful in explaining to me why some firms can do it and others cannot. The Business Council ought to think very seriously about that. The Business Council ought to think very seriously about the debt issue, as the Australian Financial Review pointed out to it this morning. If the Business Council wants to dictate an agenda on this, it will have to see that more companies participate in that agenda. I invite it to do so.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. Rather than quoting the Leader of the Opposition, as the Leader of the Government in this House has done, I will quote what the Treasurer has said. In my supplementary question I remind the Leader of the Government in the Senate that the Treasurer has said that the fundamental labour market problem that must be tackled by the Government now is the fragmented craft-based union structure. I remind the Leader of the Government that the amalgamation plans being pursued by the ACTU do not go to solving the problem of the fragmented craft-based union structure. I ask: What is the Government doing to promote a trade union structure which is relevant to enabling enterprise negotiations along the lines that the Treasurer acknowledges is required? What is the Government doing to take the initiative away from the ACTU and to put this area of change onto the right course?
—That is not a supplementary question, but I will answer it nonetheless.
—You didn't answer my original question.

—Senator Chaney says that I did not answer his original question. What he means by that is that he received an answer which he did not like. In terms of the so-called supplementary question, let me say this: on every occasion when firms have shown their willingness to tackle this issue, they have had the support of the Government.
—What are you doing about trade union structure? That is the question.

—Senator Chaney should look at trade union structure at Southern Aluminium, Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd, and all those companies that have been prepared to have a go at dealing with this issue. They have had the support of the Government and they will continue to get it.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Since the Senate last met, many people have been killed in El Salvador. Six Jesuits, their cook and her daughter have been murdered in San Salvador. These events arise out of a long running conflict in El Salvador. Does the Government see the move towards harmony elsewhere in the world reaching that country? Is there anything the Government can do to help bring a just peace to El Salvador?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The situation in El Salvador as it has developed in recent days is a distressing one. On 11 November the insurgent forces of the FMLN-the Farabundi Marti National Liberation Front-launched a major offensive in El Salvador breaking a cease-fire in what has been a 10-year civil war in which war some 70,000 people, mostly civilians, have been killed. The FMLN cancelled negotiations with the Government of El Salvador, claiming that the rightist administration had not been serious about peace negotiations and that the Government was behind recent bombings in San Salvador in which 10 people, including a union leader, were killed. Estimated casualties to date in the most recent action are over 1,000 dead and as many injured, including many civilians.

ANSWER.PARA: One of the most brutal incidents, as Senator Cooney has adverted to, occurred on 16 November when six Jesuit priests, including the rector, the vice-rector, the sociology professor and the head of the human rights research unit of the University of Central America, and also two other people, were brutally murdered in San Salvador, reportedly after being badly beaten. The Government and the insurgent forces have each accused the other of the murder of the six Jesuits. The killings have been condemned by President Cristiani and an investigation into the murder apparently will be undertaken. There is considerable speculation, however, that the priests, who were known to be sympathetic to the rebel cause and were active in defending human rights, were in fact the victims of a rightist military death squad.

Whoever is responsible, I want to make it clear that Australia absolutely deplores and condemns this atrocity, which feeds the appalling cycle of violence against unarmed civilians which, as I said, has affected El Salvador over the past 10 years. The President, army spokesman and spokesmen for the United States Embassy in El Salvador have all declared that the situation is slowly coming under control. Latest reports indicate that the level of fighting has diminished, but the situation certainly remains fluid at present. An Organisation of American States mission is visiting El Salvador in an attempt to negotiate a ceasefire but prospects for renewed peace talks are bleak. Yesterday I took the opportunity to discuss the situation at some length with the Mexican Under-Secretary of Foreign Affairs, Ambassador Rozental, in Canberra. I indicated that we would do anything we could, although it has to be acknowledged that we are not a major player in El Salvador or in Central American affairs generally.

Nevertheless, I say again that we call on both sides to resume peace negotiations without delay in order to find a lasting settlement to the conflict. We appeal to both the Government and the FMLN forces to respect internationally accepted standards of human rights and to refrain from violence against unarmed civilians. We also express the hope that all countries in the region will work to diminish tension within El Salvador and avoid actions which could further escalate the violence in that country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations agree that enterprise level agreements offer the best prospect for improved industrial relations and increased productivity? In view of the fact that two-thirds of private sector employees in Australia are not members of unions, should employees in an enterprise be permitted or be able to reach an agreement with their employer where there is no union involved?

—I have said in this chamber on a number of occasions-not just recently but over a year or two-that aggregate wage outcomes, industry restructuring, motivating work force involvement in industry restructuring and so on are of immense importance in terms of the benefits of the accord, but at the edge of the accord procedures we look, over time, to having greater flexibility in industry and enterprise bargaining relating to wages and conditions. That is why the 1988 industrial relations legislation which passed through this Senate provides for agreements certified by the Industrial Relations Commission which allow flexibility in negotiations at the enterprise level. A number of firms have taken advantage of that. Firms such as ICI Australia, Comalco Ltd and its partners at Bell Bay and the southern aluminium refinery and so on have taken advantage of that procedure to negotiate enterprise level agreements which have been put to the Australian Industrial Relations Commission for certification. I believe that that process should be encouraged. As distinct from the Opposition, this Government has been concerned throughout its period in office about aggregate wage outcomes. We will continue to be concerned about that, and that is the difference between the Government and Opposition policies on this matter.

—I ask a supplementary question. With all due respect to the Minister, he has not answered my question, which really asked whether enterprise-level agreements offered the best prospect for improved industrial relations and increased productivity, and whether employees in an enterprise should be permitted or be able to reach an agreement with their employer where there is no union involved.
—Now, turn the heat up.

—Senator Puplick says to turn the heat up. I will try to oblige him if he wants me to. The answer is that, as I understand it, there is no inhibition under the provisions of the Industrial Relations Act, which passed the Senate in 1988, in employees negotiating under the provisions of those agreements; so I do not think Senator Knowles is correct in saying that. She asked whether enterprise-based negotiations would necessarily lead to better productivity results and so on. I cannot answer that question. I believe that, in many cases, they would.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Following the recent major changes in Eastern Europe and the general moves towards a more democratic system, what is the Government's assessment of the current dramatic situation in Eastern Europe and what are the implications for Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The events in Europe of recent weeks have been, as we can all appreciate, quite tumultuous in their pace and breathtaking in their scope. Certainly they are wholly to be welcomed and hold out the prospect of a quite fundamental transformation in East-West relations, albeit one that will take quite some time to work through. They also hold out the prospect of quite fundamental changes in the shape of the world economic map which presumably will, in due course, match the political and geostrategic ones we are witnessing at the moment.

ANSWER.PARA: The process has been led by the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics (USSR), where the current leadership has acknowledged quite frankly the fundamental problems of the communist command economy system and the political system that goes with it, where that leadership has accepted the intrinsic link between economic and political reform, where it has admitted serious specific errors in previous domestic and foreign policies, and where it has vowed that future policies will be based on what we in the West regard as more moral considerations.

Following that lead by the USSR, we have seen quite striking changes in a number of other Eastern European countries: Poland has a popularly elected government led by Solidarity; Hungary is attempting to transform itself into a multi-party democracy with a market economy; and now, in the German Democratic Republic (GDR) the Government is at last allowing its people freedom of travel and has promised to hold open elections. It would appear that a process of quite fundamental revision of the political and economic system in the GDR is now under way.

That response in the same positive manner has not been evident in a number of other Eastern European countries. The Government of Czechoslovakia has made changes only at the margin and has so far resisted fundamental change. The use of force against demonstrators calling for reform is an act quite contrary to the spirit of the times. Certainly we hold out the hope and the growing expectation that the Government in Prague will follow the lead of its neighbours and take into account the wishes of its own people. The process of reform has only just begun in Bulgaria, following the resignation of the longest serving communist leader in Eastern Europe. Of course, it has not begun at all in Romania, where the dismal human rights record in that country has earned it virtual universal condemnation.

Western countries have not been slow in reacting positively to this new course of events. A group of 24 Western countries-of which Australia was of course one-formed following the G7 summit have been working together to coordinate efforts to assist the reform process. The Prime Minister announced on 15 October a significant package of Australian assistance to Poland and Hungary, which consists not only of $5m worth of food aid but also of measures to assist these two countries to improve their economic performance. All of the developments we are witnessing are seen by us and other like-minded governments as marking the commencement rather than the conclusion in what will, I think, still be a long and fragile process. I repeat that the blurring of the very sharp division that has existed hitherto between East and West is a process that offers a quite historic opportunity for lasting improvements in East-West relations and global security and is of vital concern to us as well as to everybody else in the world.

Australia has been closely following and monitoring the events that have been occurring in Eastern Europe, as would be expected, and we have been particularly closely involved at a personal political leadership level as a result of the Prime Minister's visits to the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics to meet President Gorbachev and, more recently in July, to Hungary. The exact implications for Australia are difficult to determine at this stage. With that in mind, the Prime Minister and I have agreed that I should visit Europe next month to make some first-hand assessment of these developments and their implications for Europe. I will do so from the middle of next month.

The first objective of that visit is to attend in Brussels the proposed ministerial meeting of the Group of 24 and to discuss with Western ministerial colleagues their current thinking about the strategic and economic implications of the course of events in East Europe generally. The objective also, to the extent possible in the circumstances, is to make higher level contact with the new reform leadership emerging in Eastern Europe with a view to making some better informed judgments about the likely pace and direction of future political and economic change and also to try to make some first-hand assessment of the implications for the world trading system of the freeing up of the Eastern Europe economies that we are seeing and in that context to assist potential in trading and investment opportunities for Australia. On my return to Canberra I propose to put some recommendations to the Government on further steps Australia may take and any further response that might be appropriate to this quite breathtaking situation that we are now witnessing.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade to undertakings given by the previous Foreign Minister, Mr Hayden, that a Labor government would resume aid to Vietnam after the withdrawal of its troops from Cambodia. First, does the Government agree with the British assessment that Vietnamese troops have withdrawn from Cambodia? If so, why has the Government made the provision of bilateral aid to Vietnam conditional on internal Cambodian factors, such as the achievement of a comprehensive settlement between the still warring factions, including the notorious Khmer Rouge? Secondly, does the Government support the decision of the United States Administration to offer aid in the form of medical supplies to Vietnam? If so, will Australia provide similar urgently needed equipment? Thirdly, given the decision by the Australian Trade Commission to open its first office in Vietnam in the next few months, does this mean that the Government sees the potential for better economic relations between the countries, but is unwilling to speed up this process through the provision of official bilateral development assistance?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —No government, let alone that of the United Kingdom, is in a position to assess with any confidence the precise situation on the ground so far as the withdrawal of Vietnamese troops is concerned in the absence of a properly and internationally supervised monitoring exercise of the kind that we, among others, have been seeking to put in place as part of a comprehensive settlement. There is no doubt that formed military units have completely withdrawn from Vietnam; they no longer exist as single entities. It is simply not possible to make any informed judgment about the situation with respect to individual advisers or perhaps even individual or small groups of troops that might be attached to other Cambodian units. Until it is possible to make such an informed judgment, our position will remain as it was originally stated by Mr Hayden.

ANSWER.PARA: Beyond that, we take the view that Vietnam, among others, is certainly still capable of influencing the final outcome in Cambodia politically and in other ways and that as a result it is appropriate that the rest of the world maintain some appropriate pressure on Vietnam together with appropriate pressure on all the other countries that are capable of influencing outcome. I instance among them China, particularly, because of its very crucial role in continuing to supply the Khmer Rouge. It is appropriate, I repeat, to maintain some stance of this kind in order to bring about the situation that we all very much hope for, an end to the killing in Cambodia once and for all and a settlement which will prove to be genuinely durable.

The situation with respect to aid to Vietnam is, as I have stated, based on being satisfied both that there has been a complete withdrawal of the Vietnamese troops and that as settlement of the Cambodian situation is either in place or at least on track. That will remain our policy position.

The situation concerning aid more generally, however, is not concluded by that. I have been talking so far only about the resumption of formal bilateral aid between the two countries, which was withdrawn by Australia following the invasion of Cambodia in 1979 by Vietnam. Australia does, of course, continue to provide quite a large sum of aid through multilateral institutions and non-government organisations. My recollection is that that is of the order of magnitude of some $21m in the last financial year, about $14m of which was in the form of food aid. The rest was provided through a variety of other projects, through a variety of other multilateral and non-government organisation channels.

Similarly, in the case of Cambodia itself, I think that about $6m of Australian aid is going in there-not on the basis of any bilateral intergovernmental process but through multilateral agencies and non-government organisations. We certainly propose to continue that aid in the interests both of humanitarian considerations and of the development of the country. I should make it clear also that we have taken the view, so far as Vietnam is concerned, that it is entirely appropriate that Vietnam should have access to funds from international financial institutions, the International Monetary Fund, the World Bank and the Asian Development Bank. In that respect we take a rather different view from some of our allies or like-minded countries in relation to the Indo-China dispute who have been unwilling to accept that particular principle.

So far as the question of trade with Vietnam is concerned, equally Australia has imposed no inhibitions on trade with Vietnam at any stage, unlike, again, the position of the United States in particular and some other allied countries which have dragged their feet in this respect. We have seen it as important to assist as best we can in the commercial and economic recovery of the country, and we are taking steps accordingly to upgrade our presence in Vietnam at a trade representation level to ensure that that occurs. There is a consistency about our position in this respect. We are trying in a number of ways to ensure that enough of an environment is created where there is still pressure to proceed towards a settlement of the unresolved questions in Cambodia, but we do not believe that that should be taken to the point of inhibiting the flow of very badly needed aid and trade with the countries in question.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support. In light of the Oxley Airlines crash at Coffs Harbour on 7 April 1988, in which the pilot and two passengers were killed, and the subsequent coronial inquiry, can the Minister explain how the Civil Aviation Authority can effectively maintain high safety standards when the Superintendent of Flying Operations, Warren Gengos, said under oath that the CAA lacks the staff to carry out an investigation into alleged breaches of air safety by Oxley Airlines? Is the Minister aware that Mr Gengos revealed at the inquest that the CAA altered the interpretation of the regulation governing the serviceability of distance measuring equipment on aircraft shortly after the inquest began, and, if so, what is the substance of his statement on oath? Will the Minister consider immediately suspending the licence for Oxley Airlines in the interests of public safety in view of an apparent breach of air safety standards by Oxley Airlines and the apparent illegality of its landing at Coffs Harbour on 7 April? Finally, can the Minister confirm that Mr Gengos was promoted to Assistant General Manager, New South Wales, subsequent to the inquest, despite the fact that the coroner found him not to be a credible witness?

—The only brief that I have on this matter is that the coroner has issued his report on the fatal accident which occurred at Coffs Harbour on 7 April. I am told that he made no finding on the cause of the accident, although he did note expert advice about weather at the time and the possible disorienting effects of that on the pilot. It is reported that he could find no connection between the operations of Oxley Airlines and the cause of the accident, but he said that he would recommend to the Federal Government that there be an independent inquiry into the operations of the airline. I am told by the Minister that the Government will give consideration to that recommendation when it is received. I will take into account the other questions that have been asked by Senator Dunn that I have not responded to specifically in that answer and seek an early reply.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate and follows his answer to my question earlier today in which he quoted the Macquarie Bank's report Australia's Economic Challenge as being in support of the importance of the accord. I draw his attention to the fact that, quite contrary to the point that was being made by the Minister, the section of that report which deals with labour market reform states:

QUESTION.PARA: But the facts are clear. Australia has a relatively poor record of productivity growth, particularly in manufacturing, and continues to experience unit labour cost increases well above those in the countries with which we trade.
I further point out to the Minister that the report continues:
To achieve a closer relationship between labour costs and productivity, the centralised wage fixing system to which Australia has clung for many years must be replaced.

The report goes on to emphasise the importance of enterprise-based negotiations for both working conditions and wages and points specifically to the matter that I raised in my supplementary question, that is the failure of the existing craft-based union system. I now ask the Minister: In light of the fact that the report to which he referred recommends specifically amendments to the law relating to union amalgamation, what does the Government intend to do about this matter as opposed to simply talking about it, as the Treasurer has been talking about it in Tokyo? Will the Government do anything to facilitate a more logical trade-union structure for Australian industry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —My reference to the Macquarie Bank's agenda for reform was really based on page 13 of that report, which states:

ANSWER.PARA: The present government deserves to be congratulated for many of its achievements over the past six, almost seven years. It has shown resilience and tenacity in winning a range of reforms that had eluded previous governments of either political complexion.
Its most significant measures include:
turning a record budget deficit of . . . (7 per cent of GDP) . . . into a budget surplus of . . . (2.5 per cent of GDP) . . .
introducing the Accord with the unions which has fostered a climate where the work force has become a more willing participant in fundamental reforms;
job creation . . .

I make the point that job creation has been achieved largely because of the higher profit share that companies have enjoyed for a very long time and that that, in large part, has been a result of the containment of real unit labour costs. The report goes on to deal with tax reform, deregulation of the Australian financial system, changes to superannuation and so on. That report carries the headline `Where to from Here?' and Senator Chaney has asked me questions directed to that particular point. I say to the honourable senator that, as has been said, the Government is continually negotiating on these issues of reform of the labour market and it will continue to carry on with those negotiations. All the matters that Senator Chaney read out to me are in the arena of public debate and have been for a long time. The question is: How can these results be achieved? Instead of reading from the Macquarie Bank report, Senator Chaney might also read from the editorial of the Australian Financial Review of this morning, which makes some very important points about these issues.

Ever since I have been Leader of the Government in the Senate I have been asked by Senator Chaney such questions as: When will the Government do something about next year's wages; when will the Government do something about this or that? The answer is: The Government will make an announcement at the appropriate time, and I repeat that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Does the Government have any proposals to facilitate a more logical and coherent trade union structure for Australia?
—In so far as the Government is concerned, the answer is yes. At the present time no formulated position has been arrived at on these issues.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Is the Minister aware of reported comments made at a recent meeting of the Australian Institute of International Affairs by the recently returned Australian Ambassador to Bangladesh, Ms Sue Boyd, that `Australia was using its aid as a form of leverage when suggesting change' and that, as an example, she had `already suggested ways of overcoming the population problem to the Bangladesh Government, such as preference in government employment for workers participating in a population control program'? Does the Minister believe that it is appropriate that Australian representatives suggest to other countries that it is acceptable for governments to discriminate against potential employees on the basis of their ability or willingness to prove that they are participating in a population control program? Would he not agree that such a coercive measure would violate both human rights in general and workers' rights in particular? Does the Minister believe that it could ever be considered appropriate that proof of birth control be required before anyone is accepted into the Australian Public Service? If not, why should an official representative of our country suggest such a practice elsewhere?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The population pressures at work in the desperately poverty stricken country of Bangladesh are such that it is not unreasonable to contemplate a whole variety of officially sanctioned population control policy measures being put into operation in circumstances that would be regarded as unnecessary in a country such as ours. Fundamental human rights considerations to one side, I do not think it is appropriate to draw contrasts of the kind that Senator Harradine seeks to do between countries as disparate as Australia and Bangladesh.

ANSWER.PARA: There is no doubt that the Government of Bangladesh has afforded a very high priority to its population control programs and has sought assistance from friendly countries in a whole variety of ways, including financial assistance through the aid program and through the discretionary funds that are available to Australian ambassadors in certain posts abroad. I am not familiar with the particular circumstances of Ms Boyd's contribution, if such it was, to the Bangladeshi program in question; nor am I familiar with whatever she might have said to the Australian Institute of International Affairs; nor am I familiar with the precise details of the program in question. I will seek some further information about all those matters and respond to Senator Harradine later in more detail.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. My question has not been responded to. It is not so much a matter of seeking details as a question of policy on behalf of the Government. Surely the Minister can answer yes or no as to whether he believes that such discrimination in employment is a violation not only of human rights in general but also of workers' rights in particular. That is the question I ask him as a representative of this Labor Government.
—Of course the Minister can answer yes or no to any question, but in this instance he does not choose to do so because he is insufficiently informed about the circumstances of the program.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Housing and Aged Care. I remind the Minister that I raised this matter with him after the Senate rose on 2 November. I ask whether it is not a fact that, in answer to a question from Senator Devereux on 26 October, he made a mistake by asserting:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . of all prescriptions issued, 83.7 per cent were overcharged, on average by $1.15.

Does the Minister now realise that the figure he cited relates to charging by pharmacists for pharmaceutical benefits scheme (PBS) medications below the price of $11? Is it not a fact that as these prescriptions make up only 20 to 25 per cent of total prescriptions dispensed, the claimed overcharging relates to only about 16 to 20 per cent of all prescriptions, not the 83.7 per cent put by the Minister? In view of the fact that on the previous day Mr Staples had accurately stated the position in the House of Representatives, will the Minister now confirm that he made a mistake? Will he not also apologise to Senator Knowles for describing her attempt to put the record straight, in a question to him on 2 November, as a `fairly tawdry and shabby effort'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Lewis is continuing a line of questioning that Senator Knowles started on 2 November. In my answer on 2 November I advised Senator Knowles that she would do well to read all of the documentation associated with the answer. Perhaps I should go a little further and say that if one selects a line from an answer, it is possible to make a case based on the meaning of that line, standing alone. If one takes the answer as a complete unit and reads all of the points and references made within that answer, it is possible to see that the inference that one may draw from a particular line, standing alone, is not the correct inference. Let me make this point very clear: if it is correct to take the meaning of a line standing alone, then the allegation that Senator Knowles made of me is an allegation which is equally true of her. Once again I refer Senator Lewis to the whole of the answer and the whole of the question.

ANSWER.PARA: With respect to Senator Knowles and her question of 2 November, Senator Lewis asked whether I wish to apologise to Senator Knowles for styling her comment as `tawdry'. No, I do not. That is a correct description of the type of exercise that she engaged in. Senator Lewis also asked whether the figures which I gave on 26 October relate to prescriptions under the $11 level. If Senator Lewis reads the text of my answer, he will see that they do.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Defence whether he is aware that last week the United States Navy ordered all Navy units to suspend normal operations and spend 48 hours of 72 hours reviewing procedures and training and reminding all hands of safety measures, following 10 accidents during the previous three weeks in which 10 sailors died and at least 71 were injured. In relation to this, I ask the Minister whether the Australian Government was told whether this order applied to Battle Group Alpha, which was then in Fremantle and two other Western Australian ports, as it applied to other ships in this group which are homeported at Yokosuka in Japan. What form did the safety review take? Were all naval personnel recalled from shore leave to participate in the review? If not, why not? Was a check of all weaponry included, and was the review conducted while the vessels were in port? What is the Government's response to this dramatic and unprecedented admission from the United States Navy that its safety record is far from good? Considering that there have been at least three accidents involving United States naval vessels in Australian ports-Stirling in 1981, Brisbane in 1987 and Cairns in 1988-will the Minister revise his grandiose claim made on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation's 7.30 Report during the Bicentennial Naval Review that accidents will not happen in Australian ports?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Vallentine has asked a number of questions on defence over time, but this one is sillier than most.
—That is a pretty large claim.

—I know it is a big claim but, nonetheless, I am making it. One wonders how an Australian Minister for Defence, such as Mr Beazley, can possibly give answers on reviews undertaken by the United States Navy. One wonders how Mr Beazley can then, further to that-not just on a general question-also answer as to how the United States Navy conducts its reviews, what it says to its sailors during them, and which sailors it requires at what time. It would be absolutely ludicrous for Mr Beazley to even ask the question. So, no; I cannot answer any of Senator Vallentine's questions, and I do not intend to, and I will not be asking Mr Beazley to check.

ANSWER.PARA: I do not remember what Mr Beazley said on the 7.30 Report. I remember a claim that he made some time back that a nuclear accident on a United States vessel in an Australian port was virtually impossible. I know of nothing that has occurred that would make Mr Beazley change his mind on that matter. As far as that opinion goes, I agree with it completely.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. Am I to understand from the Minister that, in inviting into our ports these United States naval vessels and any other foreign vessels bearing nuclear weapons or powered by nuclear generators, the Minister for Defence takes no responsibility whatsoever for the safety procedures involved? Is he prepared to ask no questions of the US Navy? Is it a carte blanche invitation to come into our ports, to do what they like in our ports-which could have included a check of nuclear weapons on board those ships which are tied up alongside the passenger terminal in Fremantle? Is the Minister for Defence taking no responsibility whatsoever for these safety matters?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —Gee, it is good to be back. As I have said to the honourable senator before, I recall visits to Australia by many United States ships during the bicentennial. I recall that in Sydney there were 2,000 demonstrators and 1 1/2 million people trying to get onto the ships. Those 1 1/2 million people who were trying to get onto those ships did not appear to be too frightened of an accident happening at the time. The only accidents that were occurring were people getting injured in the crush to get on board. As to the procedures that are to be applied on board United States vessels, all I can say is that they have an excellent record in Australia. They have not caused damage to Australians or Australia in the ports which they have visited. As far as the Government is concerned, the invitation for them to visit our ports remains open. The United States is an ally, and I hope it will remain so for a very long time.

—Can the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services tell the Senate what conditions apply to the use of stamps issued to senators and members of the House of Representatives at taxpayers' expense? Do the guidelines extend to allowing the use of such stamps to assist candidates in union elections? Can they be diverted for use by community groups? Has the Government informed all senators and members of the guidelines?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —I will take the last part of the question first. I am not aware that a Minister has recently reissued guidelines in regard to this particular matter, but normally, from time to time, the attention of senators and members is drawn to a whole range of guidelines as to their entitlements. As to what guidelines there are on Ministers using stamps, postage entitlements come in a variety of forms, both franked and credit card, plus an allowance of, I think, $900 a quarter in physical stamps. I assume that is what the honourable senator is referring to. In regard to that, it is usually left to the judgment of senators and members concerned. In a technical aspect, I think they are for use generally only from Canberra, because members and senators do not have their franking machines in Canberra. I do not want to have a `hands up' exercise of who has ever taken their stamps home from here because I am afraid we would get a fairly meagre response and I would doubt the veracity of those who would put up their hands, because they tend to be used both at home and here. I think that was the Remuneration Tribunal's thinking-to issue stamps so that they could be used in Canberra rather than in the home electorate.

ANSWER.PARA: The honourable senator has asked me to give a judgment on whether stamps should be used for community purposes, for internal union ballots, or for anything else. My response to that is that usually the main rule in governing the behaviour of members of parliament is commonsense. We do have arguments from time to time whether in fact postage allowances across the board are always used correctly. I have noticed a press release from Senator Short criticising Mr Cleeland for doing something when I got a letter from Senator Short in exactly the same terms as the letter Mr Cleeland sent out. I think there is a fair bit of hypocrisy here, but commonsense should apply.

TALK.START.PARA: —I didn't doctor an official government document.

—Senator Short did not have the ingenuity to photocopy a strong point and send it out. If that is the only point Senator Short is making, that is fair enough. I thought he was making more of the point that Mr Cleeland was sending out political literature, which is far less blatant than the same stuff Senator Short sent into the same electorate-and Senator Short knows it.

ANSWER.PARA: As I say, when I was Minister for Home Affairs-and I am sure Mr West takes the same approach-usually I took the approach that those stamps were for official government use. It is true that out of an electoral allowance a member of parliament may want to buy stamps and give them to community organisations. Within the spirit of the decision of the Remuneration Tribunal, I think one is allowed to use one's electoral allowance to help community groups. Where one draws the line should be left to the commonsense of the honourable member or honourable senator concerned. I guess that where that line is drawn is up to the public to eventually decide, but we generally expect people to show some commonsense in that regard. I cannot give Senator Vanstone a precise definition because everyone has different needs and uses.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In light of the Minister's two-fold answer-that he is not aware whether any guidelines on this matter have been issued recently but that in any event he believes it ought to be left to commonsense-is it the Government's view that it is acceptable to have guidelines that allow stamps for parliamentarians to use in their parliamentary and electorate business to be diverted for use in union elections and to be diverted to community groups? In that context, the question stays with the stamps that are issued and is not a question of what one does with one's electoral allowance.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —I still stick to my answer. It is basically up to the commonsense of a member of parliament as to what use the stamps are put. I did not say that the Government would not issue guidelines. I just said that from time to time it does, and I am not aware of it occurring recently with regard to this specific section of postage. We all know that guidelines have been issued as to the use of credit cards or increased postal entitlements. Senator Vanstone has received a letter and has the letters available to her, but in terms of those actual physical stamps I do not recall any guidance going out in the last few years. I do not recall having received any.
—Perhaps you should do something about it.

—From time to time Senator Vanstone has received letters about staff overtime to give her guidance. As an issue comes up, new instructions are issued or the same instructions are recirculated just to draw the issue to the attention of all honourable senators.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. In this International Literacy Year, I ask the Minister to explain the advances in literacy he believes will result from the decision to amalgamate the States' literacy grants, the non-formal adult education and advanced English program of migrants, especially in view of the proven track record of the councils of further education. Can the Minister explain the advantages expected from the decision to transfer administration of the new single program to the Commonwealth Employment Service, an organisation which is overloaded, centralised and essentially still bureaucratic? Why were the States not consulted prior to this decision being made? Can the Minister guarantee that the change will result in even better targeting of the program to those most in need, namely, women in the home, workers in low paid and low skilled jobs, people in receipt of pensions or disability allowances, Aborigines and people from non-English speaking backgrounds, as catered for under the present three separate programs? Does the Minister deny that the major beneficiaries of the change will be professionally qualified or skilled migrants who need to upgrade their language skills in order to satisfy employment requirements? What plans does the Minister have to review the effects of this decision to ensure that the Government's social justice objectives are being met?

—To use Senator Powell's terminology, I cannot explain any of those things today. I neither confirm nor deny the second part of her question. I think that is the expression that is used. I will obtain an answer to that series of questions for Senator Powell as quickly as possible and provide it.

—Is the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce aware of claims that reductions in the Budget appropriation for the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) have led to a reduction in the amount of research into the environment now being carried out? Can the Minister inform the Senate whether or not these claims have any substance?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of Mr McGauran's claims. I follow him with a great deal of interest because, of all the cowboys on the Opposition benches, he is the greatest high-rider, I think, in the outrageous claims which he makes. Mr McGauran's claims are based on a submission, based on figures prepared by my Department some 18 months ago, made to an Australian Science and Technology Council (ASTEC) inquiry by some officers of CSIRO. It was one of a hundred being considered by ASTEC. The information in Mr McGauran's statement is out of date. It is particularly out of date because in May this year the Government announced a whole package of science funding which benefited both CSIRO and other research bodies which are funded in part or in whole by the Commonwealth Budget.

ANSWER.PARA: The whole thing, as with most Liberal Opposition members, is yesterday's show. It is one of the last 1985 shows from Mr McGauran and is out of date. I do not know why he keeps on saying these silly things. The statement does not take account of the significant sums made available in the May statement. Nor does it take account of the range of government and private sector bodies which are looking at environmental problems. The most pressing environmental problem is soil degradation. Research into that is presently being conducted by the Department of Primary Industries and Energy. I thought that Mr McGauran would have known about that.

While CSIRO's contribution to research into the environment is considerable and, I might say, often world-class, that organisation has by no means a monopoly or a necessary monopoly of excellence in this field. The Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service and its State counterparts conduct research into these issues, as do various government departments, including the Department of Primary Industries and Energy, the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories and the Department of Local Government, the various State pollution control authorities, the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation, Australian universities, which conduct much of the long term basic research in this field, and industry, which is developing better and cleaner production processes, and so on.

Apart from that, because of the Government's commitment to environmental research, it has made funds available for a number of specific purposes in environmental research, not all of which have been given to CSIRO. For example, this year an additional $13m was allocated for soil research and $5m for forestry research. Funding for rural research and water resources increased by $31m; $10m was allocated for the national reafforestation program, and so on. There are many activities such as those which go beyond CSIRO and which are relevant to research into the environment. Mr McGauran, if he wants one, can have from me a full list on what the projects are that are conducting research into environmental matters.

As I have said, the statement on CSIRO is out of date. A number of things have happened since then. Ultimately the management of CSIRO research activity is in the hands of the board and senior management of that organisation. It is their job to determine priorities within the organisation as much as they can.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Robert Ray)-by leave-agreed to:
