(2) That any debate on Senator Hill's motion, if not sooner concluded, shall be adjourned at 6.30 p.m. and made an Order of the Day for the next day of sitting without any question being put.
(3) That the provisions of the Sessional Order relating to the interruption of business apply to the interruption of any debate at 5.30 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Mr President, I claim to have been misrepresented. On 9 November 1989 a Tonight program on Special Broadcasting Service (SBS) television, by a process of misrepresentation, selection of material and juxtaposition of opposing interviews, conveyed a misleading, inaccurate and unfair representation of my views on population and immigration. The misrepresentation occurred in four areas. Firstly, the program represented me as a vice-president of the Australian Conservation Foundation. I am not an office holder of the Australian Conservation Foundation. Secondly, when inviting me to the interview, the interviewer, Mr Mark Corcoran, led me to believe that the interview would last for about 12 minutes and that the whole of the interview would be shown. In fact, only a few selected excerpts were televised.

SPEECH.PARA: Thirdly, in a lengthy discussion before filming of the interview began, I made it abundantly clear to Mark Corcoran that, whatever the level of immigration, I would not support selection which was based on any consideration of race, religion, sex or ethnic origin. I stressed that it was most important to include this in the broadcast interview. The same point was stressed again during the filmed part of the discussion and again during a long discussion which followed. This important point made by me was completely eliminated in the broadcast program. On the contrary, each part of my interview was surrounded by others protesting the need for a non-racially based immigration program, giving the clear impression that my argument was racist. I and the Australian Democrats support a non-racially based immigration program with emphasis on humanitarian considerations, a program of family reunion and an expanded refugee program.

Fourthly, one part of the interview dealt with the economics of immigration. I made the point that the studies done so far of the economics of immigration had failed to show any economic benefit to Australia of a continuing high rate of immigration. Economics was mentioned twice during the selected part of the interview which was broadcast and on each occasion it was stated that I claimed that immigration conferred no benefit on Australia. The adjective `economic', an important qualifier, was removed. The word `economic' as a qualifier actually appeared on the screen on one occasion while the voice-over spoke only of `no benefit'. It would appear that someone in SBS, with the same zeal with which fundamentalist Moslems have dealt with the Salman Rushdie book Satanic Verses, is intent on crushing any sane rational debate on the size of Australia's population or the economics of the immigration program by smearing as racist those who raise these issues, however unfair or unjustifiable that may be.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CHANEY
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) 1988-89 annual report was tabled in the House of Representatives a couple of weeks ago and has received extensive coverage since that time. The Minister at the table, the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button), commented during Question Time that the Government was being bombarded with advice on the economy. That is scarcely surprising, given the very significant difficulties Australia faces in terms of international debt and the fact that in four of the last six years Australian wage and salary earners have seen their real incomes decline. If the current Budget figures are any indication, it seems likely that in five of Labor's seven years in office real incomes in Australia will have been reduced.

Some economists cheer at that sort of thing. That is understandable if reductions in real wages are part of a program for economic recovery but when, over the same seven-year period, there has been an explosion of foreign debt and a total failure to do anything about productivity, which is the key to getting ourselves out of this morass of debt and poverty, it is not surprising that many people are rallying forward with advice for the Government.

The advice which comes from politicians, whether they be from the Government itself or the Opposition, tends to be regarded with some suspicion in the electorate. Certainly there is some doubt that the process of political debate very often is focused on the substance of issues. For that reason, the contributions of people, whether they be from the Macquarie Bank or the IAC, are welcomed by the public and do help to throw some light on matters which are of some concern to the whole community.

In the case of this report, however, the Opposition would say that there is a very substantial bearing out of the views which we have been expressing for a long time and which were again brought together in the Economic Action Plan produced recently by Mr Andrew Peacock on behalf of the Opposition. The fact that there is support for issues such as privatisation and for a far more active approach to reform of things such as coastal shipping-and the Industries Assistance Commission points out how that process could be improved and accelerated by the introduction of foreign competition, which is of course completely consistent with the Opposition's policy on this matter-does I think give greater weight to the views which have been put forward by us.

In the very brief time available to me, I wish to point out to the Minister at the table, Senator Button, that once again this report suggests that there is a fundamental need for labour market reform in Australia. It is probably fair to say that Senator Button, in about the sixth response to matters raised with him in Question Time, did make some reference to the debate being about the rate of change which can be achieved. I draw his attention to the fact that the IAC, on page 28 of its report, refers to the point that the success of many of the reforms which are put forward by the IAC as being fundamental is predicated on a degree of labour market reform, and it refers to greater wage flexibility having a role to play in two respects in that it can provide signals for redevelopment and provide a means by which retraining can be financed.

From the point of view of the Australian people, however, the simple fact is that the IAC report is talking about how we can make Australia a wealthier country. It is fundamental that we do make Australia a wealthier country if we are to do away with the twin plagues of debt and declining living standards. What the IAC puts forward in this document is an estimate that reforms in areas such as transport, postal service, telecommunications and the electricity sector and reductions in rural and manufacturing assistance-all of which have been targeted by the Opposition as needing a far more rapid rate of change than the Government is promoting-could, over the long term, increase the gross domestic product in Australia by about 4.7 per cent of $16 billion a year, could increase real wages by 8 per cent, and could mean a fall in the consumer price index of 6.3 per cent. Production would increase in all sectors of the economy but by far the biggest winner would be the mining sector, where output could increase by 24 per cent. The report makes the point that the key to achieving these outcomes is increased competition. The report is critical of many of the Government's reforms, including that of coastal shipping.

I ask the Minister at the table to consider this report carefully. I believe that it is yet another condemnation of the inactivity of the Government in many vital areas. The fact is that the Government is pursuing change in most of them but in almost all it is a case of too little too late and I do not think that Australia has a lot more time to play around.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to support the motion that the Senate take note of the annual report of the Industries Assistance Commission. I support my colleague Senator Chaney in what he said in relation to this report. The first sentence in chapter 1 of the report reads:

SPEECH.PARA: If we are to prosper the economy must become more productive.

I believe that that one sentence sums up the great problems which this nation faces and it is, if I might be permitted to say, the whole purport of the Liberal-National Party's Economic Action Plan which we recently put down. Unfortunately, in relation to that report many in the media have concentrated on the taxation package. I ask them to apply their minds to the economic package detailed in that report in which we set out how the Liberal and National parties will enable this nation to prosper by making the economy more productive. I have heard Senator Button repeatedly make statements about micro-economic reform and changes which should take place in the economy of this nation over a period of many years and, as I have said repeatedly, I have admired his words. I have not admired his actions because he and his Government frankly have failed to fulfil the rhetoric that they have used in relation to micro-economic reform.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have just not delivered the goods.
—That is correct. They have talked about it. This was to be the Government of micro-economic reform. That is what the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said in 1987. What has it done?
—An historic third term.

—That is so. What has it done since 1987? All it has worried about is trying to getting itself re-elected for a fourth term in office and it has abandoned this nation and abandoned reform of this nation. The result is pointed out in the Macquarie Bank report. It points out how far down the drain this country looks like going unless and until we start to implement the significant reforms set out in this report. The IAC draws attention to means whereby the gross domestic product could be increased by $16 billion, and average household income by more than $1,600 each year. These broadly-based reforms do not include the large gains which could be expected from greater efficiency in other major services sector activity such as health, education and construction.

SPEECH.PARA: This report goes on in its own quiet way to tear this Government apart. In particular, it makes great criticism of the Treasurer (Mr Keating), who took over responsibility for the Industries Assistance Commission from Senator Button. The Treasurer ripped that responsibility from Senator Button after the last election. The Industries Assistance Commission had to sit on its tail waiting for the Treasurer and his office to get around to giving it the references. At least Senator Button was giving the Industries Assistance Commission a reference and then issuing the press release; the Treasurer went the other way around it. He issued the press release and then four or five months later got around to making the reference.

TALK.START.PARA: —It sounds like his taxation changes.

—Yes, it does. Frankly, that is not good enough. The report makes that perfectly clear. There is one other matter I wish to mention in the last 30 seconds or so of this speech. The IAC points out that alternative assistance measures are not the answer. It is very interesting that Senator Button, despite his rhetoric, has finally started to look for alternative assistance measures. The report refers to the offsets arrangements, the partnerships for development agreements and export market development schemes. It says that they are not the answer. Senator Button now has a report that is costing the Australian Manufacturing Council over $1m and to which the Government has made a substantial contribution. It is to come up with alternative assistance measures, notwithstanding the fact that the Commission, which Senator Button used to hold in high regard, says that these measures are not the answer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The 1988-89 annual report of the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) will be the last report of the Commission, as it is to be restructured. Under the title of the Industry Commission, it is sought to amalgamate the functions of the IAC, the Inter-State Commission and the Business Regulation Review Unit. However, I understand that in the restructuring serious consideration needs to be given to the constitutionally intended distinctive role of the Inter-State Commission in advising on issues in the area of Federal-State relations. Over the last financial year the IAC reports that its inquiry program has focused on the services sector. To this end, it has reported on domestic barriers and impediments to international trade in services. The IAC's report on the service industries has revealed some major inefficiencies within that sector and, as services account for three-quarters of economic activity, it is considered essential that removal of these inefficiencies be given high priority. I concur with the comments made by my colleagues Senator Chaney and Senator Lewis.

SPEECH.PARA: In addition to the services industry, action in other areas, such as the passenger motor vehicle, textiles, clothing, footwear, agricultural and manufacturing industries, I understand will also continue. The Industries Assistance Commission is keen to drive the message home that there is an urgency for micro-economic reform. Micro-economic reform entails getting rid of the obstacles raised by excessive and intrusive regulation-I adhere to that need-the inefficiencies of government enterprise, government-sponsored monopolies, like Telecom Australia, the various State electricity commissions, the restrictive work practices. In effect, to create what is often referred to as a level playing field.

Actually, comment by the Australian Manufacturing Council suggests that micro-economic reform in the form of the low-protection open market model, as espoused by both Labor and the coalition, will not result in the non-resource traded manufacturing sector providing an answer to Australia's trade problems, and that is where my sympathies lie. Whilst some manufacturing industries may use this as an argument for continued assistance, whether in the form of tariffs or tax breaks, I believe it raises an interesting point. The point is that the potential for greater exports lies in the area of raw materials processing; that is, trying to build upon our existing comparative advantages, rather than focus on areas where we are unlikely to succeed.

Australian manufacturers are caught in a pincer of small local markets and an inability to easily supply large export markets. In addition, the existence of brands, consumer franchises, tied distribution arrangements, closeness to markets, economies of scale, proprietary technology and superior purchasing power within the world means Australian companies are unlikely to compete on an equal or level playing field. So, resources dominate our export trade, but we process a relatively small part of these raw materials. The same story applies to wool, hides and cotton exports, woodchips and foods. It is here that great scope exists to boost export revenue. For example, aluminium exports alone are worth $5 billion, and this could rise three times to $15 billion if all bauxite and alumina were transformed to metal.

Perhaps the IAC in its restructured form would be best to look at the tariffs that raise the input costs for export processing, high shipping costs and poor management and labour practices which form other barriers to trade. In addition, the Government should look at the impediments it places on industry in the form of the twice-monthly payment of the pay as you earn tax and the payment of 85 per cent of a tax bill within 15 days of the close of the accounting year. This is quite intolerable so far as companies are concerned.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have got a good point there.
—I am glad that the Minister acknowledges that I have a good point and I certainly hope that he will seek to modify this in the near future.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I rise to speak on the corrigendum to the annual report of Telecom Australia which happens to be an amendment to correct a figure of 98 per cent stated to be the achievement rate for the rural and remote areas program for Telecom to a mere 96 per cent. The significance of that figure may escape the populace at first blush, but I regard it as particularly significant for the following reason: the rural and remote areas program, which costs some $530m, was instituted in 1984-85. Remarkable progress has been made to date although, as I understand it, the installations in remote areas now cost in excess of $30,000 per home.

TALK.START.PARA: —And up to $60,000.

—Well, it could even get as high as that for the remainder of the program. The significance is that this is a classic example of the claim that Telecom needs to make its monopoly profits in order to cross-subsidise the costs of these activities. What we are talking about in this particular area is very small bickies by this stage. Last year some 5,000 new and modernised services were provided. It is very instructive that Telecom does not even bother to insert the real cost in its annual report; so it must be fairly small. In the same way, of course, it does not publish, and refuses to provide to the public, material on which one could calculate the cost of its community service obligations (CSOs).

SPEECH.PARA: That is something that Senator Button and his colleagues have been handballing for months. About 2 1/2 months ago Mr Willis promised to release in the near future the report from the Bureau of Transport and Communications Economics, which would give us a real insight into whether Telecom CSOs were affordable in an open and competitive environment or whether Telecom continues to need the vast monopoly protection that is responsible for something in excess of 75 per cent of its monopoly profits, which last year amounted to $973m.

TALK.START.PARA: —You be very careful or the National Party will jump right on your head.

—That old bogey used to be trotted out with monotonous regularity when everyone thought that the true cost in today's terms was probably $600m or $800m, but the reality is that the Bureau's figure is probably not much more than $100m. I can well understand why Senator Button and his colleagues will sit on that figure until the election: it is dynamite for them; it pulls the rug out from under any justification for Telecom's continued monopoly in this area.

SPEECH.PARA: One thing that I find particularly disappointing is the reference in this context to remote Aboriginal communities. It is said that special attention is being paid to the needs of people residing within the Aboriginal and Islander communities. The fact of the matter is that Telecom is deliberately stalling and frustrating the proposals to extend radiotelephone services to 13 remote Aboriginal communities in the Northern Territory, even to the point that it is contesting a court case that has been brought on the basis that it is part of its community service obligations to provide these services.

The fact of the matter is that these services could be delivered much more cheaply and quickly by Aussat, but Telecom is determined to maintain its own rate of slow-moving progress and to install much more expensive equipment. Those communities will have to wait another 12 months or more before they are connected to the service when, by use of the satellite, it could have been in place in a matter of weeks. I regard this figure that has been corrected today as yet another indication that the rural and remote areas program is coming to its conclusion. It is not costing very much at all. It is simply one further example of there being no continuing need for Telecom's monopoly to be maintained. I just wish the Government would have the courage to face up to the issue.

A failed and discredited Minister like Rip van Willis is clearly out of control in this area. I just wish the Government would step in and face up to the competitive consequences that were supposed to be part of the rhetoric of that third term micro-economic reform agenda.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should like to draw attention to several elements of the Australian Telecommunications Commission's annual report. In doing so, I will also be drawing attention to some of the reasons for the vehemence of Senator Alston, who spoke on behalf of the Opposition.

—I rise on a point of order. I understood Senator Powell to say that she would like to take the opportunity to have a wander through the annual report. This item relates only to the corrigendum, which deals with one particular aspect of the rural and remote areas program; that is, a correction in the percentage increase. Mr Deputy President, I ask that you direct Senator Powell to confine her remarks to that issue only.

—Senator Powell must relate her remarks to the corrigendum. I must say though that, in consideration of papers in the past, that interpretation has been fairly liberally applied by the Chair. I ask Senator Powell in some way to relate her remarks to the corrigendum.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy President, and that is eminently possible especially in the context of the view held by the Australian Democrats in relation to all reports, corrigenda and other items of information from Telecom. When one looks at the country division aspect of the report-and this is a subject of the corrigendum-one is reminded of the role of Telecom and its place in our community. As an example, it produces 2.6 per cent of our gross domestic product which represents the largest contribution to the GDP from a single commercial enterprise in Australia. As Senator Alston pointed out, Telecom Australia has almost completed the provision of telephone services virtually to all Australians and it has done that as part of fulfilling its community service obligations. It has been able to do it by virtue of its ability to cross-subsidise.

SPEECH.PARA: It is important to look at the task that faces Telecom. Australia has a low density population distribution, being only one-twelfth of that of the United States of America, which has a privatised telephone system; one-one hundred and twenty-fifth of that of the United Kingdom; and one-one hundred and fiftieth of that of Japan. In this context productivity and efficiency is often demonstrated by this organisation which, while being the major single enterprise contributor to our GDP, at the same time provides a service to those people who live in remote areas. It has kept its tariffs well below consumer price index increases and compares favourably particularly with other government services provided over the same period. Telecom's costs for residential services to all Australians, even to those people in remote areas where provision of services can be costly and difficult, are ahead of costs in only the United States of America, Sweden and Canada. Many other nations with similar economies have much higher residential service costs.

In that context, the Australian Democrats believe it is important that we do not undermine the position of this enterprise which, after all, belongs to and serves the whole community-clearly something with which the Opposition does not agree.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SALES TAX (EXEMPTIONS AND CLASSIFICATIONS) AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1989

Mr President, this Bill will make a number of amendments to the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act to give effect to sales tax changes announced in the Environment Statement of 20 July 1989, in the 1989-90 Budget and in a statement by the Minister Assisting the Treasurer when moving an amendment to the Bill in another place on 31 October 1989.
Certain recycled paper products
The Bill will ensure that certain paper products are exempt from sales tax, if all the paper in the goods has been manufactured from recycled paper.
This proposal was announced by the Prime Minister in his Environment Statement on 20 July 1989.
The revenue effect of the amendment, which will operate with effect from 5 October 1989, is estimated to be less than $500,000 in a full year.

Honourable Senators will recall that when this initiative was announced the Prime Minister foreshadowed a further review to determine the practicability of expanding the range of goods made of recycled paper that are to be exempt from sales tax.
An announcement about the outcome of the review will be made shortly.
Goods for use by sub-contractors in carrying out activities of a manufacturing nature

The Bill gives effect to the proposal announced in the 1989-90 Budget to extend the range of goods to be exempt from sales tax where those goods are for use by a sub-contractor exclusively in carrying out activities on behalf of one or more manufacturers.

In addition, following an amendment moved by the Minister Assisting the Treasurer in the Committee stage in another place on 31 October 1989, the proposal has been extended to also allow exemption where the persons engaging the sub-contractors are not technically manufacturers for sales tax purposes.

The exemption is to be available only if each of the persons engaging the sub-contractors could have obtained exemption for the goods under the existing `aids to manufacture' provisions of the sales tax law had that person acquired and used the goods to carry out the contracted activities.
This change will operate from 4 October 1989 and is estimated to cost $3.5 million in 1989-90 and $6 million in 1990-91.
Small manufacturers
The Bill will increase the small manufacturer exemption thresholds.
From 4 October 1989, sales of goods by a small manufacturer with average annual sales of $50,000 or less may qualify for exemption from sales tax.
Similarly, goods manufactured by a manufacturer may be exempt if the sales tax that would have been payable by the manufacturer does not exceed $1000 per annum.
Manufacturers who qualify for exemption in respect of goods they sell are unable to obtain free of tax inputs to the manufacture of those goods such as raw materials and aids to manufacture.
The net cost to revenue of increasing these thresholds is estimated to be $8 million in 1989-90 and $11 million in a full year.
Flavoured milk

Finally, the sales tax law is being amended so that, effective from 16 August 1989, flavoured milk drinks that contain at least 90 per cent milk are subject to tax at the concessional rate of 10 per cent.
This reduction from the earlier 95 per cent content requirement was announced in the 1989-90 Budget.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
SALES TAX (EXEMPTIONS AND CLASSIFICATIONS) (COMPUTER PROGRAMS) AMENDMENT BILL 1989
This Bill complements one of the main measures in the Sales Tax Laws (Computer Programs) Amendment Bill 1989, about which I have just spoken.
By that Bill, sales tax is to be removed on all computer programs other than those on microchips.
A general principle of the sales tax law is that, where goods are subject to sales tax, goods for use exclusively or principally in manufacturing the taxable goods are exempt from sales tax.
Without such an exemption there would be an element of double taxation of the manufactured goods.
On this basis, under the present law, goods for use exclusively, or primarily and principally in embodying computer programs in goods are free from sales tax as ``aids to manufacture''.

Consistent with the removal of sales tax on computer programs proposed by the other Bill, this Bill will remove in part-and allow regulations to be made to remove the rest of-the ``aids to manufacture'' exemption in relation to computer programs that I have just described, except where the goods are for use exclusively or principally in embodying programs in microchips.
Changes to the Sales Tax Regulations to narrow the definition of ``aids to manufacture'' in those regulations will be submitted to the Executive Council as soon as practicable.
The changes will apply from 23 December 1988, as announced by the Treasurer.
Their revenue impact will be negligible.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
SALES TAX LAWS (COMPUTER PROGRAMS) AMENDMENT BILL 1989

This is the first of 2 Bills to amend the sales tax law to give effect to the Treasurer's announcement on 22 December 1988 that sales tax liability for all computer software other than firmware would be removed.
At present under the sales tax law, computer programs as such, because they are not goods, are not subject to sales tax.
However, the sale value of tangible carrying media for programs (such as floppy disks) include the value of the programs when calculating the amount of sales tax payable on the goods.
This Bill will reduce the sale value of goods containing computer programs by the amount of that value attributable to the programs.
In addition, the sale value will be further reduced by the amount of that value attributable to an instruction manual that forms part of the goods.
The carrying medium for programs and the packaging will, however, continue to be taxable.
The Bill treats as firmware computer programs on microchips.

In accordance with the Treasurer's announcement that the sales tax exemption for software would not extend to firmware, there will be no reduction in the sale value for programs on microchips-typically, programs permanently built into appliances. Where the only programs in the goods are on microchips, there will also be no reduction in the sale value for an instruction manual.
The cost to revenue of this measure is estimated to be $10 million in 1988-89, $30 million in 1989-90 and $35 million in 1990-91.
The changes will apply, as announced by the Treasurer, from 23 December 1988.

In developing this Bill it has come to attention that a number of taxpayers may have acted on the basis of a view of the Treasurer's announcement under which their sales tax liability on goods containing computer programs would be less than that proposed by this Bill.

The Commissioner of Taxation has assured me that, given the uncertainty that existed in this area and as sales tax is a tax ultimately borne by the consumer from whom it would be impracticable for a taxpayer to recover any further tax on goods already sold, he will not be seeking to increase any taxpayer's liability beyond that which the taxpayer could reasonably have expected.
The opportunity is also being taken in this Bill to make a number of other amendments to the sales tax law.
One is an amendment of a concessional nature to correct a deficiency in the present law.

This amendment will ensure that, where goods containing sounds or visual images (records, videos and the like) or goods containing computer programs on microchips are subject to sales tax when sold by retail or treated as stock for sale by retail, any licence fee for the right to use the sounds, images or programs is included in the sale value of the carrying medium on the fee's wholesale value not its retail value.
The amendment, which will have a negligible financial impact (if any), will apply from tomorrow.

Another change to be made by this Bill has become necessary because extensions of the sales tax base or increases in rates of sales tax commonly take effect earlier than the date of enactment of the amending legislation-for example, from the date of introduction of the amending legislation into the Parliament.

Consequently, because sales tax is a tax payable monthly, persons technically may be required, on a basis that is effectively retrospective to do or not to do certain things-such as to register for sales tax purposes and to pay sales tax-before the amending legislation becomes law.

On enactment, a person who has failed to register or to pay sales tax on transactions since the date of introduction technically, and retrospectively, becomes guilty of an offence or liable to additional tax by way of penalty.

This Bill will ensure that any amendments made by it or any future sales tax Bills will not result in a person being guilty of an offence or liable to additional tax by way of penalty for acts or omissions before the 28th day after the day on which the amending legislation concerned receives Royal Assent.

Consistent with that, any obligations arising from such amendments that presently should be met before the 27th day after Royal Assent is given to the amending legislation will in future not formally have to be met before that day.
In practice, this amendment is unlikely to change much of the past.

It has been longstanding Taxation Office practice to encourage registration, payment of tax and so on in the period before enactment of new sales tax changes-in recognition of the impracticability of a taxpayer recovering sales tax from retailers and consumers after the latter have already bought goods affected by the changes-but not to penalise taxpayers who decline to do so.
The revenue impact, if any, will therefore be negligible.
Finally, the Bill will alter a number of incorrect cross-references in the sales tax law, also with effect from tomorrow.

In closing, I would like to express my thanks to the Australian Information Industry Association, the Software and Services Industry Federation of Australia and the National Sales Tax Liaison Committee for the constructive comments they gave in the short time made available to them to examine a draft of this Bill and the other Bill in this package.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Knowles) adjourned.

PRIMARY INDUSTRIES AND ENERGY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1989

This Bill is an omnibus Bill for legislation administered within the Primary Industries and Energy portfolio. The Bill covers amendments to the Wool Marketing Act 1987, Australian Meat and Live-stock Research and Development Act 1985, Honey Levy Collection Act 1962, Honey Marketing Act 1988, Soil Conservation (Financial Assistance) Act 1985, Barley Research Levy Collection Act 1980, Oilseeds Levy Collection Act 1977, Oilseeds Levy Act 1977, Rural Industries Research Act 1985 and Wheat Marketing Act 1989 and repeals the Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Levy Act 1984, Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Levy Collection Act 1984, Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Trust Fund Act 1984 and Customs Tariff (Stand-by) Duty Act 1985.
I wish to cover the more significant amendments to be made by the Bill.
There are a number of amendments to be made to the Wool Marketing Act 1987. The most important amendment to that Act relates to the statutory arrangements for Wool Research and Development.

Wool remains our most important commodity export, worth around $6 billion in 1988-89. In a world context, although less than 15 per cent of the world's sheep flock is in Australia, we produce around three-quarters of the apparel wool traded internationally. Australia's wool industry is, therefore, at the forefront internationally, but we must continue to make improvements if the industry is to remain competitive on world markets. The key to further productivity gains, both on and off the farm, lies in effective research and development and efforts.

The Wool Research and Development Fund is by far the largest fund established under the Government's rural industry research policies with a $56 million expenditure program planned for 1989-90. If these funds are to be used most efficiently and effectively we need to ensure that the administrative arrangements are of the highest calibre. To this end, extensive discussions have been held between the Wool Council of Australia, the representative body of the woolgrowers, and myself and agreement has been reached on several changes to the Wool Research and Development arrangements. In making these changes, the Government has taken into account the established domestic and international links between research, promotion and marketing in the wool industry.

The purposes of the changes are to increase industry involvement in the determination of long-term R & D strategies and to facilitate the commercial exploitation of the results of R & D efforts. Changes will be made to the constitution of the Wool Research and Development Council, and to the selection procedures for its members. Accountability of the Council to the industry and the Minister will also be strengthened.

The membership of the Council is to consist of a Chairperson selected by the Minister, in consultation with the Australian Wool Corporation Chairperson; a government member selected by the Minister; an Executive Director selected jointly by the Wool Corporation Managing Director and the Council Chairperson; and 7 other members selected by the Australian Wool Industry Selection Committee. All members, except the Executive Director, will be part-time members and will hold office for up to three years (except the government member who is appointed at the Minister's pleasure), and are eligible for re-appointment.

The composition, functions and powers of the Australian Wool Industry Selection Committee for the purposes of selection of members of the Council, is to be the same as for the selection of Wool Corporation Directors. Selections made by the Committee for the Council will be against specific areas of expertise listed in the Act, and will put forward those persons who will best ensure the members of the Council collectively possess the listed areas of expertise. These arrangements should provide the Council with a broader range of expertise amongst its members than has been the case in the past.

The Selection Committee will invite the Wool Corporation and the Wool Council to nominate persons to it for consideration. To ensure that an effective linkage between the Corporation and Council is maintained, the nominations forwarded to the Minister by the Selection Committee shall contain up to 3 persons from those nominated by the Corporation.
The Selection Committee will also be able to advertise nationally for applications and will be able to engage the services of an executive search consultant in the selection process.

In order to ensure that there are no undue disruptions during the period between the passage of the legislation and the appointment of a new Council, transitional provisions have been included in this Bill. Those persons who currently hold office shall continue to do so; in the case of the Chairperson for the remainder of his appointment, or in the case of the remaining members until the end of their appointment or until the Minister terminates the appointment. It is my intention that the new selection arrangements for the Council will be activated early in the new year, with a view to appointments of these seven members being made by April 1990.

Consultation between the Council and the industry and accountability to the industry is an important element of the new arrangements. In the preparation of the R & D plan and annual program, the Council is to consult with the Wool Council and other departments/agencies and to take into consideration any comments these bodies may have. R & D plans and programs are to be submitted by Council Chairperson, through the Wool Corporation, to the Minister for agreement. The five year R & D plans will also be `rolling' plans to enable adjustments to be made during the period specified in the plan. The Council will report in a separate annual report to the Minister, which will be tabled in Parliament, and to the industry.

The final important alteration to the wool R & D arrangements relates to the commercial exploitation of the results of research. Through amendments in this Bill, the Wool Corporation will be able to carry out activities relating to the commercial exploitation of results using Wool R & D Fund monies upon the recommendation of the Council.

In conjunction with this innovation, the Wool Corporation, subject to Ministerial approval under section 11 of the Act, will be able to establish a technology adoption company to commercialise the results of research supported by the Fund.

The Bill also makes amendments relating to refunds of the Market Support Fund portion of wool tax to clarify the timing of the payment of the refund and to provide a means of making inspections to ensure that the provisions of the Act relating to refunds are being complied with.

Additionally, the Bill provides for inspections to be made for registration purposes of wool sampling sites, showfloors or testing laboratories involved in the export wool trade. The registrations, which are effected under the Wool Marketing Regulations, assist in ensuring that wool which is exported meets certain quality standards.

The final amendments to the Wool Marketing Act covered by this Bill relate to the consequential amendments arising from the repeal of the Commonwealth Functions (Statutes Review) Act 1981 under the schedule of the Bill.

Turning to the Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Levy Act 1984, the Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Levy Collection Act 1984, the Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Trust Fund Act 1984 and the Customs Tariff (Stand-by) Duty Act 1985.

The Bill will repeal these Acts which gave effect to the import parity pricing policy and the Bass Strait Coastal Freight Adjustment Scheme which were terminated in 1987. The Acts were not terminated immediately to ensure that the oil companies discharged their obligations under the Bass Strait crude oil allocation scheme, which previously prescribed the amount of crude oil produced in the Bass Strait that Australia's oil companies were obliged to buy. The scheme has now been successfully concluded, and the Acts can be duly repealed.

There are three amendments to the Australian Meat and Live-stock Research and Development Corporation Act 1985. The first, to section 7, implements the original intention of the Act in relation to investment in that the Corporation will be empowered to invest surplus funds in specified classes of securities without the requirement to obtain prior Ministerial approval for each transaction.

Sub-paragraph 24 (1) (a) (ii) of the Act, relating to lodgment of notices of motion to be put before the Annual General Meeting, is amended to remove an inconsistency in the Act which resulted from amendments made in 1987.

The effect of the other amendments is to bring the provisions contained in the Act in respect of the remuneration and allowances paid to the Executive Director and staff of that organisation into line with those to apply to similar organisations under the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Bill. The amendments, which are being made at the request of the Australian Meat and Live-stock Research and Development Corporation, will provide greater flexibility for that organisation to recruit suitable senior staff. The terms and conditions of employment of the Executive Director will require the approval of the Minister.

The amendment of the Honey Levy Collection Act 1962 is aimed at simplifying procedures and reducing the cost to industry of collecting levies. Proceeds of the levies fund the operations of the Australian Honey Board and provide industry contributions to honey research programs.

The proposed amendments provide for monthly levy payers who believe that their liability in a particular year will be less than $100 a month for at least 7 months or $1200 for the full year to apply for exemption and instead pay annually.
These amendments are being introduced with the concurrence of industry. They will impose no additional cost to the Government but are expected to reduce the cost to industry of Levy collections.

The amendments to the Honey Marketing Act 1988, which establishes the Australian Honey Board; correct a spelling error and clarify the sunset provision of the Act. Subsection 62 (1) at present provides for the Act to cease to apply 6 years after its commencement. As some provisions of the Act commenced with Royal Assent on 11 May 1988 and the remainder become operative upon proclamation 1 January 1989, there is ambiguity as to cessation date. The amendment will clarify the Act by specifying 6 years from the date of Royal Assent.

The Soil Conservation (Financial Assistance) Act 1985 currently provides for a Committee with a maximum membership of seven, to make recommendations to the Minister with respect to priorities and strategies for activities by the Commonwealth relating to Soil Conservation and for matters relevant to the operation of the Act.

An increase in the membership of the Committee is required to successfully implement the change in operation of the National Soil Conservation program from a project to program based approach and also retain the range of expertise on the Committee at times when some members are unable to attend meetings.

The National Soil Conservation program has recently had its budget increased by more than 100 per cent to $23.4 million in 1989-90 with a commitment by the Government to provide a total of $260 million over the next ten years to the program. The program itself has been restructured so that funding is now provided under four sub-programs; community landcare support, research, major support and public awareness, education and training.

It is intended that the Committee will become more proactive in recommending projects for funding under the various sub-programs and accordingly an expansion to a twelve member Committee drawn from State Government, conservation, farmer, academic and local Government interests is proposed to replace the original seven member body.
I turn now to the Barley Research Levy Collection Act 1980, the Oilseeds Levy Collection Act 1977 and the Oilseeds Levy Act 1977.
The aim of the amendments is to standardise collection periods, and enable consolidation of return forms for levies collected under the various grain Levy legislation.

The Grains Council of Australia has indicated full support for the amendments, which should lead to savings in administrative effort for some Levy payers. These savings would arise by removing confusion caused by the present variations in collecting periods, and by reducing the number of returns to be submitted from a maximum of 20 to 4 per year.
The Wheat Marketing Act 1989 is being amended to correct an anomaly in regard to the Australian Wheat Board's borrowing powers.

As the Act now stands, the Wheat Board can fund advance payments to wheat growers only by borrowing money, whereas it can raise finance for any other purpose by either borrowing or by dealing with securities.
The Board raises the bulk of its monies for advance payments by dealing with securities under facilities which in some cases have been in place for a number of years.

There was never any intention to limit the Board's access to the full range of funding mechanisms offered by the market by having different wording in the relevant sections of the Act which relate to these separate financing activities.

The amendment also makes it clear that since a proportion of the finance raised to fund advance payments is underwritten by the Commonwealth, any payment to the Board to meet that liability must be used to repay those outstanding borrowings.
In addition, the amendments enable the research component of funds raised under the Wheat Industry Fund Levy Act 1989 to be transferred to the Wheat Research Trust Fund.
Under the Wheat Marketing Act 1989, the Grains Council of Australia determines an operative Levy rate each year for the purposes of the Wheat Research Trust Fund and the Wheat Industry Fund.

On the recommendation of the Grains Council regulations have been made setting the wheat Levy at 2.5 per cent for the 1989/90 season apportioning it such that 2 per cent will be used for the Wheat Industry Fund and 0.5 per cent will be used for the Wheat Research Trust Fund.

Amendments to the Rural Industries Research Act 1985 are now required to enable the portion of the Levy intended for research to be directed to the Wheat Research Trust Fund. In the absence of these amendments, funds levied from the wheat industry for the purposes of research are unavailable for use by the State research committees. This money will remain in consolidated revenue until a mechanism for its release is enacted. These amendments provide the necessary mechanism.

As the 1989-90 wheat harvest will not begin in earnest until October, very little money has been levied under the new arrangements. Only old season crop delivered after 1 July this year has so far been subject to the Levy. Nevertheless, to ensure that those funds which have already been levied under the new arrangements are made available for their intended purpose, the amendments will be effective from 1 July 1989.

This is not a retrospective tax. The money in question has already been raised. The amendment is only retrospective in that it will ensure that money which has already been levied for wheat research will be made available to the State Wheat Research Committees.
None of the proposed amendments have any significant financial impact.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators, and present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
PRIMARY INDUSTRIES AND ENERGY RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT BILL 1989

The purpose of this Bill is to provide for the establishment of Research and Development Corporations in the Primary Industries and Energy portfolio to replace the present Research Councils and Committees which administer the allocation of R&D program funds.

The Bill recognises the need for closer involvement of industry in determining the objectives of research and development. It will bring about improvements in the organisation and administration of research and development. These improvements will enable the expenditure of research funds to be conducted in a more autonomous and flexible manner.
As part of its overall review of science and technology policies, the Government has recognised the need for a more integrated approach to research policy across the primary and energy industries.
The Government proposes to make research and development in this area more efficient and effective while continuing to produce results relevant to industry needs.

The changes proposed are in three major areas-funding, co-ordination and evaluation of research efforts. The Government considers that there is a need for more research/industry interaction and the arrangements proposed in this Bill are designed to address this need.

This Bill builds on the outstanding record of this Government in encouraging research in the primary and energy industries. In May 1989, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy and I made a statement entitled ``Research, Innovation and Competitiveness''. In this statement the Government reaffirmed its commitment to continued matching of industry levies for funding of R&D in the rural industries up to 0.5 per cent of gross value of production.

This follows the proposals, contained in the Government's 1988 `Policies for Growth' Statement, that all rural industries participating in the arrangements should aim for a levy of 0.5 per cent of gross value of production by 1992.

The current Commonwealth contribution averages around 0.29 per cent of gross value of production over all industries currently receiving Commonwealth funds. In 1989-90, the combined value of Government/industry funding for rural industry research will be approximately $141m. Under the new arrangements, this amount should increase in 1990-91.

The Government will continue to fund soil, water and energy R&D from appropriations. In 1989-90 funding in this area was approximately $25 million. The Government will also continue the coal research levy and introduce new arrangements for forestry R&D.

The new arrangements contained in this Bill will enhance the capacity of Australia's primary and energy industries to innovate and adjust. In particular, the Bill sets out arrangements for the establishment of research and development corporations and the preferred structure for the administration of R&D program funds. The Government considers that the corporate form of administration will give the best results because of the operating and financial flexibility it will bring.

The proposed R&D corporations will provide strategic leadership to industry R&D and act as a catalyst to stimulate R&D interest within industry. They will take a pro-active role in identifying and filling gaps in the research effort. It is expected that the R&D corporations, operating on a more commercial basis, will be able to expand the level of resources available for R&D, improve the efficiency with which R&D monies are spent and bring a focus to funding R&D in high payoff areas.

The Government expects the new corporations to improve the adoption of research results. This should demonstrate the benefits of increased R&D funding. In turn this should encourage industry to increase levies beyond the level which attracts matched grants from the Commonwealth.
Commonwealth contributions should ideally be seen as seed money to encourage industry contributions. The new R&D corporations will have a key role in generating, as well as allocating, money for R&D.
The objectives for R&D corporations set out in the Bill are:
* increasing the economic, environmental and social benefits to the rural and wider community;
* promoting the sustainable use and management of natural resources;
* making more effective use of the community's resources and of the skills of the scientific community; and
* improving accountability for expenditure on primary industries R&D.

In the Bill, the definition of research which R&D corporations fund is deliberately wide. It covers any experimentation in science, technology or economics which is carried out with a view to improving production, processing, storage, transport and marketing in these industries.

It is envisaged that R&D Corporations will initially be established in the dairy, grain, coal, natural resources and energy industries and in those existing Rural Industry Research Councils where the industry decides on an independent R&D corporation.

Additionally, a Rural Industries Research and Development Corporation will be established to cover the present Australian Special Rural Research Council. This corporation will also cover those industries which decide not to form an R&D corporation in their own right nor to merge with another R&D corporation.

It is expected that most R&D corporations will be established from 1 July 1990 under regulations in accordance with the provisions of this Bill, although a start before that date would be possible if an industry were willing to make the necessary arrangements. The Bill also contains provisions to cover the transitional period. The Minister seeks a contribution from those involved in the present administrative structures to ensure that there will be a smooth transition to incorporation.
The proposed R&D corporations will be bodies corporate. They will have the power to:
* apply for patents or otherwise manage intellectual property;
* set up their own committees;
* employ staff and set terms and conditions for their employment;
* charge for services and information;
* enter into agreements or joint ventures for R&D activities;
* act as trustee for money or property;
* accept gifts or bequests;
* acquire real or personal property; and
* form companies.
The corporations will also be able to borrow or raise money with the written approval of the Minister.

The corporations will be required to prepare R&D plans in consultation with their industries or constituent groups. Each Board will establish the priorities and focus of its corporation's operations. The resultant plans will outline their objectives for a five year period and the strategies and policies they intend to adopt.

In addition, R&D corporations will be required to prepare an operational plan for each financial year, consistent with the five year R&D plan. This annual plan will specify the broad groupings of R&D activities the corporation proposes to fund in that year, the likely administrative expenses and the expected receipts. The plans will be submitted to the Minister, who examines their consistency with the overall strategic direction proposed in the five year R&D plans and approves them.
The R&D corporations will be responsible to the Minister for carrying out these plans.
The Government considers that this process should enhance the corporations' capacity to direct research and development towards achieving industry-endorsed objectives.

In addition to co-ordinating and funding R&D activities consistent with their annual operational plans, the corporations will monitor and evaluate those activities. They will not simply play a passive role in allocating money. Evaluation of projects will be done against an assessment of industry needs and objectives as embodied in the strategic plans.

The corporations are also charged with facilitating the dissemination, adoption and commercialisation of research results. This is a very important part of their function. It is through technology transfer that research results can be put into practice, and progress can be made towards greater innovation and commercialisation in industry. The Government expects these new arrangements to maximise the returns on the money spent.
Research and development is vital to the profitability of the primary and energy industries and increased concentration is needed to ensure that research results are not wasted.
The effective use of networking will play a major role in assisting R&D corporations to increase their effectiveness and to encourage greater investment.

R&D corporations will be responsible for developing close liaison with each other. This will do much to ensure informed decision making and collaboration between corporations. It will assist in reducing unnecessary duplication and provide flexibility. It may also result in joint funding of projects and sharing of results.
Although the R&D corporations are designed to be autonomous, the Government also proposes that they should be accountable to the providers of the funds.
In addition to the five year strategic plans and annual operational plans, the corporations will be required to provide an Annual Report to be tabled in the Parliament.
The corporations will be subject to the requirements of the Audit Act.

Annual Reports will address performance against the key elements identified in the strategic plans. Corporations will also be accountable to the industry, which supplies a significant proportion of their funds, through the presentation of Annual Reports or by way of an Annual General Meeting. Annual Reports should contain enough information to allow the industry to make a comprehensive assessment of the value of the R&D activities undertaken.

Amendments to the Bill agreed in the other place allow for the Governor-General to consider the recommendations of industry representative organisations prior to determining through the regulations that the provisions regarding Annual General Meetings will apply to a particular R&D corporation.

I believe that there is a case for direct accountability to stakeholders in Annual General Meetings as the principal means of accountability for specific industries. However, I recognise that with other industries, accountability to the executive of organisations which represent stakeholders may be more appropriate. The Government will determine the particular accountability mechanism to apply for each R&D corporation in agreement with the relevant industry. It does not intend to impose Annual General Meetings on industries.
Corporations will consist of nine directors, comprising a Chairperson, a government-nominated director, six directors nominated by an independent selection committee and an Executive Director.

The Chairperson will be selected by the Minister, as will the government director. The Minister will be looking for Chairpersons with strong leadership and strategic skills, experience in commercial management and an appreciation of the vital role of R&D in enhancing industry performance.

The Government director will also be selected on the basis of expertise in R&D management and experience and knowledge of Government policy processes. The continued Government involvement in these appointments reflects our desire to play a role commensurate with the Commonwealth financial contribution.

The Executive Director will be selected by the corporations. This person has a key role, being an ex officio director of the Board as well as the day-to-day manager of a corporation's operations. Corporations will also be empowered to employ professional staff on terms and conditions determined by the Boards.

The Bill sets out arrangements for the constitution of independent selection committees designed to ensure the best available people are selected for appointment as directors, also on the basis of their expertise. This is a change from the previous arrangement where there was a common selection committee for all research councils. Separate selection committees for each industry will allow the relevant industry to have a greater influence in the selection process.

These selection committees will be set up on an ``ad hoc'' basis. The Minister will appoint the Presiding Member and he/she will have the responsibility of establishing a committee when a selection task arises. The committee will be disbanded when the selection process has been completed.

The Committee will comprise three to six persons nominated by the dominant industry organisations. In those cases where the corporation is funded predominantly from appropriations, the Minister will have the opportunity to appoint persons of his/her choosing to the selection committee.

One advantage of ad hoc selection committees is that they can be tailored to suit immediate needs, both in numbers and expertise. A specific example is scientific expertise which will be of importance to Selection Committees for all corporations. The Minister will write to the industries concerned about the importance of scientific representation on the Selection Committees and the need to take this into account in making their nominations.

Since selection committees will be formed only when required, it is considered appropriate that members of selection committees should themselves be eligible for consideration as Board directors in any subsequent selection process.
To safeguard against conflicts of interests, however, members of the Executives of industry bodies will not be eligible for nomination as Board directors.
Selection committees will be required to nominate persons for appointment to R&D corporations on the basis of expertise in one or more of the fields of:
* commodity production;
* processing or marketing;
* natural resource conservation or management;
* science, technology and technology transfer;
* environmental and ecological matters;
* economics;
* administration of R&D; and
* finance or business management.

While it is expected that Boards should be nominated on the basis of achieving a balance of skills it is not expected that all criteria must be met for every Board. I do, however, see that in striking a balance Selection Committees will maintain the need for certain specific expertise areas to be covered such as scientific expertise.
I now turn to the Rural Industries R&D Corporation which will operate under different arrangements.

The Rural Industries R&D Corporation will incorporate the present Australian Special Rural Research Fund which funds small industry, multi-industry and national interest R&D for rural industries. The Rural Industries R&D Corporation will essentially be established on the same footing as other corporations under the legislation. In addition, it will provide a facility for incorporating Councils for those industries which have decided not to opt for a separate R&D corporation nor to merge with another corporation.

Where this occurs, special arrangements will be introduced to ensure that those councils and their industries are not disadvantaged by incorporation as an R&D Council within the Rural Industries R&D Corporation.

The R&D Councils established under the Rural Industries R&D Corporation will control their own funds, continue to have a separate selection process and be responsible for their own strategic plans and annual reports.

Specifically, R&D Councils' responsibilities will include, as for corporations, the preparation of five year strategic R&D plans in consultation with their industries, and annual operational plans designed to focus their activities around industry-endorsed objectives. Again, as for corporations, they will be required to fund and monitor research, facilitate the dissemination, adoption and commercialisation of results of research and report annually to the Minister on their activities.

R&D Councils will be subject to the requirements of the Audit Act and will be accountable to their representative organisations. The Chairperson will be required to meet with the Executive of representative organisations on an annual basis.

Councils, however, will not be bodies corporate and will not be empowered to borrow funds, enter into agreements, take out patents, form companies and so on. But they will, as part of the Rural Industries R&D Corporation, be able to call on it to perform such functions on their behalf.

R&D councils will not be required to contribute to the Rural Industries R&D Corporation overheads and costs associated with the Board of the corporation. They will only have to meet the cost, on a user pays basis for services requested by them for the corporation to perform or which they have a statutory obligation to meet, that is, entering into agreements and paying their audit fees.

R&D Councils will be established on the same basis as research councils under the present Rural Industries Research Act. They will consist of up to nine members: a Chairperson, a government member and three to seven other members. The Chairpersons and government members will be selected by the Minister and the other members will be selected by an independent selection committee.

The Minister will appoint the Chairperson and one member, on the basis of scientific expertise, as a core group to the selection committee. When selections are to be made for the Rural Industry R&D Corporation or the Councils, three nominees from the representative organisation will be appointed to join the core group.

The measures set out in this Bill will involve Commonwealth outlays of a one-off nature at the time of establishment of each corporation. This relates to the need to transfer reserves of present funds to the new R&D corporations. On present indications amounts of approximately $3.5m-4m in 1989/90 and approximately $76m in future years are indicated. The Minister for Finance, in consultation with the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, will determine the exact timing of the transfer of these reserves. Costs for establishing new R&D corporations will be met from current program funds.

Administration matters will be transferred from the Department of Primary Industries and Energy to the R&D corporations, but it is not expected that this will result in higher costs to industry, as administrative costs are already cost-recovered from Research Council funds.

There may, in fact, be cost savings to industry in that the corporations will be free to share staff and premises, if they consider this appropriate, and can locate in whatever part of the country they consider most beneficial.

The ability to undertake fund raising beyond the levy collection process will also increase their capacity to offset such costs. The Commonwealth will, of course, continue to contribute to a proportion of administrative costs in the rural sector by virtue of the 50 per cent matching of levies.

The major impact of the Bill will be in providing flexibility and autonomy to the administration of research and development and in providing industry with a greater influence on the objectives towards which research and development expenditure is directed. The Government considers that this is necessary if industry is to recognise the value of research and development expenditure and invest more in this area. This is vital if our primary and energy industries are to remain competitive and profitable in a rapidly changing world.
I commend the Bill to Honourable Senators and present the Explanatory Memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Senator Knowles) adjourned.
