STATES GRANTS (SCHOOLS ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1989

The main purposes of this Bill are to amend the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Act 1988 to implement decisions in the recent Budget on Commonwealth programs for schools in 1990 and to supplement for cost increases grants already appropriated for schools programs for 1989.

As foreshadowed in the Governments Rural Statement in April 1989, there are also changes to improve the educational access of rural students. This Bill provides for government and non-government organisations operating hostels providing accommodation for rural students to apply for funding under the general element of the Capital Grants Program. It also provides for the establishment of a Rural Hostels Program to provide assistance to such hostels with an initial allocation in 1990 of $1 million.

Eligibility under the New Arrivals Element of the English as a Second Language Program is also being broadened. This Bill provides that students enrolling in the first formal year of primary school will be eligible for New Arrivals funding where they arrived in Australia up to eighteen months previously.
The Bill also amends the definition of full fee paying overseas student so that it applies to primary as well as secondary students.

The Bill appropriates an estimated $2,212 million for schools programs in 1990, and provides for additional funds for 1989 programs in line with cost supplementation arrangements to bring total funding for 1989 programs to an estimated $2,055 million.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
HIGHER EDUCATION FUNDING AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1989

The purpose of the Bill is to amend the Higher Education Funding Act which provides funding for 1989-91 triennium. The Bill provides funding for higher education institutions for 1992 amounting to $2865 million in accordance with the rolling triennial funding arrangements. It takes account of the Government decision to provide funding of $34 million for an additional 4000 intakes in 1992 and additional funding for capital projects in 1992 to bring the total annual funding for major works in 1992 to $198 million. These measures honour the Government's commitment announced in the White Paper for the continued expansion of higher education to provide for a more highly skilled and educated Australian community.

These funds will allow the Government to make early decisions on new capital projects to commence in 1992 in order to facilitate the proper planning of these developments. Many of these capital projects will take into account mergers which have occurred or are occurring in many parts of the country.

In relation to one of those mergers, that between the University of Western Australia and Murdoch University, I take the opportunity to announce a major new development which will become possible should the merger be given legislative effect. Agriculture is a vital area of study for Western Australia but the facilities at the Crawley campus have for some time been inadequate. The merger provides the opportunity for agriculture to be relocated to the Murdoch campus which already offers veterinary science as well as having developed a very strong capacity in the physical and biological sciences. This is one of the earliest examples of the advantages which can arise from mergers. To assist with the planning for this development the Government will fund the relocation of agriculture, currently estimated to cost $17 million, commencing in 1992 and will also fund other capital projects consistent with the new university's priorities.

Increased funding is being provided for 1990 and 1991 amounting to some $13 million in accordance with the Government's cost supplementation arrangements. The Bill also provides for the incorporation of Australian Research Council programs into the Act in line with the Government's decision to fund these programs on a rolling triennial basis. It includes additional amounts for new research initiatives of $150 million over the 1990-92 triennium announced by the Government in its Science and Technology statement in May 1989.
I present the Explanatory Memorandum and commend the Bill to the Senate.
STUDENT ASSISTANCE AMENDMENT (No. 2) BILL 1989

The Student Assistance Amendment (No. 2) Bill seeks to amend the Student Assistance Act 1973, which provides the legislative basis for AUSTUDY and the Postgraduate Awards Scheme, to enhance the debt recovery regime for outstanding student assistance debts. It contains two main measures.

First, it will extend the application of existing provisions of the Student Assistance Act relating to the prevention of fraud and the recovery of overpayments; the provisions concern matters such as garnishee action to recover debts incurred under the Act and the penalties for false statements in connection with applications made under the Act. The provisions will be extended to apply to the non-legislated student assistance schemes, namely the Assistance for Isolated Children, ABSTUDY and Aboriginal Overseas Study Awards Schemes. To further streamline processing debts under these schemes, action to waive or write off such debts will be taken under the Student Assistance Act, rather than by the exercise of a delegation under the Audit Act as is currently the case.

Second, the Bill provides that interest is to become payable on outstanding debts, whether incurred under AUSTUDY or Postgraduate Awards or under one of the non-legislated schemes. Interest will commence three months after a debtor has been advised of the debt. However, provision is made for the Department to approve an interest-free period in cases of financial hardship, particularly where the debtor has come to an arrangement to repay the debt by instalments.
The Bill would apply simple interest accruing on a daily basis. The regulations will specify a formula giving a commercially comparable rate of interest.

The intention is that the recovery of student assistance debts should proceed in a manner comparable to normal commercial practice. This must include the application of a commercially comparable rate of interest so that debtors do not effectively have an interest-free loan from the public purse. Having said this, I should perhaps add that the introduction of an interest provision will affect only recalcitrant debtors who do not settle their debts or come to some arrangement with the Department within three months of having been advised of the debt.

The Bill will also enable Ministerial guidelines to be set giving guidance in the exercise of various administrative powers under the Student Assistance Act. Action will be taken as soon as possible to set guidelines relating to the waiver, writing off and recovery by instalments of overpayments, and to the approval of interest-free periods. In view of the proposed guidelines, the Bill seeks to extend the range of officers to whom Ministerial powers under the Act may be delegated.

A significant number of amendments have been made to the Student Assistance Act since its enactment over sixteen years ago, and the Bill therefore proposes to renumber the Act so that all provisions will now be numbered sequentially.

I have referred to the Postgraduate Awards Scheme as coming under the Student Assistance Act. The Government is significantly improving the research component of this scheme by injecting more money and devolving the administration of research awards to individual institutions. As a result of the devolution, Postgraduate Research Awards are ceasing to be administered under the Student Assistance Act.

I come now to the financial impact of the proposed measures. It is estimated that the Bill will result in increased debt recovery of approximately $5m over the two years 1990-91 and 1991-92. The effect may then lessen, reflecting the resolution of existing debts and the introduction of more effective fraud control.

I would add that the significance of the interest provision is essentially as a deterrent. The actual amount to be collected by way of interest on outstanding debts is estimated to be of the order of $100 000 a year.

In conclusion, I would emphasise that the changes contained in this Bill are an integral part of an overall package of measures addressing the question of student assistance fraud. This package also includes front-end controls and other administrative measures. An important effect of the package will be an increased awareness of the Commonwealth's determination to address the problems of fraud and debt recovery in the area of student assistance.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill and commend the Bill to the Senate.
STATES GRANTS (TAFE ASSISTANCE) BILL 1989

The States Grants (TAFE Assistance) Bill 1989 gives effect to the Government's Budget decisions on Commonwealth assistance for technical and further education, as announced in TAFE 1990 Commonwealth Programs and Priorities which Mr Dawkins released in August 1989.
The purpose of the Bill is to provide the legislative basis for the distribution of Commonwealth funds for technical and further education in the States and Territories for 1990.
The Bill provides $328.896 million for technical and further education for 1990.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill and commend the Bill to the Senate.
OVERSEAS STUDENTS CHARGE AMENDMENT BILL 1989

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Overseas Students Charge Act 1979 to fix the amounts of the charges payable under the Act for the 1990 academic year. The amounts are shown in the Bill. The charges are payable by overseas students enrolled in Australian education institutions under the subsidised program to which the Act relates.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill and commend the Bill to the Senate.
ABORIGINAL EDUCATION (SUPPLEMENTARY ASSISTANCE) BILL 1989

The Aboriginal Education (Supplementary Assistance) Bill 1989 gives effect to the Government's Budget decision to endorse a National Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Education Policy. The Policy is a long-term commitment towards the attainment of equity for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in access to, participation in and outcomes from education.

The National Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Education Policy is a concerted effort to address the educational needs of Aboriginal people, by cooperatively directing the strategies of the Commonwealth, the States and Territories, non-government education authorities and educational institutions, to achieving:
* involvement of Aboriginal people in educational decision making
* equality of access to educational services
* equitable and appropriate educational outcomes

The purpose of the Bill is to enable the Minister for Employment, Education and Training to enter into bilateral agreements with State and Territory governments, higher education institutions, non-government school systems and other institutions over objectives, strategies, resources and joint monitoring arrangements consistent with the National Policy.

The Bill will provide a legislative basis for a consolidated program and funding approach that is supplementary to mainstream Commonwealth education funding through an Aboriginal Education Strategic Initiatives Program.

The Government has allocated a total of $266.0 million as its commitment to the National Policy over the next 3 years. Through standing appropriations, the Bill provides $236.3 million of the above amount for the Aboriginal education over the three year period 1990-92.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

CRIMES LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1989

The primary purpose of this Bill is to review the Commonwealth sentencing legislation and the laws governing federal offenders found unfit to be tried or not guilty on the grounds of mental illness. In addition, the Bill makes minor amendments to the Cash Transaction Reports Act 1988, the National Crime Authority Act 1984 and Part VIIC of the Crimes Act 1914 (spent convictions).

Although the Crimes Act 1914 was amended in 1982 following the Australian Law Reform Commission's Interim Report on Sentencing (ALRC 15) to require that imprisonment be the punishment of last resort, (except for serious federal offences) and make State and Territory alternatives to imprisonment, such as community service orders, available to federal offenders for the first time, this Bill represents the first significant change to Commonwealth sentencing law since the Commonwealth Prisoners Act 1967 was enacted over 20 years ago.

The number of federal offenders in custody has been steadily growing from 244 out of a total prison population of 10,621 on 1 May 1985 to 517 out of 12,429 on 1 July 1989. These offenders serve their sentences in State gaols by virtue of s.120 of the Constitution and are subject to the same prison regime as State or Territory prisoners. This system can only operate effectively because of the significant assistance and cooperation that I and my Department receive from the officers of the State and Territory Corrective Services Departments or Commissions, on a range of matters including the calculation of sentences and the preparation of parole reports and such like. That assistance is greatly appreciated.

Because of the close association of federal and State/Territory prisoners, it has been the policy of successive Commonwealth Governments to maintain intra-State parity of treatment for federal offenders. The current Commonwealth legislation applies State and Territory laws relating to the fixing of non-parole periods to federal sentences. However, the increasing divergence of, and frequent changes, both administrative and statutory, to State and Territory legislation, have resulted in increasing use of administrative measures to ensure that federal offenders are not disadvantaged.
In late 1988, the final Report of the Australian Law Reform Commission on Sentencing (ALRC 44) was tabled in Parliament. It is therefore timely that further and more significant amendments be made.

The reform and review of the sentencing legislation to ensure its fairness, effectiveness and to ensure community confidence in the ability of the criminal justice system to deal with offenders, is an important part of the Government's fight against crime particularly organised crime. The new sentencing proposals are intended to complement the other major legislative initiatives by the Government in this area, including the Proceeds of Crime Act 1987, the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Act 1987, the Extradition Act 1988, the Cash Transaction Reports Act 1988, the 1989 amendments to the Australian Federal Police Act 1979 to enable superannuation to be forfeited where a police officer is convicted of a corruption offence and the Crimes (Superannuation Benefits) Bill 1989.

The Government believes that there is a need for a separate Commonwealth sentencing regime, to ensure that federal offenders are not disadvantaged because of the complex legal problems that may arise in a federal system. This Bill provides a sentencing regime for federal offenders which pursues the aims of certainty and fairness.

The requirement that imprisonment be the punishment of last resort has been strengthened. But, where a court determines that a sentence of imprisonment is the appropriate penalty, that sentence will be certain. The Bill provides that where a federal offender is sentenced to imprisonment, if the court fixes a non-parole period or makes an order for release on recognizance (a form of bond), this is the period that the person will actually serve in custody before parole eligibility arises, or the person becomes eligible to be released on recognizance. Such periods will not be reduced by remissions from the non-parole or pre-release periods.

Great care has been taken to ensure that establishing certainty in sentencing does not result in harsher or longer prison terms. In those States where remissions reduce State non-parole periods, the Bill specifically provides that a federal offender is to have his or her non-parole adjusted to take into account that it will not be reduced by remissions. The Bill requires that the court explain to the person that the sentence of imprisonment is made up of a period to be served in custody, and a period in the community, subject to conditions either on parole or on recognizance.

As federal offenders are persons who have been convicted of offences against Commonwealth law, for example, the importation of narcotic drugs, money laundering and fraud on the Commonwealth, they will include principals in large scale operations as well as persons who have played minor roles in such offences or persons who have committed relatively minor offences. Federal sentencing legislation therefore needs to provide a range of sanctions to enable the sentencing court to choose the sentence that is appropriate and proportionate to the offence. Although this Bill deals mainly with federal offenders who are sentenced to imprisonment it also ensures that a greater range of alternatives to imprisonment is available to persons convicted of federal offences.

In addition to these important matters, this Bill also provides an innovative and humanitarian regime to deal with the difficult and frequently overlooked problem of mentally ill and intellectually disabled persons who come into contact with the criminal justice system. The existing legislation only provides limited options to deal with a person who has been charged with an indictable federal offence where there is a finding of unfitness to be tried or not guilty on the grounds of mental illness. One of the most serious criticisms of the existing law is that a person may be kept in custody indefinitely, without any statutory requirement that his/her case be reviewed. Moreover, a person found unfit to be tried is kept in custody indefinitely without even a prima facie case being established that he/she committed the alleged offence.

The Bill provides a new regime for dealing with persons who are found unfit to plead, or unfit to be tried or not guilty on the grounds of mental illness. Sentencing courts are also being given additional options for persons who are mentally ill or intellectually disabled. The Bill gives magistrates courts greatly increased options when dealing with cases summarily. Hospital orders will be available in lieu of imprisonment, where mental illness has contributed to the commission of serious offences. Special bonds will also be available-psychiatric probation orders (for mentally ill offenders) and program probation orders for intellectually disabled offenders. The new sentencing options of hospital orders and bonds give effect to the Australian Law Reform Commission's recommendations.
Contents of Bill
A detailed explanation of the contents of the Bill is contained in the Explanatory Memorandum. Accordingly, Mr President, I wish only to refer to the more important features of the Bill:
- The Bill repeals the Commonwealth Prisoners Act 1967 and amends the Crimes Act 1914 to consolidate all the general sentencing legislation in that Act.

- Remissions that currently reduce the non-parole periods of federal sentences in some States will not apply to sentences imposed after commencement (except remissions granted for prison warders's strikes). In those States where remissions off the non-parole period apply, the courts are specifically instructed to take account of the fact that they will not apply to federal offenders and to adjust the non-parole period accordingly.

- Remissions that reduce the total (head) sentence will continue to apply, if available under State law. In those States where remissions on the head sentence are not available (only NSW at present), the courts are specifically required to take this into account, so that federal offenders are not serving longer sentences because of the abolition of remission for State prisoners.

- Federal offenders sentenced to imprisonment prior to the commencement of the Bill, will continue to have their non-parole periods reduced by remissions available under State or Territory legislation.

- The new legislation provides for a federal scheme for setting non-parole periods (instead of relying on State/Territory law). A non-parole period may only be set where the sentence is greater than 3 years.

- Where the sentence is 3 years or less, and the court considers that the person should be released from prison subject to the conditions then, at the time of sentencing, the court may make an order for the person's release on recognizance (a bond subject to court imposed conditions relating to good behaviour and supervision, etc).

- Consistent with the Government's view that there should be certainty in sentencing, the Bill provides that a court sentencing a federal offender to a life sentence, may fix a non-parole period. A federal offender serving a life sentence with no non-parole period at the time this legislation comes into force, may apply to a court to have a non-parole period fixed. It is not mandatory that a court fix a non-parole period for a life sentence.

- Where the sentence is greater than 3 years but less than 10 years and a non-parole period is specified, release on parole is to be automatic on completion of the imprisonment period with the Attorney-General setting conditions, where appropriate.

- If the sentence is greater than 10 years (including a life sentence where a non-parole period is set), there is a presumption in favour of release on parole upon completion of the non-parole period. However, in these cases the Attorney-General has a discretion to defer release on parole. Where release on parole is deferred the Attorney-General must provide the prisoner with reasons for the deferral.
- The Bill retains the ``release on licence'' mechanism to permit early release where a prisoner establishes exceptional circumstances.
- The releasing authority for parolees and licencees will be the Attorney-General (instead of the Governor-General).
- Procedures for the revocation of parole orders and licences have been revised.

- The Bill provides that State or Territory pre-release schemes may be prescribed, subject to eligibility conditions. These schemes enable select State or Territory prisoners to be released shortly before a non-parole period is served or a sentence has been served. Prisoners are subject to strict conditions and supervision while on these schemes. Any regulations prescribing a scheme will, of course, be subject to s.48 of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901, which permits a regulation to be disallowed by either House of Parliament.
- The Bill provides a new regime where a person, charged on indictment with a federal offence, is found unfit to plead or be tried, or is found not guilty on the grounds of mental illness.

- These changes, for persons found unfit to be tried, include procedures for determining whether the prosecution has established a prima facie case, and for establishing the person's likely fitness to stand trial within 12 months. Where a court finds the person will not become fit to be tried the person may be released on a bond or placed in custody for a period not exceeding the maximum penalty for the offence

- If a jury finds a person not guilty on the grounds of mental illness the court may either release the person with or without conditions or make an order for his/her detention in custody for a period not exceeding the maximum penalty for the offence

- In cases where a person is ordered to be held in custody either because he/she is not fit to be tried or has been found not guilty on the grounds of mental illness, the Bill, provides regular review of the detention and for his/her release by the Attorney-General.
The Bill also contains a number of minor amendments to the Cash Transaction Reports Act 1988, the National Crime Authority Act 1984, and the Crimes Act 1914.

The substantive thrust of the Cash Transaction Reports Act is contained in provisions of the Act that are not yet in force. Members will no doubt appreciate that it has taken time to establish the Cash Transaction Reports Agency, which is pivotal to the operation of the legislation. I am pleased to inform the House that the Agency is now in place and the substantive provisions of the Act are to come into force progressively from 1 January 1990. The staff of the Agency have been involved in extensive liaison and consultation with financial institutions, other cash dealers affected by the Act and law enforcement agencies. As a result of this process it became clear that the Act required fine tuning. The amendments contained in this Bill will greatly enhance the implementation process and the effectiveness of the legislation. Certain amendments, such as that removing the requirement for an identification reference to be a statutory declaration, and the amendments to the account verification provisions, have been made following representations from financial institutions.

The present requirements of the CTR Act in relation to account verification are contained in sections 18 to 21 of the CTR Act. Briefly, these sections require that a signatory shall produce a verification statement including an identification reference from an acceptable referee. The amendments will supplement this procedure by enabling a further, alternative procedure to be used, in place of the identification reference, to verify the identity of the signatory to an account with certain cash dealers. The structure of the amendments to implement this change is as follows:

- Firstly, provision is made for the designation of certain cash dealers as ``identifying cash dealers''. Cash dealers will be able to apply to the Director of the Cash Transaction Reports Agency for approval as an identifying cash dealer upon giving an undertaking to comply with stringent verification procedures;

- Secondly, where a person wishes to become a signatory to an account with an identifying cash dealer a verification statement in relation to an account need not be accompanied by an identification reference under section 21. Where no identification reference is produced the cash dealer must verify the identity of the signatory by using the new prescribed identification method under subsection 20 (8);

- Thirdly, the proposed alternative system of account verification, which will require the cash dealer to conduct certain inquiries to verify the signatory's identity, will be detailed in regulations to be made under subsection 20 (8). Those regulations will be prepared in consultation with cash dealers and law enforcement agencies, as well as the Cash Transaction Reports Agency. Also, the Attorney-General has undertaken to provide the Shadow Attorney-General with a draft of the regulations under subsection 20 (8) before they are made.

It is envisaged that the regulations will prescribe twelve or so separate checks to be undertaken by the cash dealer. It is anticipated that the checks will include, for example, the examination of a primary identification document, an electoral roll search and an employer check. These checks will be directed at verifying the name, address and date of birth of the signatory. The identifying cash dealer will be required to carry out a certain minimum number of checks.

Of course it may occur that anomalies will be detected by this verification process. If the anomaly is such as to give the cash dealer reasonable grounds to suspect that information held by the cash dealer concerning the transaction may be relevant to the investigation of tax evasion, or one of the other matters mentioned at paragraph 16 (1) (b) of the CTR Act, eg opening or operating an account in a false name, then the cash dealer will be obliged to report the anomaly as a suspect transaction under section 16.

The verification may, on balance, verify the identity of the signatory whilst also giving rise to the sort of suspicion referred to in section 16. For example, the process may well verify that the signatory is in fact who he or she claims to be but the circumstances as a whole may also indicate that the person may be evading taxation or engaging in other unlawful activity. In such a case the account would be unblocked but a suspect transaction report under section 16 would also be lodged with the Cash Transaction Reports Agency.

The major difference between the existing requirement that a signatory produce an identification reference, and the proposed alternative system, is that the existing requirement places the responsibility for the verification of identity upon the signatory whereas the new system will place that responsibility upon the cash dealer. This will introduce a beneficial degree of flexibility into the critical process of account verification, particularly for those cash dealers who do not have an extensive branch network throughout Australia to facilitate access by customers.

In conclusion I would say that the amendments to the CTR Act meet the concerns of many cash dealers about the possible unintended market effects of the existing requirements by offering flexibility both to cash dealers and to the signatories of accounts, whilst at the same time maintaining or enhancing the integrity of the verification process from the law enforcement perspective.
The balance of the amendments to the Act, and those to the other Acts, are minor and self-explanatory.
Mr President, those are the major features of the Crimes Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989.
Financial Impact Statement

There is not expected to be any significant increase in costs or expenditure from the measures proposed in this Bill. In fact, savings in administration costs are anticipated from the abolition of remissions on non-parole periods and the introduction of automatic parole.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
UNIVERSITY OF CANBERRA BILL 1989
The purpose of the University of Canberra Bill is to establish a University of Canberra under the sponsorship of Monash University to replace the Canberra College of Advanced Education.

Following the release of the White Paper in July 1988 which provided the blue print for wide-ranging reforms in higher education, a Steering Committee chaired by the former Chairman of the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission, Mr Hudson, was established to advise on the amalgamation of the three Canberra higher education institutions. Acting on the recommendations of the Steering Committee, the Government introduced the Australian National University Bill 1988 into Parliament in November 1988. Subsequently, the Government agreed to a request from the incoming ACT government to defer consideration of the Bill to enable the new Assembly to provide advice on the structure of higher education in the Territory. A select committee of the ACT Assembly reported in July 1989 recommending that the amalgamation of the three institutions not proceed at this stage but that a University of Canberra be established to replace the Canberra College of Advanced Education.

The University will be established under the sponsorship of Monash University in accordance with an agreement between the two institutions. The Report of the Task Force on Amalgamations in Higher Education chaired by the Chairman of the Higher Education Council, Dr Ramsey, released in April 1989 proposed that the sponsorship of former institutions in the advanced education sector by existing universities is an appropriate model for the development of these institutions as full members of the Unified National System. Institutions in other States have adopted this model. The Government recognises that there is no single model that is applicable for achieving its objectives of a stronger and more viable higher education system. The establishment of the University of Canberra represents a positive step in the development of higher education in the ACT.

The agreement provides for the participation of Monash University in a wide range of activities undertaken by the new University. The sponsoring institution will be represented on the Council and the Academic Board as well as on various committees of the University. Development of graduate programs and appointment of professorial and equivalent staff will be subject to approval by Monash University during the sponsorship period. The two institutions will promote academic articulation across a range of activities, including student and staff exchanges, integrated professional awards, joint doctoral supervision and joint research projects. Particular consideration will be given to the needs of the ACT community. The agreement will operate for an initial period of three years. It is envisaged that the sponsorship arrangements will be subject to external review at the end of this period. The funding for the University of Canberra will be assessed on the same basis as all higher education institutions. The Government will provide funding of $300 000 to Monash University over the next three years to contribute towards the costs incurred in the sponsorship arrangement.
I present the Explanatory Memorandum and commend the Bill to the Senate.
TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 4) 1989
Mr President, this Bill amends the taxation laws in a number of respects.

It will significantly broaden the income tax concession for research and development project expenditure incurred after 20 November 1987, and extend its availability for a further four years with deductions being allowed at the 150 per cent rate to 30 June 1993 and at 125 per cent until 30 June 1995.
The Bill will also modify the imputation provisions as they relate to 1988-89 assessments received by companies after 18 January 1989 and before 1 July 1989.
Also included in the Bill is an exemption from income tax for the pay and allowances of Australian Defence Force personnel while on duty in Namibia.

The capital gains provisions will be amended to enable a taxpayer to elect that the grant of an eligible long term lease or sublease of land will be treated as a disposal of the underlying freehold or leasehold interest in the land.
An income tax deduction is being provided for expenses incurred in contesting an election for membership of the Legislative Assembly for the Australian Capital Territory.
The Bill will terminate, with effect from 1 July 1991, the deduction for certain subscription monies paid in respect of initial shares in licensed Management and Investment Companies.
Some modifications are being made to the substantiation rules that apply where an employee receives transport allowances under an industrial award.
Minor amendments to the employer provisions of the tax file number arrangements are also proposed.
The Bill will also amend the sales tax law to exempt shipping containers of a kind used in containerised cargo transportation systems.

The prosecution provisions of the taxation laws will be amended to permit the Commissioner of Taxation to apply to a court of summary jurisdiction to have a conviction or order set aside and the matter reheard to correct situations of hardship affecting taxpayers.
Finally, the Bill makes some minor technical amendments to the tax laws.
I turn now to a more detailed discussion of these measures.
Research and Development Activities

As an integral part of the strategy contained in the Government's Science Statement that was tabled in the Parliament on 8 May 1989, the company tax concession for industry investment in research and development activities is to be extended by this Bill for a further period of four years. Already in place until 1991, the 150 per cent deduction scheme will be extended to 30 June 1993, and a 125 per cent scheme will operate until 30 June 1995. The cost of the extension is estimated at $640 million over the years concerned.

Consistent with this extension, the present deduction for expenditure on scientific research will now terminate in 1995, instead of 1991. The Bill will also give effect to a number of measures which will in the interim significantly broaden the scope of the concession. These measures, which flow from a technical review of the concession, were announced on 20 November 1987 and will generally apply after that date.

A company that receives a government grant or recoupment in respect of expenditure on a research and development project will no longer suffer a total loss of the deduction entitlements. Instead, a formula is being introduced to reduce the deduction otherwise allowable by reference to the grant or recoupment.

A further widening of the concession will allow a company to share with others plant and equipment used exclusively for research and development activities without putting the deduction in jeopardy which is the position under the present law.

Instead, where consideration such as a lease payment, is received for the use of the plant, the owner's entitlement to the accelerated write-off allowances will be reduced by one-half of the consideration.

Other broadening measures will extend access to the research and development concession to partnerships of eligible companies and, from 1 July 1988, to public trading trusts that are taxed as companies.

The Bill will also authorise the write off of expenditure on buildings used for research and development activities on a similar basis to expenditure on buildings used for specified income-producing purposes-typically at the rate of 2 1/2 per cent per annum.

It will also amend the Industry Research and Development Act 1986 to broaden certification powers of the Industry Research and Development Board so that it can issue certificates about the activities of all taxpayers affected by the wider concessions being made available.

In the course of finalising these measures, the Government has decided not to proceed at this stage with changes announced on 20 November 1987 in the areas of capital gains and intra group research and development activities, but proposes to keep those matters under review.
Imputation

On 18 January 1989 the Government announced that the law would be amended to provide that franking credits arising from the service of an assessment during the income year to which the assessment relates would be calculated on the basis of the company rate of tax rate for the financial year during which it was received.

The Bill provides that a company receiving an early 1988-89 assessment (that is, an assessment received before 1 July 1989) will be required to calculate the franking credits it receives from that assessment at the 49 per cent tax rate.
It will apply to 1988-89 assessments that are received after 18 January 1989 (when the measure was announced) and before 1 July 1989 and will result in a revenue gain of $1.3 million in 1989-90.
Exemption of pay and allowances of members of Defence Force Personnel serving in Namibia

As announced by the Prime Minister on 6 March 1989, the Bill will exempt from income tax the pay and allowances earned by Defence Force personnel while allotted for duty in Namibia as part of the United Nations Transitional Assistance Group.
The exemption is to apply from 18 February 1989 when the first member of the Defence Force Group left Australia and is estimated to cost $2.75 million in a full year.
Long term leases of land

In terms of a proposal announced on 16 November 1988, a new right of election will be made available for capital gains purposes to a taxpayer who grants a very long term lease or sublease of land after 16 November 1988.
The amendment will enable a taxpayer to elect to have the grant of the new lease or sublease treated as a disposal of the underlying freehold or leasehold interest in land.
The election will only be available where a lease or sublease of land is granted for more than 50 years.

The effect of the election for a taxpayer who acquired the freehold or leasehold interest in the land before 20 September 1985 will generally mean that the grant of the long term lease or sublease will not result in a capital gain or a capital loss for tax purposes.

Where the lessor or sublessor was entitled to any deductions in respect of building depreciation allowances for buildings on the land concerned, the entitlement to those deductions during the life of the new lease will be transferred by the election to the lessee or sublessee.
Because of the nature of this measure it is not possible to make a reliable estimate of its cost to the revenue.
Election Expenses
An income tax deduction is to be authorised for expenditure incurred by candidates in an election for membership of the Legislative Assembly for the Australian Capital Territory.

Deductions are, of course, already available for similar expenditures incurred by candidates for election to the Commonwealth and State Parliaments and the Legislative Assembly of the Northern Territory.
This amendment is to apply for expenditure incurred in the 1988-89 and subsequent income years and is estimated to cost $100,000 in 1989-90.
Licensed Management and Investment Companies

This Bill gives effect to the proposal announced in the 1988 May Economic Statement to terminate, from 1 July 1991, the 100 per cent taxation deduction for certain subscription monies paid in respect of initial shares in licensed Management Investment Companies.
Subscription monies paid after 30 June 1991 for initial shares in licensed Management and Investment Companies will no longer qualify for that deduction.

The Bill will also ensure that certain subscription monies, which attract a 100 per cent deduction if paid before a Management and Investment Company's licence is granted, are not deductible where the licence is granted after 30 June 1991.

These changes will not alter the existing claw-back arrangements that reduce the deduction allowed or allowable where the shares or the licence are not retained for four years from the date of the last payment on the shares.
The revenue saving from this measure is estimated at $2 million in 1991-92 and $20 million per annum thereafter.
Substantiation
This Bill gives effect to the proposal announced by the Treasurer on 28 April 1989 to modify the requirement for employees to substantiate certain claims for income tax deductions.
Under the existing law taxpayers claiming relevant deductions are subject to substantiation requirements if transport allowances paid under an award increase after 29 October 1986.

Taxpayers receiving allowances that have increased after that date will remain outside the substantiation requirements-provided they do not claim a relevant income tax deduction in excess of the amount of the allowance payable under the award as at 29 October 1986.
These modifications to the substantiation requirements will be at an annual revenue cost of less than $100,000.
Tax file numbers

Amendments contained in the Bill will require a copy of an employment declaration to be retained by an employer until the close of the income year after the income year during which the declaration ceases to have effect.

Amendments are also to be made to ensure that tax file numbers are recorded on group certificates and tax check sheets issued for eligible termination payments where the numbers are quoted to the payer on a form provided for that purpose.
These changes will have negligible affect on revenue.
Shipping containers
The sales tax laws are to be amended to exempt certain shipping containers from sales tax.
This measure, which was announced on 25 January 1989, is part of this Government's ongoing commitment to reducing industry costs and removing non-essential industry regulation.

A shipping container will be exempt from tax where it is for repeated use on ships to transport cargo. A shipping container for use for other purposes, for example as a building site shed, will not be exempt from tax unless it has previously gone into use or consumption in Australia.
Rehearing procedures

An amendment to the Taxation Administration Act will enable the Commissioner of Taxation, in appropriate circumstances, to apply to a court of summary jurisdiction to set aside a conviction or order in relation to a prescribed taxation offence.
The right to apply to a court will be restricted to situations where the defendant was not present in court at the original proceedings.

State and Territory court procedures usually apply to enable a court of summary jurisdiction to rehear a case and rectify any anomalies which may have arisen at the original proceedings because the defendant was absent.
However, relevant State legislation does not sufficiently provide procedures to correct all anomalies involving offences under Commonwealth taxation law.

This amendment will remove the need for the Governor-General to be asked in each case to exercise the Royal Prerogative of Mercy to rectify an administrative anomaly or misunderstanding, or to deal with hardship cases, where rehearing provisions under State or Territory law do not provide a satisfactory procedure for rectifying or dealing with these matters.
This measure will not result in any cost to the revenue.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Knowles) adjourned.
Motion (by Senator Bolkus) agreed to:
That these Bills be listed on the Notice Paper as separate Orders of the Day.

(a) to Senators Crowley and Giles for the period 21 to 24 November 1989, inclusive, on account of absence overseas on parliamentary business, and

Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise only one matter today relating to trade which is causing great concern. It is the issue of live sheep exports to Saudi Arabia, about which we learnt very recently that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) had written a letter to the King, as I understand it. When this crisis developed some months ago we suggested that the Prime Minister should intervene and take personal action because of the significance of the loss of trade and our concern that the position could become entrenched, which would be at enormous cost to this industry at a time when Australia could least afford another loss in export revenue. The Government refused to accept our advice at that time and said that it was unnecessary. It was also suggested that nothing further could be done until a particular Minister of the Saudi Government returned from holidays. Then we understood, particularly through the press, that Australia's Ambassador was going to make representations, and the industry had its expectations lifted, again it seems with no positive result. Finally, the Prime Minister decided to write a letter.

SPEECH.PARA: Why did the Government not accept the invitation of the Australia-Saudi Arabia Business Council and the Australia-Arab Chamber of Commerce and Industry to use their good offices to assist in the resolution of this problem early when the offers were made and when it did not seem to be such an intractable position? When the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) received advice from Dr Mahsoud of the Arab League in New York-reference to which he made in answer to a question recently-that the use of these business organisations was a very sensible way in which to progress, why did he not accept that advice and, in turn, ask those two organisations to assist the Australian Government? Why did he at that time believe that the Australian Government could better achieve the goal without the assistance of such organisations?

What is the current state of play in relation to this dispute? I would be interested to know what has been the cost of the dispute to Australia's export revenue. Does the Minister believe that it can be resolved in the reasonably near future? What is the Government now doing to resolve it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I said in my answer to Senator Hill on this matter on 24 October, to which he has already referred, the Government welcomes and continues to welcome the offers by the Australia-Saudi Arabia Business Council and the Australia-Arab Chamber of Commerce and Industry to use their good offices to help in the dispute. My Department has been in touch with both organisations. There has been very substantial and lengthy conversations, as I understand it as recently as a few days ago, on how the matter might be progressed, in the course of which a full explanation was given, as I understand it, of the approach that the Government has been adopting to this matter from the outset.

SPEECH.PARA: As I understand it, that approach as spelt out by our officials on that occasion was fully understood by the Australian representatives of the organisation concerned, in that there is no sense of hostility, as I again understand it, about the way in which this dispute has been carried forward. We have certainly encouraged them to use their own contacts now in parallel with Government efforts to help resolve the dispute. The difficulty now, as it has always been, is that issues of very great delicacy and sensitivity are involved. It is very difficult and undesirable, I think, in the interests of getting a speedy resolution to this matter, to speak about the issues on the public record.

The truth is that it will have to be resolved through very careful diplomacy with the Saudi royal house. That is proceeding as best it can in all the circumstances. We are taking such advice as we can from a variety of sources and are simply trying to move the thing forward. There can be no question that our concerns have been made known to the Saudi authorities. I quickly list the things that have been done. A high level delegation visited Saudi Arabia, Bahrain, Kuwait, Oman and the United Arab Emirates in August. Mr Duffy wrote to the Saudi Arabian Commerce Minister on 23 August noting that Australia regarded the dispute as a major trade policy matter with potentially serious adverse implications for the bilateral trade relationship. I took the opportunity of my presence at the non-aligned movement foreign Ministers meeting in Belgrade to clearly highlight the concerns of the Australian Government in a conversation I had with the Saudi Arabian Deputy Foreign Minister on 4 September. I did, as Senator Hill has indicated, have a helpful conversation with the Arab League Ambassador to the United Nations, Dr Clovis Maksoud, on 4 October, and which I reported back to the Department here. Such follow-up as has been thought appropriate has occurred in response to that, including the recent conversation I have described.

The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin, who along with Mr Duffy has had the primary carriage of this matter, has written twice to the Saudi Arabian Minister for Agriculture and Water, most recently on 7 September, in which he proposed a range of cooperative technical measures to resolve Saudi concerns about the health of our live sheep exports. The response received from the Saudi Minister for Agriculture and Water, Dr Al Shaikh, which was received on 27 October, did appear to indicate some misunderstanding of those proposals as put forward by Mr Kerin. Mr Kerin discussed the matter again with the Saudi Ambassador on 30 October, and that matter has been the subject of further discussion within the Government. Industry representatives and Government officials met on 31 October to discuss further action.

The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has written to King Fahd. The letter was handed to the Saudi Foreign Minister on 12 November. It is obviously not appropriate to disclose the contents of that letter. All I can say is that it is a problem the dimensions of which, although I am not in a position to quantify them at this stage-I am not sure that anyone is-the Government is very concerned about. We are doing everything we possibly can within the constraints of the situation to move it forward. We certainly hope that the sound commercial relations that Australia and Saudi Arabia have enjoyed in the past will continue in the future. Beyond that, I really cannot be more specific in any of the matters that Senator Hill has raised.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) is fully aware of the events that led up to the dispute. They have already been pointed out by Senator Hill. I fully understand the difficulties of dealing with Saudi Arabia-in fact, with any country in the Arabian Gulf area. The matter has now been around for at least three months. It started off in August. A vast amount of damage has been caused to the trade. I can only speak for the western side of the continent about how much damage has been done to the trade. I base that on the amount of stock that has been held on farms. We all know that the holding paddocks of the shipping companies or the buying companies have been cleared. I do not know whether the sheep were eventually all shipped off or whether they were sold back to graziers. There are at least 300,000 to 400,000 export wethers in Western Australia locked up on farms waiting for a market to be found for them.

SPEECH.PARA: What has alleviated the situation to a certain extent has been a very good feed season in Western Australia. In addition, of course, now that we have a downturn in the wool market, the industry is being made a lot more jittery. If the industry is hanging on to the sheep, at least the sheep are growing a fleece. But with the state of the wool market the situation is now getting a bit worrying. I know that the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade has played a great part in the matter, and we are indebted to him, but three months have now passed and, with respect, it seems to me that very little has been achieved. I mean by that that we are no closer to resolving the matter; nor are we any closer to finding out whether any Australian sheep were diseased when they left Australia. There is a need for urgency from the industry in order to bring the matter to a conclusion one way or another. The industry has to plan for next year. The industry has to plan what sort of markets it will have. That is how one sets up one's breeding program, or stocking program, for that matter. If this market is to be lost-and I do not want to see it lost-then so be it. Let it come to a head so that we can start looking for somewhere else to go.

The situation has also been slightly alleviated by a strong inquiry from the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics for frozen beef. The wethers going to the Arabian Gulf are three-year-olds, if I am right, and still reasonably suited as mutton for the rest of the world, whereas a few years ago the Gulf states used to take up to five-year-olds or whatever. So there is a bit of a let go there. But considering that the new season is fast approaching, the industry would certainly like to see some movement in bringing the matter to a head one way or the other.

A few other things worry me. Since the sheep movements have been stopped, the animal liberation organisation, especially in the western part of the continent, has been getting more active. It is a lot easier to stop something which has been stopped for some other reason. These organisations are getting more active in order to make sure that the movements of live sheep do not start again. It is easy to say, as I heard Senator Jean Jenkins say in the last week in Western Australia, that we should be selling more frozen beef. She does not understand that the live sheep go to the Gulf states for religious reasons, because the sheep are killed how and when the states themselves dictate.

Another matter of concern-I suppose it was an accident-is that there has been a fire in a live sheep carrier lying off Adelaide. It will take a while to put the fire out. That is another thing that gives the detractors of the live sheep trade reason to fight hard in order to make sure that the trade does not start again. It is for those reasons that I consider the Government should make renewed efforts to bring this matter, hopefully, to a successful conclusion and thus get the trade going again.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand Senator Panizza's frustration, which I and the Government share. We are genuinely doing everything we can. We are very conscious of the damages concerned and of the point which Senator Panizza makes about the need for forward planning. We are conscious of the absence of effective alternatives for the sale of those sheep at the moment, although if a frozen meat market could be developed, in many ways, from a number of points of view, not least that of the animal liberation movement, it would be a more satisfactory way of conducting that trade. But none of that is leading us to lessen our efforts in any way to resolve the Saudi problem.

—I accept that the Government is doing everything possible, as the Minister has stated. The Minister recognises, by his own example, the importance of travel and the importance sometimes of making an effort to move to the area of a problem and doing something through personal negotiation. Mr Duffy wrote a letter and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) wrote a letter. Might it not have been of some value if one of the Government's Ministers-including Senator Evans, who is about to head off to Europe because, as he said to us in Question Time, it is important to go there to learn at first hand what is happening in Eastern Europe-had gone to Saudi Arabia and tried to resolve the issue personally?
—Why doesn't he go there on his way to Europe?

—As Senator Panizza says, he could even go there on his way to Europe, so it would not be necessary for him to make a one-off trip. We suggested some time ago that a Minister should have intervened personally to try to resolve the problem before it got too bad. That did not occur and it still has not occurred. I still do not understand why it has taken so long for the Minister to embrace the invitation of the private business organisations, which we are both led to understand are so highly regarded in Saudi Arabia and which we have both been told could have played a unique and useful role in helping to resolve the matter early on. My two questions are: Why will a Minister not visit Saudi Arabia and try to sort out the problem, and why were the business organisations' invitations not accepted much earlier in the hope that the problem could have been resolved?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am touched by Senator Hill's confidence in the diplomatic capacity of my fellow Ministers and me to resolve complex problems of this kind. All I can say in that respect is that I will raise the matter with my colleagues-the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and Ministers Kerin and Duffy, who have had the direct carriage of this-to see whether they want to take that course at this stage. But here, as elsewhere, it is a matter for judgment about how best to advance the process of negotiation. The best advice that we had from inside the Saudi system was to handle it in the way that it has been handled to date. That has not produced results, but it is a somewhat complex and difficult system for governments such as ours to deal with on sensitive matters of this kind. We have to take such advice as we can, weigh it, juggle it and balance it and then see what we can do.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not sure of the precise sequence of events so far as the response to the overtures of the chambers of commerce are concerned. All I can repeat is that, as I understand it, the tactics for utilising that parallel track were discussed fully with the senior executive members of the Australian arm of this organisation just a few days ago. I am told that there was no disagreement as to either the way in which the matter had been handled or the way it should be handled in future to move it forward. I do not have full knowledge of those exchanges. It may be that that answer will need to be supplemented. However, for the moment I cannot add anything to what I have said previously.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to touch on some matters which I suspect Senator Hill will mention this afternoon when he moves his motion in respect of events taking place in Eastern Europe. I am sorry that the Australian Democrats and Senator Vallentine have not come in here during this debate to make their useful contributions. In my view, one of the fundamental reasons that we are seeing changes now in Eastern Europe is a result of the attitude-perhaps I am pedantically stating the obvious-of the Soviet Union, Gorbachev's fundamental approach to perestroika and glasnost and the fact that they disavowed the Brezhnev doctrine.

SPEECH.PARA: This has come about because of the incapacity of the Soviet Union, in many respects, to deal with the problems because of its own domestic economic problems. Gorbachev has acknowledged that the problem for the Soviet Union is that it is a first world defence power but a Third World economy and one could not continue to support the other. When Reagan and Weinberger dramatically increased the level of United States defence expenditure they sent fear and shivers through the spine of the Soviet Union. Their enormous financial commitment to the strategic defence initiative (SDI) made it very apparent to the Soviet Union that it could not afford to keep pace with the United States and its Western allies in terms of modernising its defence capacity and expanding the technology of that capacity.

As a result, perhaps the first fundamental step that we saw was the intermediate-range nuclear force (INF) agreement. It might be argued that the INF agreement was the result of the West's deployment of its missiles. I suspect that that was only the beginning of the Soviet's recognition that they could not continue to maintain the level of funding necessary to be competitive. We saw some significant changes in attitude to foreign policy in the Soviet Union, including its withdrawal from Kampuchea and Mongolia, the release of troops from the Sino-Soviet border and the INF agreement. The Soviet Union was haemorrhaging economically because of its attempts to maintain the enormous defence budget which it was required to undertake.

Anybody who has been to the Soviet Union or has bothered to look superficially at its economy understands the major problems that it has. Having to move so much of its top technology from civil activities and the economy into its defence forces and defence research has very much depleted its capacity in terms of its being a strong economic force. I give the simple example of Uzbekistan, an area in the south of the Soviet Union, which produces fresh fruit and vegetables, but when one travels a comparatively short distance to Moscow or Leningrad one finds vast queues in the streets. People queue up simply to buy rotten vegetables and fruit. They are rotten because they do not have a fundamental and simple capacity to transport goods and services. In addition, there are all the inevitable problems that go with having 158 million civil servants trying to run the economy.

Much of what we are seeing now has come about because of the levels of expenditure outlaid by the United States and its allies which ultimately, notwithstanding what the Democrats, Senator Vallentine and others say, have the capacity to provide stability, peace and the prospect of long term peace to the world and which in many other respects have led to a fundamental change in the political system in Eastern Europe. That will have enormous implications not only for those economies but also for the Soviet Union because of the intrinsic and compulsory commercial relationship between those countries and because of the contrasting difference between the composition of the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation and the Warsaw Pact countries.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask a question relating to the situation on the Iran-Iraq border. Can the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) give us in a succinct form an assessment of the current situation? Recent newspaper reports have suggested that the situation is tense and that problems have arisen. Can the Minister bring the chamber up to date on the matter? I am particularly concerned because we have a peacekeeping force in the region? If the Minister could brief us, I would be grateful.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —The most recent conversations I have had on the subject are a few weeks old now. My understanding was that the tortuous process of negotiation was still proceeding under United Nations auspices, that it was somewhat stalemated and had been for a number of months, but that there was no great fear abroad that the situation would escalate back into violence. It may be that there are some other straws in the wind which suggest cause for greater pessimism than that. I had better take that question on notice, in effect, and respond to it perhaps after Question Time tomorrow to give Senator Newman a more considered answer on the basis of an updated briefing.

—I thank the Minister. I draw his attention also to the fact that there have been reports of artillery barrages. Additionally, what is the situation about agreements on return of prisoners and such matters?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will take that on board and follow it up.

SPEECH.PARA: Proposed expenditure agreed to.
Department of Transport and Communications
Proposed expenditure, $992,241,000

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to pursue the vexed question of the Bureau of Transport and Communications Economics report on Telecom Australia's community service obligations. As I understand it, it is now some nine weeks or more since the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis) undertook to release the report publicly `in the near future'. I would be grateful for advice as to whether `in the near future' contemplates a pre-election release and, in particular, a 1989 release of that document.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am able to say only that the report is with the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis) at the moment. It is a matter for his judgment as to when it is released.

—I understand that and I appreciate the reasons for stonewalling, but it would seem to me-and, I am sure, others-that if the Government is not proposing to release the report it should at least have the decency to say so. A commitment was given to release it in the near future. If words mean anything, I would have thought that the near future was almost the immediate past. I therefore invite the Minister for Transport and Communications, in the interests of maintaining any shred of credibility in this area, to say what is meant by that and, in particular, whether he proposes to release the report this year. We are looking at another five weeks or so. If we add that to the nine weeks that have already elapsed, we are talking about three months or more. That cannot be `in the near future'.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am told that the matter was on the agenda of Cabinet or one of the subcommittees of Cabinet this week, which suggests that the matter is inching forward towards a Government determination and also suggests that the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis) expects to put something on the record by the end of this year. If the Minister's impression is any different from that, I will undertake to advise Senator Alston accordingly, but on the basis of that information it seems that something is reasonably imminent.

—I am indebted to the Minister for that morsel. I gleaned from an article in the Australian Financial Review that the matter might be on the agenda for the structural adjustment committee meeting on Thursday but I have had subsequent information that it probably will not be on the agenda because the Minister for Transport and Communications returns to Australia only today. Is it right that the latest information of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade is that the matter will be on Thursday's agenda?

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not in the business of giving Senator Alston a blow by blow account of the day by day variations in Cabinet and Cabinet committee agendas. He asked what the expectation was in relation to the release of the report-this month, next month or next year. Within the parameters of his question, I think I have given him a quite remarkable degree of precision in the answer. Beyond that I am neither able nor willing to go.

—I do not want it to be taken that I am satisfied with that but I want to turn to another matter, which concerns Telecom Australia (International) Pty Ltd (TA(I)). One of the questions concerned the total number of contracts that TA(I) has sought. The answer given in the additional information is that information is not available. Does that mean that Telecom has no idea of how many contracts it has applied for or does it simply mean that it is unwilling to provide that information? If it is the latter, which I suspect it is, could we have the courtesy of an explanation as to why that should be?

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will have to take that on notice, I am afraid, and give the honourable senator an answer tomorrow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am indebted to the Minister for that. At the same time, perhaps the Minister could also advise me why we are continually reminded of the $86m figure for the Saudi Arabian contract, which is over a three-year period, but we are not given a period for the Pakistan $30m contract and we have no details at all other than this statement:

SPEECH.PARA: Some of the other countries in which the Company has been successful include . . .

I would have thought it was possible to speak definitely about those countries in which the company has negotiated contracts and what the value of those contracts is. From memory, the recent annual report indicates a loss in the order of $2 1/2m, which certainly suggests that there are either high start-up costs or these contracts are pretty insignificant. Can the Minister please provide a definitive list of the total number and detail of contracts and their actual value?

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will endeavour to do just that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to cellular mobile telephone services (CMTS), one of the questions asked was in relation to performance indicators and quality of service indicators. In particular, the experience of Pactel Cellular Inc, which is a California-based company, was cited as having a 99 per cent probability of the first call attempt being successful. That seems to me to be a fairly self-evident assertion, but the answer says that it is not understood what Pactel is claiming in its design standard of 99 per cent probability of a first call attempt being successful and that this is not related to the 90-90 rule, which is Telecom's rule. Part of the answer says:

SPEECH.PARA: A number of quality of service indicators are employed for CMTS.

The main ones are coverage of 90 per cent of area for 90 per cent of the time. I would have thought that had a particular meaning, but later in the answer it is stated in relation to the Pactel claim:
. . . is not related to the 90/90 rule which is a transmission guideline rather than a probability of call success.

Can the Minister explain why 90 per cent of area for 90 per cent of the time does not give a probability of the likelihood of a successful call being made? If not, what is meant by the cute expression `transmission guideline'?

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator Alston would appreciate that he is getting into a degree of detail to which it is simply impossible to respond within the Senate chamber in the context of the way in which we deal with these things. I will just have to take that on notice, too. If he has any more of these, maybe he could give me a list of them and they can be dealt with on that basis.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can do that, but I want to make it clear, certainly in the presence of those who are advising the Minister, that these documents are provided for debate in the chamber in the committee stage and we would normally be entitled to conduct the debate and have further questioning on the basis of information which makes some sense. To have these sorts of oblique references and cryptic descriptions of what would otherwise appear to be self-evident parameters seems to me to be particularly unhelpful.

SPEECH.PARA: I move to another section in relation to a question asked by Senator Panizza on the cost of establishing a UHF communications network from Port Hedland with a line running straight east to the Northern Territory border. The answer states that this could not be achieved without extraordinary cost and it goes on to point out that it would be necessary to provide a series of repeater stations, et cetera. I suppose that we all have a general idea of what might be meant by `extraordinary cost', but again I would have thought it would have been possible to be a little more precise than that and to give a quantitative rather than a qualitative assessment. I simply ask, on notice, that the Minister make a further endeavour to come up with a meaningful, quantitative figure.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will pass on that request. There is a point at which something is so obviously beyond the range of that which is affordable that it is self-evident to the merest passing spectator, and the kind of effort involved in pulling out a detailed quantitative analysis is simply not justified, even in the interests of freedom of information, public debate and everything else. That is a judgment that has to be made periodically when Ministers are responding to questions on notice. I would ask Senator Alston, if he wants to keep Telecom a lean and taut organisation and not misusing its resources in going on goose chases of one kind or another, whether he would be prepared to waive that particular request rather than require Telecom to debate resources to prove something which will not make a halfpennyworth of difference to any policy outcome.

—I appreciate the superficial and frivolous nature of the response, but I am sure that Senator Evans himself would have some figure in mind if he were describing something as extraordinary. I am not suggesting that a division of Telecom officers be sent off for a month to push some buttons on their machines. I am simply asking what figure, in ballpark terms, they had in mind when the term `extraordinary' was used. Does it mean more than $10m? Does it mean roughly more than $100m? We should be given some general idea, and that does not involve any more than going back to the figure that presumably generated the assessment of `extraordinary'.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —Now that Senator Alston has gracefully clarified his position and made it clear that he seeks no more than a ballpark figure, I am sure that Telecom will be happy to oblige.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should like to raise a point regarding Telecom, although not Telecom's record profits. It seems that Telecom has a good deal of switching gear that is slightly out of date. I remember receiving a circular letter the other day advising that, firstly, it cannot get parts for this switching gear and, secondly, it is not able to train the younger technicians in repairing this switching gear that has been around for a day or two. I am talking about equipment that has been around for only 10 or 15 years at the very most. I believe that this is beyond all reason.

SPEECH.PARA: Telecom supplies very sophisticated gear and, for many applications, I believe it is too sophisticated-not in its use but because it is very expensive. For instance, a small business may want a main telephone and two extensions. It is impossible these days to get such simple switching gear. The business would have to have the three telephones in parallel, which is totally unsatisfactory, or it would have to use as a minimum the Commander system and would be up for thousands of dollars. If it wanted five lines, the cost would be astronomical. Of course, equipment can be leased from Telecom but it is capitalised at about 33 per cent a year, so the total cost would be written off in three years.

Can the Minister comment on whether there is good, workable, cheaper gear available that could be used to phase out these switchboards? Although they have been around for 10 or 12 years, they are quite functional, but obviously Telecom does not want to operate them any more. Could Telecom supply cheaper equipment rather than the sophisticated equipment?

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will ensure that Senator Panizza's remarks are communicated to Telecom management. Senator Panizza will realise that the matters he is talking about are essentially matters for the commercial and managerial judgment of Telecom. For better or worse, it is running as a government business enterprise entirely within its own parameters and discretions in that kind of judgment. Really, there is nothing the Government can offer by way of useful comment except, as I said, to pass on the honourable senator's remarks and hope that they are heard.

—I return to the community service obligations (CSOs). A question asked what figure Telecom put on the cost of its CSOs and the answer was that Telecom had provided figures to the Minister as part of the overall study and that the timing of any announcement was a matter for the Minister. That relates to the outcome of the Bureau's investigations and presumably any government response. I ask the Minister why it is that the Telecom input figure should be so sensitive? I can understand the delay, accompanied by Government anguish, over the consequences of the level of the figure that the Government might accept from the Bureau, but I do not understand the sensitivity about the mere Telecom input figure.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a commercially sensitive issue because it has implications for the pricing of a whole variety of services, as Senator Alston would be well aware. I guess it is a matter for the judgment of Telecom in the first instance, and otherwise the Minister himself, as to what is put on the public record in terms of the Telecom input, as Senator Alston described it.
