I shall draw Senator Alston's remarks to the attention of the Minister and seek a response from him on that subject, but I envisage that it is an issue best addressed in the context of his response to that report.

—I am indebted to the Minister for taking it on board to that extent. I remind the Minister that a little less than two years ago Telecom put out a press release claiming that the cost of its CSOs-cross-subsidies as they were called then-was of the order of $1 billion. In the context of the Government's May 1988 statement, the Telecom figure was said publicly to be $670m. Why is it now regarded as sensitive and confidential to the point where even that starting figure cannot be disclosed publicly? Is it that Telecom is reluctant to put it on the record or is the Government simply putting its foot on Telecom?

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —It may not be sensitive in the current judgment of the Minister and Telecom. I will raise it with the Minister and find out.

—The second question related to the estimated cost of Telecom's involvement in the Bureau study. The answer states that the study was a complex exercise and involved a wide range of staff in answering questionnaires and collecting data and that it was not possible to estimate the cost of Telecom's involvement. I would regard that as a priceless response but it seems to me that it is also an extraordinary concession either that Telecom's accounting practices are inadequate or that a strategic policy decision has been made not to enable quantification of the cost of Telecom's involvement. Why on earth is this so and why cannot we be given a figure that would at least show the extent of Telecom's involvement in the Bureau study?

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is another example of the phenomenon to which I referred earlier when sometimes the time, effort and cost involved in pulling out and quantifying, albeit according to well established accounting standards, the inputs from a variety of people in a number of different divisions and areas is simply not justified by the conceivable utility of the information thus described, even to Senator Alston, in order to grind on in chamber debates of this kind. It is a familiar response and one that Senator Alston would have had from Ministers in answer to some of his more extravagant questions on notice; it is also one that I am not disposed to try to second guess in this instance. The honourable senator should not draw any assumptions about the inadequacy of the accounting practices from an unwillingness to embark upon a detailed quantification of inputs for something of this kind.

—I am indebted to the Minister. There is a glimmer of enlightenment there because he said that a deliberate decision not to apply Telecom's accounting processes to enable such a figure to be derived was taken. I would like him to confirm that that is the case because from what he said a moment ago I understand that there is no deficiency in the accounting process. The figure could have been generated, but a decision was taken not to make it available. I ask the Minister whether that is so.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Alston is erecting his usual large edifice on a very small foundation. If the honourable senator replays the record, he will see that all I said was that it is not to be assumed from a response of this kind that there is any inadequacy in the accounting practices involved. A more likely assumption, one that I am not in a position to confirm or otherwise, is that the problem is not with the accounting methodology, but is simply the sheer expenditure of resources that are involved in quantifying inputs of this kind.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I turn to the matter of pay television. My question, which can be found on page 28 of the 3 October Hansard record of Estimates Committee B, reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Without the introduction of a fibre optic based pay television service by what year does Telecom expect to have laid optic fibre to the hubs in the streets in metropolitan areas?
The answer does not mention a date, except in the context that if pay television is introduced, 60 per cent of homes could be connected by 1994.

I would have thought that even the Minister could have recognised that as a transparent delinquency. It is quite clear that Telecom is evading the answer. Will the Minister kindly address Telecom's attention to the issue and come clean as to what the real program is. We know that the agenda involves Telecom's ambit claim for pay television provided by its optical fibre network, but the question concerned the consequences if that path is not pursued.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —The question, as I understand it, is premised on a hypothesis about pay television being introduced and what would be the situation by year X in that context. It is a hypothetical question and not one that it is possible to answer, as I understand it, and it is not reasonable to seek an answer for it.
—You don't understand it.
—I heard only half of it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I fully understand the Minister's predicament, I will repeat the question. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Without the introduction of a fibre optic based pay television service by what year does Telecom expect to have laid optic fibre to the hubs in the streets in metropolitan areas?

The only answer which provided a date did so in the context of saying that, if we have pay television, 60 per cent of homes could be covered by 1994. That is a straight evasion of the question which asked about what would happen without pay television. That is the question that I want answered.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a plausible reading of the response, not the only possible reading of it. I will seek further and better particulars, as Senator Alston would describe it, in another incarnation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the hearing of Estimates Committee B, some questions were placed on notice on 3 October-I point out that it is now 21 November-which related to the continuing saga of the construction of Darwin Airport. The particular questions sought information that could very properly have been provided well in advance of this date, particularly as in the interim period since 3 October media releases in Darwin have been made by the airport manager of the Federal Airports Corporation in Darwin, Mr Bruno Santalucia, on both 9 October 1989 and 24 October 1989 which related to issues that were asked in the questions that were put on notice on 3 October. The annual report of the Federal Airports Corporation for 1988-89 was subsequently tabled in this Parliament and a number of issues were at least alluded to in that report.

SPEECH.PARA: Additionally, as all honourable senators would be well aware, on 30 October 1989 the report of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works was tabled in this chamber. The report, entitled Northside Development of Civil Aviation Facilities, Darwin Airport, Northern Territory, contained a number of conclusions and recommendations and, in particular, drew the Parliament's attention to five very specific recommendations. As an aside, it is interesting to note that the report tabled here on 30 October contained only five recommendations and a total budget proposal for the Darwin Airport of $72m at May 1989 prices, whereas by comparison the seventh report of 1984 of the Public Works Committee at that time had very similar recommendations but included nine specific recommendations and in 1984 dollar terms had an airport estimate at that time of $95m. The Government, as usual, has prevaricated and procrastinated continually in this particular area.

I would like to know very specifically why the questions that were addressed on 3 October have not yet been attended to and answers provided to the Senate, despite continual requests through the Committee secretariat on a daily basis for at least the last fortnight. The questions related to the design and timetables, the funding expenditure and the source of loan funds, the timetable for the letting, the cost implications, the financial status of the FAC and some of the implications arising from the current pilots dispute and the implications of a loss of income to the FAC. I would be very interested in ascertaining from the Minister why the answers have not yet been provided and what information he can give that will address these points.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand it was hoped to have the answers for the Committee this afternoon. The answers to the questions are presently in the Minister's office, I am told. I have just made a very explicit request to the Minister's office to see what can be done to expedite the presentation of that material in the chamber and I am awaiting an answer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —When consideration of this group is concluded, I ask that final consideration be deferred until such time as that information is provided.

SPEECH.PARA: Similarly, I draw attention to the questions that were raised on 3 October with regard to air traffic controller operations at Darwin, and these were specifically at page B193 of the Hansard of 3 October. Questions were asked on my behalf with regard to changes in the operations and size. It was indicated on 3 October that further information would be made available in that regard and I am not yet aware that any of that information with regard to these safety implications and consultations with the Northern Territory Government have in any way been made available to the Committee or for consideration. When will they be provided, or what information can the Minister give with regard to those questions that were asked over seven weeks ago?

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot give the honourable senator a specific answer on those particular questions. It is believed that they may be bundled up with some of the other aviation answers that are presently in the Minister's office awaiting clearance for their being put before the Committee. We will follow that up and give the honourable senator an answer as best we can in due course.

—Similarly, I refer to the Hansard of 3 October with regard to the operations of the Independent Air Fares Committee. A question was asked with regard to any air fare increases that might be caused by the pilots strike, and I sought an assurance that the Government would guarantee that there would be no increases in air fares arising from the present domestic strike. Again it would appear that no further information has been provided on this most important issue and I would ask how that is currently being addressed.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —The particular matter to which Senator Tambling has referred was not, to our knowledge, taken as a question on notice. Under the circumstances, I do so now. It is not a matter of any delinquency; I think it was not understood to be a question or taken as such. An answer will be given to the honourable senator as soon as possible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to raise a couple of questions about the receipt dates of annual reports into Ministers' offices as well, because Senate Estimates committees were in some instances obliged to deal with matters of substance without the benefit of annual reports. For example, I mention the Australian Telecommunications Corporation. I was unable to attend that meeting of the Senate Estimates Committee B of 3 October, but I understand that the annual report of the Australian Telecommunications Corporation was not available to the Estimates Committee on that date, although in fact the Chairman's report to the Minister was dated 13 September 1989. Could I ask the Minister when the report did become available?
—I am sorry, I do not have that information to hand. I will find out and let you know as soon as possible.

—I make the general point that the absence of such a report is grossly unsatisfactory. It is a disgrace that a Senate committee-which is the only surveillance mechanism available to this Parliament for the corporations which have this enormous power and this modicum, this minute amount, of apparent responsibility-does not have such a report. It seems to me that it is the only occasion that we have any chance to really test the matter of the responsibility of corporations which do not appear to share the same obligation to face up to their shareholders, who are the people of Australia represented by us, as do, for example, public companies.

SPEECH.PARA: I tend to look at Senate Estimates committees as something like the annual general meeting of a corporation and it would seem to me that every effort should be made to provide reports. I might say many government organisations have made every effort. Many government organisations did the right thing and provided us with draft reports, even though it was ahead of the maximum time requirement for the presentation of annual reports.

I am interested in looking at the Australian Telecommunications Corporation to see whether there are some matters which presumably could have received some attention in a Senate Estimates committee. For example, it is interesting to note that one of the charges against operating profit was research and development costs of $36.2m. This might be a situation where one could in fact commend Telecom for undertaking considerable expenditure on research and development. I do not know of many other companies, either public or private, with a turnover of $7.7 billion who were spending as much money as that. Perhaps it is a comment on all of Australia that it is noteworthy that $36m, or 0.5 per cent of turnover, has been spent on research and development. Apparently that is a commendable figure when compared to the rest of Australia. Figures like this should be available to Senate Estimates committees to discuss.

I am intrigued to note that, although the bad debts written off total about $70m, the provision for bad debts has been cut by $21m. Is this because Telecom expects to have a far better bad debt situation in the coming year? I do not know. I do know that Telecom has had a fair bit of trouble-I suppose I gave it a fair bit of trouble-concerning its appointment of a new collection agency for its bad debts in New South Wales. I understand that the new agency involved is the subject of some police action. I do not know what the results have been. In the end I must commend Telecom for cooperating as fully as it did with the police in this matter after Telecom was nagged about it in this chamber by me.

There are concerns about Telecom's bad debts. I know that with such a huge turnover the writing off of $70m may not be awfully bad in relative terms, but certainly there are many people who appear to be abusing Telecom's services by changing names, disappearing and so on. I do not know how a group like Telecom can get the figure down even smaller than $70m, but that underlines my query about why on earth the bad debt provision has been cut by $21m. Perhaps the Minister may have some suitable answers, but if we had this information at Senate Estimates we would not have to ask the question now.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —Again we are confronting a request for detailed information about what is essentially a matter for a commercial management decision by Telecom. Telecom is not an organisation which enjoys any contribution from government appropriations through the Budget. I suppose it is a fair question to address to Telecom and I will pass it on and seek a response, but Senator Baume will appreciate that it is not a response that he can expect reasonably to get in the context of this sort of debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister and acknowledge that, but perhaps Telecom should be reminded that all its shares are owned by the people of Australia, and we provide the people of Australia with their only opportunity of asking questions about their company. It seems to me that this halfway house that the Government is pushing so many business corporations into, having them as separate structures and in fact answerable only to the Government, is the worst of all worlds. The management is not subject to the pressures of the marketplace in the sense that there is a public shareholding who can vote them out or express their views about poor performance or poor service, particularly when they are a monopoly like this. It seems there is an added burden on Telecom to meet this obligation to report fully and openly. That is another reason why I share the concern of one of my colleagues in the House of Representatives and that of Senator Alston, who has been talking about the institutional advertising of Telecom costing large amounts of money. From looking at the report, one would certainly get no view about how much it is spending on advertising.

SPEECH.PARA: In other words, what has happened in this area is that by corporatising structures like Telecom, the amount of information required to be provided is limited. We go cap in hand, as the Minister appeared to indicate, to Telecom asking, `Pretty please, with sugar on top, could we have an answer?'. We face the prospect of getting a response that it is commercial in confidence and that basically Telecom, in the great bulk of its operations, is acting as a state monopoly. This underlies the need to get rid of this uncomfortable halfway house and to privatise these public corporations, which are at present in the worst of all possible worlds for both the users and the owners. I take the Minister's point that all he can do is ask for a response, and I will keep my fingers crossed and hope that I shall get a sensible answer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —After the hearing of Estimates Committee B I was provided with a copy of the direction by Minister Willis to the Civil Aviation Authority to waive charges payable by IPEC Ltd from 28 August, that is the various charges which the Authority could levy on airlines operating in Australia. During the dispute the Minister directed both the Civil Aviation Authority and, I understand, the Federal Airports Corporation, to waive charges.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to ask the Minister whether this direction which in the case of IPEC is dated 28 September-I do not have any copies of any other such directions by Mr Willis, but I presume that the others are in substantially the same form-and similar directions to the Civil Aviation Authority are the basis on which all subsequent actions by the Authority in relation to charges and the actions by the Government in relation to payment for charges were taken? Is that the substance-the basis-on which further action was taken?

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —All I am able to tell the honourable senator is that a direction is made for each claim that is put in. I am not quite sure whether that is the particular point that the honourable senator is addressing or whether there is another aspect of it that she wishes pursued further.

—To help the Minister, I should say that I understand from the wording of the direction which I have in front of me and to which I referred that all charges which were payable by Ipec from 28 August were to be waived. There is no concluding date. As it appears on the document, it is an open-ended direction. I do not know whether the Minister wishes to have a look at it.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am told that Ipec is not as yet a party to the agreement, so no waivers have in fact been made. As to the open-ended character of that, I am told that an arrangement as between Ipec and the Government will be finalised shortly. In the course of that matter being finalised, the outside parameters within which the arrangement works will be identified and, hopefully, bedded down. That will give the honourable senator a much more precise answer; but it has not yet been settled.

—I thank the Minister, but he has added somewhat to the confusion, because the document that I have here refers to the `agreement annexed hereto', and in fact I have seen a copy of an agreement that includes Ipec. Is the Minister telling me that it was not signed?

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know what agreement the honourable senator has there, but the agreement between the Government and Ipec, which might be in draft form or might be modelled on some other agreement that she has seen, has not yet been signed. My information is that the agreement between Ipec and the Government has itself not been signed; it is still subject to being finalised, which is the reason for the answer I have just given.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister. There appears to be confusion as to whether Ipec is a party to this agreement to which the other airlines and the Government were parties-namely, that the costs would be waived and that recognition would be given to the cost to the airlines of not standing down certain of their employees.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to the other airlines, were the directions given by Minister Willis under subsection 66 (2) of the Act relating to the waiving of charges in similar form to this direction that I have here in front of me and that relates to Ipec? Was that a typical direction signed by Minister Willis, in this case on 28 September?

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer is yes.

—I thank the Minister for that. If those directions by the Minister to the Civil Aviation Authority were put in place, am I also to assume that similar directions were made by the Minister to the Federal Airports Corporation? Did a similar direction also go out to the Federal Airports Corporation?
—That is my understanding, yes.

—We understand that regular cheques have been paid by the Commonwealth under the terms of the agreement that was annexed to those directions. I understand that is all agreed; there is no argument about cheques for periodic payments being drawn by the Commonwealth in relation to this matter.
—Correct.
—Can the Committee please be told: were those payments payable to the airlines or were they payable to the two authorities?
—To the authorities, I am advised.
—Could I now be told on what legal basis they were paid to the authorities?

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the authority in question is a formal direction made under each of the Acts in question. That relates to the waiver of the charges. The two authorities are simply being reimbursed in accordance with proper accounting processes of the Government for the losses thus incurred in the waivers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the sake of simplicity, I will talk about the CAA and assume, unless I am told otherwise, that the FAC is in a comparable position.
—Yes.

—I understand that in June the CAA made a determination which was gazetted and which set out the charges to be levied by the Authority and which included other clauses. I draw the Minister's attention to clause 29, which gives the Authority a power to remit or refund charges, and clause 22, which gives the airlines the entitlement to assign any liability they might have under the charges to another person. Having drawn the Minister's attention to those two clauses, I would also suggest to him that both of those clauses are beyond the power of the Authority to so determine. Under the terms of its Act, it is wide of its powers.

SPEECH.PARA: I am concerned that the authority, having obtained advice from the Attorney-General's Department, only part of which was made available to the Committee, appears to have ignored those two clauses which, as I claim, are beyond the power. If, as I assume from what the Minister has just said, the Commonwealth has paid those cheques to the Authority on the basis of those determinations, am I right in assuming that under clause 22 of the June determination of the CAA-namely, that the airlines may assign any liability to another person-they have assigned their liability for charges to the Commonwealth and the Commonwealth has now paid the dues to the Authority?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —Not only is it not the occasion for a detailed bush lawyer's dialogue on possible legal foundations of these matters, but also my understanding is that the authority to waive the charges in question was ministerial direction, which is provided for under the legislation. The reimbursement of the authorities to compensate them for the amount lost as a result of such waiver is a reimbursement that has been paid by the Government in the ordinary course of public accounting procedures-in this instance, I presume through payment from the Advance to the Minister for Finance, which obviously will have to be the subject of a top-up appropriation at the right time because at the time that the Budget went to bed obviously the expenditure was unforeseen.

SPEECH.PARA: As I understand it, there has been no question of assignment using the formal provisions of the legislation to which Senator Newman refers; rather, it has involved the legal processes as I have described them. However, I repeat that in relation to this matter, I do not think it is very edifying or helpful, quite apart from contravening Standing Orders, to try to give legal opinions on the run. Senator Newman seeks a series of legal opinions about the authority for various things which, presumably, may be the subject of some legal discussion.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister misinterprets the questions. I am asking quite specific factual questions about the basis on which payments were made and amounts assessed. I asked the Minister for a categorical assurance that the airlines did not transfer their liability under those Acts to the Commonwealth.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —My clear understanding and the clear advice I have been given is that they did not transfer the liability employing those statutory mechanisms-this was a different mechanism of the kind I have described.
—Can the Minister advise what payments have been made by the Commonwealth to the CAA and what payments have been made by the Commonwealth to the Federal Airports Corporation?

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —In the case of Australian Airlines Ltd, the figure is $2,294,480, of which $1,422,935 was approved for waiver against FAC charges and $871,545 for waiver against CAA charges. In the case of Ansett Airlines of Australia the overall figure is $4,131,718, of which $1,556,024 was approved for waiver against CAA charges and $2,575,694 for waiver against FAC charges.

—I thank the Minister for that information. I would now like to ask the Minister some further questions about the situation in relation to the civilian charter of Royal Australian Air Force aircraft, which is known in the RAAF as Operation Immune. Following questions put to the Civil Aviation Authority, I was told that it had no legal right to regulate civilian charters of RAAF aircraft carrying civilians. Can the Minister now tell me who is liable for any navigation charges and landing fees for those RAAF aircraft when they are under civilian charter and carrying civilians?

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am informed that Government-owned aircraft, including RAAF aircraft, are not normally charged. Pursuant to that principle, neither Australian Airlines Ltd nor Ansett Airlines of Australia pays landing charges associated with the flights operated by RAAF crews for those two airlines.

—Am I to understand that not only are the airlines having their charges waived in respect of their own or chartered aircraft but also they are not paying fees in relation to their chartered RAAF aircraft? That is a somewhat rhetorical question, but such a situation involves another hidden subsidy. Is there any way of quantifying the amount of navigation charges and landing charges that would be involved if those RAAF aircraft were purely chartered civilian aircraft?
—Yes, there is a way of quantifying that.
—Has it been done, Minister?

—Not to my knowledge, but you can do the homework involved. Have some regard for our poor over-worked government business enterprises and companies trying to make a buck in a hard and cruel and hostile universe.

—I also draw the Minister's attention to the fact that, for the moment at least, I am still in opposition, but I hope to change that situation shortly. However, the Minister does have the advantage of having these highly paid and hard-working members of the Public Service at his disposal and, if the Minister had been so minded, they could have provided me with that information. I presume that the Minister is not so minded. What has happened to the documents that were to be produced to the members of the Committee? On either 10 or 11 October a number of documents were still outstanding when the meeting ended at 11 o'clock and I understood that some of that information was to be provided to me. It is now well into the next month and I cannot understand why the chamber has not been provided with the information that it requested.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have just been handed some documents relating to Arrow Air Services Pty Ltd. Is that the subject matter of the honourable senator's question?

—One of them related to the number of occasions and in what circumstances discretion was exercised by the Authority in relation to pilots and planes that have been brought into operation in the emergency. There were two other matters.
—This particular information is for Senator MacGibbon, it says here. I do not know whether or not Senator Newman is running this exercise on his behalf.
—No, not at all. I am not a member of the Committee, but I attended for 13 long hours.
—Order! The Minister has the call, so we will let him finish first.
—No, I cannot help the honourable senator with those documents. I will investigate this matter and ascertain what is going on.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would now like to address generally the question of the Estimates Committee B report to the Senate. I draw the Committee's attention to the fact that the report covers only about eight points, all of which are technical, relating to the administration of the hearing and none of which go to the very important substantive issues that were raised during the Estimates Committee hearings covering two or three days. During a time as important as the airline dispute-which, as we know, is now over-I, for one, was very disappointed to note that the officers of the Authority who appeared before the Senate Estimates Committee were so ill-prepared for answering questions of detail on a matter that was, and has continued since to be, of such importance to the nation. Anybody who is interested in the subject would have expected that officers of the Department would have come prepared with a great deal more material than they did. It was almost as if the Estimates Committee caught them by surprise. Certainly, I would have expected that the question of compensation and the questions that were raised at the Estimates Committee hearing on 3 October would have been at least referred to in the Estimates Committee report. I was disappointed to find that there was no reference to them at all.

SPEECH.PARA: On 11 October there was a hearing of a quite different nature and one which I have never experienced in my 3 1/2 years in Parliament. That Estimates Committee hearing on 11 October was called in response to a request by the Opposition for a Senate select committee to be established to deal with questions relating to the airline dispute and questions of safety. This was an extremely important matter which was causing great concern in the country. As a compromise measure, instead of establishing a Senate select committee, it was agreed by all parties that the Estimates Committee be recalled. As the chamber has already heard in previous debate, that committee meeting was a most appalling exercise in prevention of information being made available to senators.

I do not wish to dwell upon that matter now because my colleague Senator Chaney has made it very clear in the past that that Estimates Committee hearing was a travesty. Serious matters and questions were raised at that hearing which were stifled. The behaviour of Government members at that hearing defies belief. As a result of that, the Senate was so appalled by what took place that there was then support for the establishment of a select committee to look not only at the question of safety and compensation aspects but also at the economic impact of the airline dispute on the country. I am glad to say that that committee has now been formed.

I want now, in a somewhat conciliatory mood, to raise a matter which I believe should have been included in the report of Senate Estimates Committee B but which I found missing-that is, the question of the ruling by the Chairman of the Committee, Senator Coates, during the hearing on 11 October, with regard to the sub judice rule. Documentary evidence was available to that Committee and officers were present who could have answered questions about those documents. However, Committee members were informed that we would not be able to ask a range of questions that we wished to ask because they may have related to matters which may be the subject of hearings before courts. This occurred at the time when the airlines were issuing writs at the drop of a hat against anybody who said anything about the airline dispute. Matters of great importance could have been tested at that hearing, but honourable senators were prevented from doing so by the Chairman's ruling that these matters would be going before a court and the Senate could not inquire into them.

I draw the attention of honourable senators to the fact that since that date I have put two notices of motion before the Senate relating to the question of the use of the sub judice rule. Senator Coates said that he was a new chairman and he was concerned that he should not do the wrong thing. Therefore, he chose to err on the side of safety. I felt that he was wrong and I tried to persuade him to overturn his ruling. I produced examples from Hansard and advice from the Clerk, but I was unable to use these effectively to change the Chairman's mind.

I believe that this is something which cannot be allowed to continue. If it does, we will have a situation in the Senate where we will not be able to perform our duty of inquiring into matters of national importance. Frequently, matters which are to go before the courts also come before the Parliament. There have been rulings down the years by Presidents and by other parliaments.

I draw the attention of honourable senators to some recent rulings in this chamber. On 10 May 1988 the President referred to a suggestion that writs had been issued in relation to a matter brought forward for debate. He drew attention to the lack of significance of the issuing of writs and to the basis of the sub judice principle-that is, that proceedings on foot must not be prejudiced. On 30 May 1989 Senator Dunn was allowed to continue a speech referring to a person then charged with a criminal offence, following a notable exposition of the sub judice principle by the Minister for Justice, Senator Tate. On 27 September 1989, Senator Dunn was restrained from continuing a speech on the basis of the possibility that the matter could be before a jury in the near future. At the suggestion of Senator Evans-the Minister who is in the chamber today-she postponed her speech until the matters to which she proposed to refer could be examined to assess the danger of prejudice to a trial then in prospect. Erskine May sets out the rules of the House of Commons which, of course, are also significant for the emphasis which they give as to where the legal action is at the time that the matter comes before the Parliament.

What is quite clear and has not been in doubt in this Parliament is that until a matter is about to go to trial or to a hearing, the Senate must not be prevented from pursuing its lawful purpose. In this case, Estimates Committee B was so prevented, despite my protests. We must not allow this situation to continue or to be in any doubt. Therefore, I draw the Committee's attention to the request which I have made in the motion of which I gave notice on 2 November, that the President make a formal statement to the Senate as to whether previous Presidents' rulings should be regarded as defining the limits of the sub judice rule and prescribing the approach to be adopted by all chairmen of committees. It is not good enough for chairmen of committees to say that they are new and they want to err on the side of safety. The role of the Parliament is too important to have it thwarted by somebody for good reason, or even for malicious reason, which I am not ascribing to Senator Coates. We must make sure that senators who take up the important job of chairing our committees fully understand their responsibility in relation to the sub judice rule.

I am disappointed not only at the ruling that Senator Coates made and the fact that he was obviously not prepared to follow the advice which the Committee received and the precedents which I tried to show him on that occasion, but also that the matter was not raised in some appropriate way in the report of Estimates Committee B. I urge the President to lay down a ruling very soon and give directions to chairmen of committees so that the application of the sub judice rule in this chamber and in its committees is always consistent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —If that is an example of Senator Newman in conciliatory mode, I would hate to listen to her when she is feeling a little on the peppery side. I take the point about what she said in regard to the sub judice rule. It is always a matter of delicate judgment for anyone in the position of chairing a committee. I would not want to say anything that would be construed as expressing any lack of support for my colleague Senator Coates who, I know, had a very hard row to hoe on that day. Here, as elsewhere, the kind of questions which Senator Newman obviously wants to pursue-or is lamenting the previous lack of opportunity to pursue-about the airlines affair, are perhaps better dealt with by the Committee that has been established, rather than by trying to deal across the chamber now with further matters of detail. On the subject which she has addressed in regard to getting answers on matters of detail, I refer her to the fact that the current Department of Finance guidelines which cover the attendance of departmental officials at Estimates committee hearings state:

SPEECH.PARA: The departments have a responsibility to provide witnesses who are sufficiently expert and adequately briefed to provide answers immediately and competently.
Where they cannot provide answers immediately there is a further guideline which says:
Requests for supplementary information should be the subject of every effort to have the material provided within seven days.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 5.30 p.m., pursuant to the resolution of the Senate this day, the debate is interrupted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-
(a) recognises the breach in the Berlin Wall for what it is-a powerful symbol of the triumph of freedom over oppression;
(b) welcomes the prospects of a more democratic future for the peoples of Eastern Europe;
(c) applauds the courage of those who defied repression and intimidation in the cause of greater political and economic freedom;
(d) notes the considerable uncertainty as to the future course of events in Europe; and
(e) supports measures that will actively encourage genuine reform processes in Eastern Europe in a way consistent with Western security and economic interests.

I thank the Senate for its cooperation in allowing this matter to be dealt with this afternoon. Every day history is created, but some facets of history are more dramatic, more exciting, more hopeful and more challenging than others. What is happening at an astonishing pace in eastern Europe meets all of those descriptions. The wonderful sight of East Germans crossing the wall, of East and West Germans greeting each other with open arms, was brought to our living rooms in recent days. We have moved this motion to allow the Australian parliamentary representatives to record their support for the extension of freedom but also to recognise that many of the hurdles remain to be jumped before a new order of security and freedom can be assured.

The extraordinary developments in East Germany, Czechoslovakia and now Bulgaria over recent weeks have been further confirmation that the post-war order in Europe is undergoing rapid and fundamental change. Taken together with the reform processes under way in Hungary and Poland-and within the Soviet Union itself-a whole new era for the people of Europe is emerging. In recent times we have seen Lech Walesa before the Congress in Washington; most of the old guard in Romania, except for the President, has been swept away; President Gorbachev is soon to meet the Pope in the Vatican; and, as we have indicated in the terms of this motion, the Berlin Wall is being chiselled away. No-one would have said a few years ago that any of these events would have been possible, and some of these events would not have been foreshadowed even a matter of months ago.

What is happening in the Soviet Union and eastern Europe has to be understood in terms of the bankruptcy of communism as an ideology. The mass rallies in Prague, Dresden, Leipzig, Riga, Vilnius and Tallinn show that political and economic freedom has an attraction that no repressive government can forever stifle. Their actions have demonstrated that centralised economic control is a discredited system. The resurgence of democracy has been a triumph for basic political and economic freedoms. Economic failure, I suggest, is the key to what has been occurring. Food queues, housing shortages and the absence of basic products essential for reasonable life have brought enormous pressure upon the eastern European states. The yearning for freedom, of course, has always been there. Add to that the effect of growing interaction with the West, an interaction which the East could no longer afford to ignore because it was unable to remain isolated, it having been demonstrated to those in the East that there was an alternative that could lead to a better lifestyle; the inspired and courageous leadership of Lech Walesa and others whose names we are just learning; and finally a changed attitude in the Soviet Union, and the pressure for change becomes irrepressible.

I want to return briefly to the Soviet Union. Without a changed approach, which honourable senators may argue has occurred voluntarily or has been forced upon the Soviet Union by reality, these changes within eastern Europe would not be happening. Mr Gorbachev saw the same problems in the Soviet Union as we have seen facing the eastern satellite states. He saw it economically falling further and further behind the West, with obvious ultimate defence implications, he recognised that Western technology was essential, and he recognised that economic improvement was not possible without a diversion of excessively high military expenditure-all of which meant that he had to work for a better relationship with the West.

We applaud President Gorbachev's recognition that there cannot be economic reform without political reform-perestroika without glasnost. The modest extensions of freedom that have been granted within the Soviet Union we obviously support. But the reforms that are under way in the Soviet Union, as most will appreciate, are occurring under great stress. Mr Gorbachev himself is performing a delicate juggling act with almost irreconcilable political demands and pressures: radicals who want the reforms to go further; conservatives concerned with the legitimacy and primacy of Marxism and the territorial integrity of the Soviet Union; and popular frustration with the failure of reform to produce anything so far in the way of tangible improvements in the quality of life, some people in the Soviet Union arguing that their quality of life has deteriorated during the process of change. With such pressures and Gorbachev's future and that of his programs still unresolved, we suggest to the chamber this afternoon that we must exercise caution in our own assessments not only for the Soviet Union but also for eastern Europe because they are irrevocably linked. The process of reform itself, whilst we applaud it, will lead to an interim period of great instability. An unstable environment always presents its own dangers. It is hard to see, for example, how the Warsaw Pact will hold together if its ideological bond is broken, notwithstanding the fact that Mr Gorbachev has been prepared to allow these processes in eastern Europe to occur provided that the Warsaw Pact is not harmed thereby.

Of course events in eastern Europe are still unfolding. No-one can predict with certainty how they will finally be resolved. There is certainly an imposing agenda building up of unresolved issues created by these events. The significance of these events in eastern Europe is not confined to Europe's boundaries. They create a significant movement of population and possible new sources of refugees and immigrants. They generate changes in the pattern of trade and financial flow. They lead in the longer term to reviews of security and military deployments. I remind the Senate that the United States Secretary of Defense only yesterday foreshadowed big cuts to United States defence spending in the European theatre. The result of the reviews of security could have wide implications for Australia as a member of the Western Alliance. Our challenge is to work out how we can lock into these changes in a positive way, to be supportive and also to protect our own interests.

Senator Gareth Evans told us earlier today that he is being deployed by the Australian Government to Europe to make an assessment of what is occurring. We read in the press that he is to produce a detailed assessment of the security, trade and financial implications for Australia and to put that down in the Parliament. We hope it is to be put down in the Parliament; Senator Evans has introduced no papers into this chamber. The closing of our Berlin Mission in 1986 did not show much foresight. We hope that the Minister may now recognise that it was in fact shortsighted. In view of the dramatic circumstances of recent times, the Opposition will look to having the Berlin Mission reopened.

Our advice to Senator Evans and to the Australian Government while it remains in office and attempts to assess what is happening in eastern Europe is to be cautious. We regret that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) saw it in his best domestic political interests to bucket our caution when addressing the Evatt Foundation a few days ago. We suggest that the Government should remember that the Western alliance has secured against war for a record period in Europe and that strong alliances, soundly based on mutual interests, offer better security than Mr Hawke's personal relationships with other world leaders. The Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, in our assessment, sees its security for the future in a neutral Europe, and at least for the foreseeable future a neutral Europe is not in our best security interests.

We suggest that the Government support the economic process of these eastern European states which are embracing a new direction, because economic involvement will best secure continuation of the democratisation process. This will require some flexibility in approach, because some countries, such as Poland, will obviously need assistance and an aid level, whereas perhaps the best way that we can assist Hungary in its economic development may simply be through opening up the opportunities to trade. So each country will have to be assessed on its own unique circumstances.

We also suggest that the Government, in making this assessment of Australia's interests in the light of these dramatic events occurring in Europe, should not underestimate the effects of the post-1992 delivery of a single market within the European Economic Community which must now be linked with the possibility of a further economic linkage with a even wider democratic European Community. If this occurs, the consequences to trade and the economies of countries such as ours will be enormous. The time to make these considerations and plan for these possible changes is now, not in some years time.

In summary, therefore, we rejoice in the fact that the people of eastern Europe are being offered the possibility of freedom, which they have not enjoyed for so many years. We believe that Australia should be looking for ways in which it can support that process consistent with our own interests, particularly our security interests but obviously also our economic interests. Australia should be realistic and recognise that the best way it can do that is to support particularly the western European states which are at the front line and are working hard towards the objective of furthering the democracy process and the economic opportunities in the east.

We applaud the fact that the European Community leaders have met only in the last few days to look at ways in which an economic linkage might be extended and a bank might be formed that could help in the reconstruction of eastern Europe. We would like to see Australia locking into this process. There is a great goal to be achieved. We want Australia to be supportive. We want the process to continue and ultimately to lead to a situation of greater security, greater stability and freedom for all those who have suffered from oppression for so long.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have no hesitation whatever in supporting on behalf of the Government this motion now before the Senate. I did respond in some little detail in Question Time today on a number of aspects of this question. I do not want to retrack over that ground and, as a result, I think I can make this contribution perhaps a little shorter than it might otherwise have been.

SPEECH.PARA: Nonetheless, there are some important things to say and to put on the record. The first of them perhaps is that bipartisan support for the sentiments expressed in this motion which we are seeing here in both Houses today does reflect, I think, the very great pleasure and, indeed, excitement felt by all Australians at the breathtaking developments that we are witnessing in east Europe. Indeed, it is the case that many Australians escaped totalitarian regimes in east Europe, and for these people in particular there will be a definite satisfaction in seeing their former homelands revert to freedom. The fact that the Opposition has come a little belatedly perhaps to an appreciation of the significance of what is happening, as the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) rather graphically made clear in his contribution to the debate in the other place today, makes its current enlightenment no less welcome for that.

TALK.START.PARA: —You're not going to lower yourself to that level, are you?

—I am a statesman these days. The motion correctly recognises that there are uncertainties ahead so far as the future of Europe is concerned. As Senator Hill himself noted, one simply cannot assume that President Gorbachev will in fact stay around to follow through the implications of the crusade on which he has embarked-and it deserves no lesser description than that-in the Soviet Union, the problem there being the extraordinary expectations that have been generated by the course of events until now and the danger that, particularly so far as economic prosperity is concerned, those expectations will not be satisfied for a long time to come. That is a situation that does perhaps generate very real problems for political leaders.

SPEECH.PARA: However, one thing about which there is absolute certainty is that the ideological foundations of communism as it has been practised in eastern Europe and elsewhere have unequivocally crumbled. While the grand principles of the socialist tradition of equality, social cooperation and personal freedom are undoubtedly still capable of application in political and economical systems, what has become unequivocally clear is that their application in the traditional command, totalitarian economies of eastern Europe has proved wholly and comprehensively unpalatable to the citizens of those countries and that the only possible future environment in which they can be pursued in the future is one of political and economic democracy. That is the great phenomenon that we are witnessing at the moment. It represents a transformation of contemporary history, and it is a course of events that we wholly welcome.

The foundations on which post-World War II Europe were built are being fundamentally shaken and reshaped. The cold war, which we had come to regard as an inevitable feature of contemporary European and global life, is now receding to the point where that description is just no longer applicable. The huge armies that faced each other across Europe already seem to be part of yesterday's world. How else can we interpret events when a soldier can patrol his border during the week and then stroll across it to the other side for some shopping over the weekend? Surely, the nuclear arsenals which the superpowers hold must be the next item on the international agenda to flow from this extraordinary rebirth of rethinking that we are seeing in Europe.

It is in that context that the Australian Government very warmly welcomes the decisions of President Bush and President Gorbachev to meet in Malta early next month. Their task is not to draw up a new blueprint for Europe. We do not wish to repeat the mistakes of Yalta, but it is important to maintain the flow of dialogue at the highest levels and avoid the kinds of misperceptions and misunderstandings that can creep into international relations when that kind of communication does not occur. It is far too early to try to prognosticate about the larger strategic implications of what is happening, but that there are implications and that some of them are already working themselves out-for example, in the United States defence budget decision making process-is not to be denied.

As the motion points out, the wall in Berlin is perhaps the centrepiece and focus of international attention at the moment. It has been a symbol of a world ideologically and geographically divided. The wall as a fortification has been well enough known in world history, but the wall as a barrier to fence in the country's own people in a prison state is one of those particularly ugly innovations of the twentieth century. Every year we learnt with horror of those who had died trying to breach that wall, the last victim being shot as recently as earlier this year. We sympathise with the families which are torn apart by the existence of that wall. It is, therefore, entirely appropriate that the Senate should focus, as it is in this motion, on the crumbling away of that wall as the most powerful and unhappy symbol of our times.

There are very real prospects for agreement on new security arrangements and understandings for the whole of Europe based on and catalysed by the new mood of East-West cooperation. We can hope for early full-scale agreement to match the earlier discussions that have occurred already on conventional force reduction in Europe. The North Atlantic Treaty Organisation has already formally tabled proposals and the initial Warsaw Pact reaction to those proposals has been very positive. The clear and unmistakeable impression we can properly glean from these remarkable developments is that both alliances are determined to succeed and to conclude expeditiously agreements on radical and stabilising reductions in what is still the most heavily militarised part of the world.

The motion goes on to welcome in effect the prospect of a new Europe. There are now hopeful signs that it will be a Europe of liberal democracy-small `l' liberal democracy-a Europe with a prosperous market economy; and a Europe where human rights are respected. These are the very values that Australia has defended over the years. That is why we can take particular pleasure in Europe's present day triumph. While the battle is not over, the evidence of change is overwhelming. In Hungary we can see a nation united in its desire to rejoin Europe as a multi-party democracy with open borders. In Poland we have seen the Marxist-Leninist party give up its leading role and serve under a non-communist Prime Minister. In the German Democratic Republic (GDR) we have been witness to a spectacular demonstration of people power in which the majorities of cities' inhabitants have demonstrated in favour of fundamental change, a display so overwhelming that the authorities had no option but to accept the will of their people and to break down that wall.

As I said in Question Time today, the situation is still rather less promising in Czechoslovakia, although obviously tumultuous events are occurring there too. It is distinctly less promising still in Bulgaria, although signs of movement are on the way with the replacement of a long serving and peculiarly lugubrious leader in recent times. In Romania, regrettably, there are no signs at all for the moment of that peculiarly unattractive regime succumbing to the same sentiments which undoubtedly beat in the heart of its people. It can, one presumes, be only a matter of time before movement occurs there, but obviously there is a long way to go. Albania, which is still preoccupied with the China of the 1950s, and with its particular model of social progress, remains off the map as far as Eastern Europe reform is concerned. We need to acknowledge the realities and the fact that not everything is happening at once, but an enormous amount is happening and I am sure that all honourable senators will join me in calling on the other nations of East Europe to embark upon that road of reform and democracy.

Senator Hill acknowledges the extent to which I am dealing with the substance of his motion-I am not merely using it as a rhetorical springboard-and it is appropriate that we applaud the courage, as the motion does, of those who defied repression and intimidation in the cause of greater political and economic freedom. One of the leading dissidents, Andrei Sakharov, is now a parliamentarian in the Soviet Union and is playing a major role in shaping the future of his country. Others have not found-to date anyway-so happy an ending. This is a particularly appropriate time to recall Imre Nagy, the Prime Minister of Hungary in 1956, who was hanged for his resistance and his espousal of some of the things that are happening today. It is at least comforting, to all except Imre Nagy, to know that he has been posthumously remembered for his services to his country.

The fate of yet another leading reformer reminds us that the battle is by no means won. Alexander Dubcek was arrested last Friday in Prague for participating in a demonstration calling for political reform there. One hopes that these are just the last gasps of the dinosaur as it succumbs to the momentum that has been so widely generated. But it is important that we continue to acknowledge that the millennium is not yet with us; there is still a road to travel.

In that context it is important that Australia continues to support actively, to the extent that we can realistically, given our geographical location and clout in that part of the world, this course of events. We have been active in the general Western response to these developments. We have worked with the G24-the group of Western nations-coordinating material assistance to eastern Europe. As I said today, recalling an earlier announcement, the Prime Minister has indicated a package of measures to provide economic assistance to Poland and Hungary. That package announced on 15 October includes food aid to Poland to the value of $5m; extension of the Australian system of tariff preferences to both Poland and Hungary; and the negotiation of double taxation agreements and investment protection agreements with both countries.

The thrust of these measures is not to provide charity but to give Poland and Hungary a better opportunity to help themselves and to reinvigorate their economies. The process of assistance in which we are participating will also, hopefully, help cement the incorporation of Poland and Hungary in the international economic system. We have worked closely with our Western allies to provide encouraging signals to the governments and peoples of eastern Europe and we will continue along that course.

Senator Hill posed the question as to what we ought to be doing regarding our diplomatic representation in eastern Europe. I do not think that it was entirely appropriate to slap us around for our lack of foresight in closing the GDR mission as we did in 1986 in an environment of fiscal restraint which, I note, will be pursued with knobs on by any administration which we may be unfortunate to see Senator Hill lead. Our absence of foresight was a mere bagatelle as compared with that offered by the Opposition, not least in Mr Peacock's spectacular Cleopatra metaphor. As that has had something of an outing today, I will not belabour the point, but it is too good a prediction to miss putting into the public record Mr Peacock's response to the Prime Minister's statement on his trip to Hungary in July this year when he referred to the Prime Minister as being `like Cleopatra in a barge'. He stated:
Like Cleopatra in her barge, we had the sight of our Prime Minister sailing down the Danube proclaiming the world `was at a turning point in history'.
Mr Peacock continued:

The Prime Minister's belief that the new democratic process emerging in Hungary will automatically flow through to other eastern European nations is not borne out in fact. What of Czechoslovakia? What of East Germany?
What indeed of Czechoslovakia and East Germany?

TALK.START.PARA: —What are you saying-that Hawkie was predicting all of this?

—He was there when things were happening. He got it right. He perceived the course and flow of events and made it perfectly clear, in a way which is totally beyond the capacity of the Opposition to appreciate even in its most statesmanlike mode, what was going on. We have a widespread pattern of representation in eastern Europe-in Moscow and Warsaw-which also operates in Czechoslovakia and the GDR. We have missions in Budapest and Belgrade. As to the extent to which it may be necessary to rethink the pattern of that representation in the light of current and future events, that is something which we will bear in mind.

SPEECH.PARA: We are trying to keep track of the situation and estimate its impact on Australia and the rest of the world as best we can. As I said in Question Time today, and as Senator Hill acknowledged politely and graciously, I will travel to Europe next month to participate first hand in this historic process, attending a likely ministerial meeting in Brussels of the G24 countries on 13 December. This will give me an opportunity to discuss with my Western ministerial colleagues their current thinking on the strategic and economic implications of what is happening. To the extent that it is possible to organise this in the time available, given all the tumultuous circumstances, I will also seek to make high level contact with the new reform leadership in Poland, Hungary, Czechoslovakia and, hopefully, the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics and the GDR in order both to get a first-hand feel for it and to meet the new leaders who will play a fundamental and important role in future. That will also enable Australia to assess the implications in this context of the impact it is likely to have on world economic developments, the trading system and trading and investment opportunities for Australia.

There will be opportunities for all Western nations in the re-ordered economies of Eastern Europe. For that reason alone I will seek to make contact with those responsible for economic management and trade policy to see where the opportunities for us might lie. We have to grasp those opportunities as best we can, but the real opportunities are those now opened up for the citizens of Eastern Europe themselves. It is their new-found freedom that we should be particularly celebrating today and I am glad to add my voice to that cause.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -At the moment we are discussing a motion moved by Senator Hill with regard to a number of matters. The first one focuses on the breach in the Berlin Wall as a symbol of what is occurring. Indeed, it is a symbol of the types of situations which one day politically are considered immutable and the next day are swept away. Unfortunately, all too often it is assumed that this is done in a way that has nothing to do with Australia and that we are mere spectators of the changes and events that exist around us. That, of course, is not the case. Australia, under any administration, spends a considerable amount of money and expertise in seeking constructive change around the world. That is totally appropriate. Unfortunately, silly debates often take place within the Australian community about the usefulness of many of the activities we engage in-many of the international conferences that we and our representatives attend and, indeed, many of the diplomatic operations that are carried out. In many ways the events that occur around the world often flow from this type of activity.

SPEECH.PARA: The breach in the Berlin Wall is a symbol that we are moving to a new stage and that we must rethink the type of approach we have had in the past. It is somewhat unfortunate that Senator Hill's motion does not entirely manage to break free of the way of thinking that we cannot afford to continue with. I refer, for example, to part (5), which states:
. . . measures that will actively encourage genuine reform processes in Eastern Europe in a way consistent with Western security and economic interests.

The most secure type of operation for the West's economic interests is that the developments in eastern Europe may be in the interests of the people there, and the most secure interests that they see for themselves--

TALK.START.PARA: —That might therefore be in our interests.

—I think that merely to pose a suggestion that the types of developments that ought to go on there should be ones which are useful for us is, first, naive and, secondly, not useful in the sense that the ones which finally will bed down and take root in those countries are those which are in their national interest.

SPEECH.PARA: We have seen a very clear indication on the part of the people of many of the countries in eastern Europe that the type of economic and political regime that has been operating is not in their interests but has been operating in the interest of small cliques and groups. Hence the people themselves have finally come to the breaking point. But, of course, people are able to be intimidated. One only had to view on television in recent days the `spontaneous applause' on 60 or 65 occasions for President Ceausescu of Romania in, of all things, a six-hour speech to know that dictators are alive and well and that people can be intimidated and terrorised into accepting them.

That prospect, of course, can re-emerge in eastern Europe and, we must acknowledge, in the rest of the world as well. It behoves us to be slightly humble. Even a country in the organisation to which we belong and with which we have so many ties, the Commonwealth of Nations, managed to create its own dictatorship and overthrow a democracy in our own region within the last couple of years. These types of changes have occurred in the past and may occur in the future. They will not be prevented simply by what I heard Senator Hill refer to as the `quality of life'-by which I think he was actually referring to the standard of living. They will be prevented not simply by economic measures but by worldwide support for a whole range of issues which I would like to call the quality of life issues. They are issues of freedom and democracy and the support of people who are poor and oppressed. There is also the recognition-which has now been acknowledged, I think-of the complete unwillingness of people to live any longer in a constantly and increasingly polluted environment. That is a very important element in the changes, for example, that are taking place in the Soviet Union.

In Senator Hill's terms, the Senate should welcome the prospects for a more democratic future for the peoples of eastern Europe. Certainly it should. I think that that is the most important item of Senator Hill's motion. We should welcome an increasing ability of the people of eastern Europe to determine their own future in a way which is in their interests and for their development. Some stupid articles have been written about recent events being a triumph of capitalism. They are silly and probably do not require very much rebuttal, but it is naive to suggest that people were looking for some of the aspects in our society that we in this chamber spend a lot of time trying to eradicate and constantly pass laws trying to prevent. There is no way in the world, for example, that any of the Eastern bloc countries want our level of imprisonment, or the gross drug trade, or any of the other ills we have managed to spawn in our society.

Let us not be overweeningly proud that we have managed to develop a social structure that does not incorporate ills and problems. We have them. They are part of our structure and they are part of the way that we have chosen to organise ourselves economically. We have a lot of developing to do and a lot of changes to initiate within our own societies. I suppose we can acknowledge that many of these societies which have up until recently suffered under oppression have been able to move in the direction they have.

One particularly important element in all of this exercise, of course, is the incredible change that has taken place in the prospects of world peace. It was not many years ago that that famous clock had its hands moved much closer to 12. When they were asked their greatest worry, it was that the world would not even be around. That was not so long ago. Indeed, it was only a couple of years ago that that was turning up in the polls taken of youth in this country.

What has occurred since, of course, has been nothing short of a revolution. It has been initiated from the side of the Soviet Union, which is rather extraordinary. Earlier, Senator Crichton-Browne gave a most extraordinary interpretation of what has been occurring. One point he made concerned this particular matter. It was the Soviet Union that moved first and moved constructively to unravel, but the reasons for this would obviously be a matter of dispute between us. I freely acknowledge that a large amount of it was driven by sheer economic desperation as the Soviet Union economy very rapidly became unravelled. In fact it was the Soviet Union that moved under its current President and it was, at least in part, the response of the United States which enabled that momentum to be carried through. What we as a small country have to do is keep up the pace of those types of developments. We do not do that by being a sycophant of either, but by stating our voice as a small country that has an interest in this matter. The momentum towards peace, the momentum towards disarmament and the unravelling of the nuclear insanity that still exists must be a high priority, and we in the West have as much responsibility as the countries of Eastern Europe to engage in that activity.

The proposition in Senator Hill's comments at paragraph (d), concerning the considerable uncertainty as to the future course of events in Europe, is acknowledged. Certainly, one would have to have blinkers on not to know that many of the positive changes that have taken place could be overturned as readily as they have come. It is in our interests to make sure that they are not. How do we actually do that? One of the ways that the Government has chosen is for the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) to visit Europe. I thought the Opposition's rather lukewarm support for that was rather odd. It seems to me to be most appropriate that a senior Minister of the Government go to eastern Europe at this stage to present from the point of view of Australia another symbol against the Berlin Wall symbol and indicate that we recognise the important changes that have taken place. It is a pity that Senator Hill, on behalf of the Opposition, could not give warmer support for that initiative by the Government. For our part, we wish Senator Evans well in that move not only in terms of demonstrating that Australia is very supportive of the changes that are taking place but also in terms of our economic interests, to see where in fact we need to go economically and in trade.

The Australian embassy in the German Democratic Republic was mentioned by both Senator Hill and Senator Evans. I think I am the only person on record as opposing the closure of the GDR embassy at the time. The reason was not that I had prescience that this was about to occur; I wish I had, but I did not. The reason I opposed it was that I have always seen the GDR as being the linchpin in whatever occurred in that region in the future. I did not expect what occurred in the GDR to occur. I must admit that, even two or three months ago, I would have thought it almost impossible. But I did know at the time that we should be there as a listening post and be able to understand the types of movements that were taking place because undoubtedly the GDR has been, is currently and will be, in the near future at least, a country very important to an understanding of what is occurring in the Eastern bloc. An embassy there would be more important than our embassies in Warsaw and a number of other countries. That is not to denigrate them; it is merely to say that the GDR does have a fundamental role probably because of its strategic and geographic locality and also because it has been the most successful of the Eastern bloc countries economically and has always been a powerful voice in their deliberations. It seemed to me that it was, in that vein, a silly move to close down the embassy there. I hope that the Foreign Minister, in his visits, will look very closely at the possibility of restoring that diplomatic mission in Berlin as again an essential ingredient in our total diplomatic moves. I thought it was silly at the time, not because I had the foresight to know what would occur but because it was then a very important country in understanding the eastern European area.

The Australian Democrats support the motion moved today and welcome this move by Senator Hill and the Opposition in this chamber and in the other place. We are living in exciting times. We are living in dramatic times. We are living in times full of hope. It is important that we in this chamber add our words and encouragement to those very hopeful prospects that are occurring, and I thank Senator Hill for undertaking this move. While we are mindful, as he suggested, of the uncertainties of the future, we are supportive of the changes that are taking place and certainly wish that all of those moves to democracy, liberty and freedom will be encouraged by the GDR being joined by other countries in quick succession. I refer to those countries that have not joined in any sense, such as Albania, or in any constructive way, such as Romania. Little has been done in Bulgaria. Even the Czechoslovakian situation remains extremely unclear. The moves in Czechoslovakia could go in any direction as of even today. Opening Czechoslovakia will be a difficult task if repression on a mass scale takes place by those leaders clinging to power in what is undoubtedly a vastly unpopular government.

The situation is sitting on a knife edge. We have seen some wondrous things take place and we wish that more will occur. At the same time we must say that the changes that will take place and really take root are those that are in the genuine interests of the people of those countries, not necessarily to construct the type of country that we happen to like but to construct the type of country and social system that looks after those people and delivers to them security, freedom and reasonable economic growth and development. If that happens, we can be assured that it will continue; if that does not happen, the country will undoubtedly close down again and it may be another 50 years before we see any lights on the hill and we will all be plunged back into a situation to which we do not wish to return, one in which the world itself teeters on the edge of nuclear war and holocaust. We have moved away from that in a fashion which I repeat is almost unbelievable. It is enormously hopeful for those of us who politically spent a lot of time on this issue that the countries are now in a position to be unravelling their nuclear arsenals and spending on the poor and the underprivileged everywhere in the world those vast amounts which today are spent on weaponry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I share the general sense of hope and welcome the changes that have been taking place very dramatically in recent times in eastern Europe. I am grateful to Senator Hill for putting forward a motion which gives us a chance to express our hope that these changes for further democracy will take place. These are indeed amazing times.
