Only a few years ago, we would not have thought it possible that the Berlin Wall would have crumbled to the extent that it has.

SPEECH.PARA: In general terms, I support the motion, but come in with a word of warning about the very last line of the motion which suggests that we should encourage the reform processes in eastern Europe in a way consistent with Western security and economic interests. We should be thinking about global security, not Western or Eastern. That is part of the cold war thinking that has to go. That is the dramatic change which we have to embrace wholeheartedly. It will impose some risks and it will make people feel nervous because of the rate of change that has taken place. We should think of security in a global sense rather than an East-West sense because that is the stuff of the cold war, that is the stuff we have to leave behind. We must not look at this in terms of what is best for us or our security on one side of the ideological divide. We have to move beyond both communism and capitalism. The world is doing that at a very great pace. Environmental concerns have brought the world together because we have to think as one global community and not as part of one ideological set opposing another.

I welcome the motion in its expression of our hope for greater democracy and its applauding the courage of those who have struggled for openness over the years since this divide has been in place, since families have been separated. The enormous courage displayed by so many people in seeking this greater openness certainly needs to be recognised. I include in that group people who have been extraordinarily courageous, those who have been persecuted for belonging to peace groups behind what has been called the Iron Curtain. They have been there all these years and we have been in contact with them. I have continually mentioned in this place-I think some honourable senators have not believed it-that opposition to the Warsaw Pact was alive and well within the Warsaw Pact. People who have been working in an underground sense all these years are now vindicated in the efforts that they have made. Certainly they have been working for disarmament and have opposed the militarisation of the Warsaw Pact as much as we in the West have opposed the militarisation of the Western alliance.

We need not only to look at the situation in eastern Europe and the importance that it has for all of us globally, but also to bring that rhetoric and our hopes for genuine democracy to our region. We should also bring the work for disarmament into our region. That is what my notice of motion earlier today was about. The major superpowers of both East and West should reduce their military expenditure. It is high time that they realised the need to do that. It is absolutely essential, as Senator Macklin said, that we pay attention to the very real social needs which remain unmet. Millions of people could well do with military expenditure being redirected towards meeting the basic social needs of human beings. Our environment could also benefit from some of the billions of dollars we pour into militarisation. That money could go into repairing our environment so that we can all live as global citizens belonging to one world. Increasingly, it has to be seen as that.

Going further than that, I call on the Australian Government to respond. We heard from the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) many very encouraging words about the situation in eastern Europe, but he did not translate what that means for Australia in our region, what it means for us here. Will the promise of the former Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Hayden, of regional disarmament, looking at naval arms control, especially in the Pacific, be on the agenda now? It should be. I encourage our Foreign Minister to take up the enormous challenges and opportunities which are now presented for the Pacific also to be a part of the disarmament process, also to recognise that the cold war is over and to look seriously at the question of naval arms control in our region.

The weapons that have been dismantled in western Europe-of course, I join with others in being very glad about that-the intermediate nuclear range systems, are now being deployed at sea. One-third of the world's nuclear weapons are on board ships and submarines which are all over the place in our oceans and are increasingly coming into our ports. The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) would do well to acknowledge that that is also part of the environment movement. The very people he disparaged in his answer to my question earlier this afternoon are the same people whom he is wooing so assiduously in trying to capture the green vote. It is about time that Senator Richardson made the connection. Disarmament is an environment issue. Getting rid of nuclear weapons which are an environment risk to our ports is an environment issue and the Minister needs to understand that because every time he puts me down so rudely, as he did this afternoon in answer to my very reasonable question about nuclear weapons coming into our ports, he offends a lot of people.

We also have to understand that many of the world's crisis points have related to and continue to relate to East-West tensions. We have seen that exemplified in our region. We need to call again for the removal of all foreign bases in our region. That includes the Soviet base at Cam Ranh Bay, which the Secretary-General of the Soviet Union has put on the international agenda. We need to call for the removal of all United States bases in the region. That has not been put on the agenda by the United States, but it could be put on the agenda by Australia. We have to understand that the ANZUS alliance was framed in the hysteria of cold war rhetoric in the early 1950s when, as Senator Hamer pointed out to me this afternoon, Australia's concern was about the pact that had recently been signed with Japan. We have to understand that many of those tensions which were in existence in the early 1950s are increasingly irrelevant. Thus we need to challenge our membership of the ANZUS treaty; so we need to step up our moves for disarmament in this region; so we need to step up our calls for the naval arms race to be put on the international agenda so that there is some independent monitoring of the nuclear weapons which are on board ships and submarines at sea at the moment. This is all part of the democratisation which must take place and which will flow on from the exciting changes which have taken place in Eastern Europe. We cannot underestimate the nature of the change.

The decade of the 1980s will go down in history as a decade of enormous change, when we move from the cold war concepts of East and West into a global thinking pattern. That is very exciting and encouraging. Australia could be taking a greater part in it by questioning our continued involvement in one of those two superpower blocs. We need to be part of the democratisation process too, which means looking very closely at Australia's current defence relationships, our current expenditure on militarisation which is increasing when in other countries it is decreasing in response to democratisation. We need to challenge what is now being referred to as Australia's new militarism, which is not appropriate in the current economic climate and certainly not appropriate in the current international climate which is moving further towards reconciliation, discussion and democratisation. I welcome the changes.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Sitting suspended from 6.29 to 8 p.m.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT SELECT COMMITTEE ON MIGRATION REGULATIONS

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Leave to Meet During Sittings of the Senate

PROCTEXT.PARA: That the Joint Select Committee on Migration Regulations have leave to meet during sittings of the Senate on 22 and 23 November 1989 for the purpose of considering its draft report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition opposes this motion. I am sorry that we have not really had the opportunity to discuss it across the chamber beforehand, but the situation is that clearly the chamber must take priority. Already two Senate committees have been given leave to sit during the course of the Senate sittings. I have to say to the Government, the Democrats and the Independents that this has been done most reluctantly by us, but on each occasion it was explained to us that the priorities were absolutely essential. The first matter is in relation to the pilots dispute and, with the urgency of that matter, one could understand why the Senate would accept that there would be a need for one of its committees to meet while the Senate was sitting to consider that matter. The next is in relation to a foreign affairs matter where a representative of the Soviet Union has apparently come out from the Soviet Union specifically to deal with this particular matter and it is agreed that the only time he can give evidence is apparently this evening.

SPEECH.PARA: There are not so many senators and, when one looks around the chamber, one sees that the situation is becoming quite out of hand. When we start talking about a committee to deal with regulations in relation to migration, the Opposition thinks that it must draw the line. We had a meeting today at which we pointed out to one of our colleagues, who was raising this question as to whether or not a committee could meet, that it would be possible for the committee to meet formally either during the luncheon recess or during the dinner recess. They could overcome the formal responsibilities in relation to the meeting procedure and thereafter they could then meet informally while the Senate was sitting. That would mean that they would then be responsible for answering the calls of the Senate, including the answering of the bells for divisions and the bells for quorums.

If we continue down the path of allowing Senate committees to meet willy-nilly during the course of the Senate sitting, then ultimately it will get to the stage where the Senate frankly will just not have a quorum available. This is a ridiculous situation and one that we are strongly opposed to. I have been in this Parliament now for 13 years and for many, many years-as long as I have been in this Parliament-we have been opposing Senate committees meeting during the course of the Senate sessions. I can recall my predecessors in this place who used to lecture me at great length-Reg Wright and Jim Cavanagh on the Labor side and others-and say it was outrageous that Senate committees should be allowed to meet.

If the Government has set the program-as it has-currently requiring the Senate to sit right up until 22 December and, in effect, sit four or five days a week right up until 22 December, then all I can say to the Government is that it had better get its act into order and reorganise its program so that there is time for the Senate committees to meet. We are going to oppose this motion, and if the Government would like to take a division, that will be the result.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I listened very carefully and closely to the words of Senator Lewis. I also listened with a degree of sympathy to the sentiments that he was expressing in opposing the motion. I do not think that too many people around Australia realise the workload of senators, not only in time in the chamber, but also in committees. It is a work load that grows exponentially as the session heads to a conclusion, with the necessity for committees of the Parliament to present reports to the Parliament to meet deadlines imposed by the Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: The Migration Regulations Committee is not a committee that the Government sought to have established. We opposed its establishment, but it was the will of the chamber that such a committee be established. In fulfilling the task imposed on it by the Parliament, the Committee has met with a number of obstacles, not the least of which is the fact that the regulations which go with the new Act covering migration to Australia are extremely complicated. They run to about 180 pages. The Committee members received the draft regulations only on 31 October. They met for three days the week before last, one day last week, and all day yesterday. They have certainly put in the hours in attempting to fulfil the obligations imposed upon them. As the Committee has pursued its business, it has been necessary to seek clarification on various items that are included in the draft regulations, and many of the answers to those questions were delivered to the Committee only yesterday.

We have a deadline to meet. The deadline which was imposed was to report back to the Minister by tomorrow and report to the Parliament prior to 19 December. There are all sorts of printing schedules and such to be considered as well. The committee is endeavouring to fulfil the obligations imposed upon it by the Parliament and, quite honestly, this is the only way that we can fulfil those obligations.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator McKiernan's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to raise yet again the question of annual reports arriving long after Senate Estimates committees have met to discuss matters to which these reports relate. I want to draw attention in particular to the annual report of the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) which now, I remind the Committee, is a one-line entry in the Estimates but which involves the expenditure of considerable amounts of money. When I asked questions at the Senate Estimates Committee on the CAA, its role in air safety and the expenditures involved in air safety, I was told that the annual report was not available and that there was no requirement on the Civil Aviation Authority to provide an annual report at any reasonable time. There was not even a suggestion that it should provide a draft to the Senate Estimates Committee because it is one of these new, ludicrous structures which this Government has created, a sort of corporatised body which it seems is responsible effectively neither to this Parliament nor to the public. As I said earlier about Telecom Australia, it is the worst of all worlds.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to stress that as far as I am concerned the CAA situation is totally and grossly unsatisfactory. At that Senate Estimates Committee I asked Mr Freeland of the Civil Aviation Authority, `When do you expect the CAA's annual report to be released?'. His response was, `It is our first annual report, as you know. It is our first year of operation. I would think it should be tabled about November. It is basically complete and has to be printed'. So this report was basically complete at the time the Senate Estimates Committee was inquiring into the operations of the CAA, but the report was not available to the Committee; there was, roughly, a one-line appropriation. I suppose it is appropriate to describe this time as `about November'. It is about the end of November; we are two-thirds of the way through November.

I want the Minister to give some sort of indication, if he can, as to when we can expect the CAA's annual report. Not having the CAA's annual report or any of these annual reports at a time when the Senate Estimates committees meet, which is the only time they are subject to any kind of scrutiny, is like having the annual general meeting of a corporation before the report is issued. I do not know of any other occasion when the Senate is given the opportunity to examine these bodies in any detail, when any real evidence can be presented and their responsibilities to Parliament can be discharged. As you know, Mr Temporary Chairman, a five-minute speech on reports is hardly the place for a coherent examination of the multi-million dollar activities of some of these bodies. This Government in particular has shuffled these bodies increasingly into this halfway house or never-never land, which diminishes Parliament's opportunity of thorough and proper investigation.

The very serious matter of air safety is being examined by a Senate committee as part of the general inquiry into the question of the impact of the pilots strike. This subject had a real relevance and should have been made available to the Senate Estimates Committee at that time. The Committee even held an extra meeting to discuss questions of air safety, but nothing from the CAA annual report was available to us about air safety, even though I did ask about that matter.

I will raise this matter in another forum, but it seems ludicrous that these bodies are exempted from the request to departments to provide their annual reports in good time for Senate Estimates committees. In fact, the Chairman interrupted my questioning during the Senate Estimates Committee meeting by noting that the guidelines for departmental annual reports are to be made available, if possible, even in draft form, for Estimates committees. However, the guidelines for statutory authorities do not contain that requirement. As I said, I believe it is a very bad principle and my first question is: When is the annual report of the CAA-a report, one would imagine, of some substance and relevance-to be made available?

I am also concerned about the annual report of the Federal Airports Corporation (FAC). As I recall it, that report became available to us after the Senate Committee deliberated on the matter, although the letter from Mr Ralph Willis to Mr D. W. Sullivan, the Chairman, appears to bear no date. I cannot recall whether or not this report was available to us at the time. However, as far as I am concerned, the FAC has been involved in a one-sided dispute with me about security at Sydney Airport.

TALK.START.PARA: —Won't they let you in?

—It would be nice if I could get somewhere when I went in. I know that there is no industrial dispute in the airlines because the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has said so, but one cannot get anywhere. The problem with Sydney Airport security is that one can get into secure areas far too easily. Officers from the Auditor-General's Office managed to gain access to the tarmac and to secure areas without any pass or authorisation of any kind. They reported all these matters in an auditor's report and I raised them with the Australian Customs Service in the appropriate Senate Estimates Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: I have made some serious charges in this chamber by repeating the charges made by Customs officers and the Auditor-General. Why did the FAC present a totally misleading and, I believe, disgraceful report on 7 September 1989 in which it claimed that the problems raised by Customs officers and the Auditor-General had largely been resolved when that was simply false, as was evidenced by the comments made by the Customs officers to the Senate Estimates Committee? I wonder whether the Minister has any response to this matter. I might add that all that appeared in the annual report from the FAC was that a review was undertaken at each airport and security had been improved. It has been improved so much that Customs officers believe that it is totally and grossly inadequate.

What concerns me about the lack of any Government response to this matter is that since I raised this matter in the Senate Estimates Committee, I think on 3 October, according to Customs officers a meeting was to be held with the FAC and other relevant bodies at Sydney Airport to discuss the urgent need to improve security. Can the Minister inform the Committee what has happened about that meeting? Were decisions taken that would remove the concerns expressed by the Customs officers? If so, we have heard nothing. The Government has not paid us the courtesy of responding to my expressed concerns about security at Sydney Airport. If staff members of the Auditor-General can walk freely onto the tarmac at Sydney Airport and can report that gates that are supposed to be locked in fact provide ready access because they are unlocked, it seems that we have a real security problem. It is not as though terrorism is unknown in the airline industry. It is not as though there is no real risk that people may behave in a wild, reckless and dangerous way with either threats or actual terrorist activity. The fact is that these things are real.

We have an immense facade of x-ray machines and heavens knows what, which have been installed at great expense, to take baggage or people into security areas and the Auditor-General says, `All you have to do is to walk through the right gate or door'. I would like the Minister to help me, if he could, in these areas because it is a matter of some urgency.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to the latter matters raised by Senator Michael Baume, I am unable to provide that information on this occasion. We will take his concerns on notice and try to expedite a reply to the earlier problems to which he adverted in the Estimates hearings and elsewhere. I am advised that the CAA report is being printed at the moment and it is expected that it will be available before the end of this month.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to address some very important issues of broadcasting policy which I think it is now abundantly clear to the Australian population are totally out of control under the present Government. Not so long ago Senator Evans was vaguely in control of this area, but certainly no-one is in control now. What strikes me above all is the backfilling that has been going on in recent weeks which I think demands an explanation. I hope Senator Evans is sufficiently on top of what has been happening in Cabinet when he chooses to pass through Australia these days to be able to at least throw some light on the difficulties that have emerged. One, of course, is the fiasco that resulted in a journalist writing a report in the Sydney Morning Herald on a briefing she was given by a senior departmental officer which then resulted in an extraordinary letter to the editor, but otherwise no communication with the press, by the Minister for Transport and Communications, Mr Willis.
—Where is Mr Willis?

—As usual, he is sleeping soundly on the sidelines. He is presumably back in the country by now, but why he ever left is a matter of speculation. One can only presume that the kitchen got too hot and he realised there was nothing more to be gained by hanging around. As a result he took the last trip available to him before the change of government. One can well understand why he would do that, but it is certainly not in the best interests of the broadcasting industry or, indeed, broadcasting regulation in general.

SPEECH.PARA: What is particularly deplorable and what I think needs explanation are the two faces that are being presented in this area. The remarks that appeared in the Sydney Morning Herald on 3 November made it clear that the fundamental review that Mr Willis announced on 1 November-when I say `announced' I mean announced by way of press release-was going to canvass a whole range of issues, including the possible abolition of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal (ABT), the abolition or amendment of ownership levels, the relaxation of foreign ownership rules and the possibility of allowing self-regulation in areas such as the Australian and children's content requirements. That report provoked a flurry of outrage and indignation to the point that the Minister was compelled to write to the Sydney Morning Herald and basically deny the proposition. But what he did not do was to rule out the possibility that this fundamental review that is going on in the back rooms will be canvassing those very matters.

It is a matter of acute concern to the Australian public in the run-up to the election to know precisely what is on the Government's agenda. Is the Government saying, through Mr Willis, that this fundamental review process will simply not canvass issues that might touch on the abolition of the ABT, the abolition of ownership levels, the relaxation of foreign ownership rules and self-regulation in general? Are those matters simply off the agenda altogether or have they been put out in the back room so that they can be dealt with in due course by that review team?

That, I think, is a matter that is very much exercising the minds of people who include Mr Saunderson and who are about to do to Mr Willis what they did to Senator Evans. Senator Evans, at a time when he still had a bit of energy and drive, was quite interested in the concept of deregulation in the telecommunications industry. Senator Evans pursued with some vigour the notions that would have involved substantial deregulation and the exposing of Telecom Australia to competition. Of course, the fatal mistake was that those plans got out. The draft report of the task force which Senator Evans had established got into the public domain, and, as a result, we saw the establishment of the Telecom monopoly protection society, which passed under the name of the Telecom Caucus liaison committee. That proceeded substantially to derail all of Senator Evans's fond hopes for deregulation in this industry. As a result, he was so comprehensively rolled that we now have probably the most protected and sheltered telecommunications environment in the Western world.

That was a tragedy that does not deserve to be repeated, yet that is precisely what seems to be in train now, because Mr Saunderson, no doubt basking in the reflected glory of his Caucus colleagues and about their triumphs and successes over Senator Evans, is on the verge of attempting to repeat the same success. Various newspaper reports have suggested that the Australian Labor Party Caucus has begun to fight moves by the Department to deregulate broadcasting policy. Various articles suggest that backbenchers are furious at reports that the Government may be considering an approach similar to the Opposition's policy. The next meeting of the Caucus committee is expected to insist that a three-member subcommittee be formed to counter the push. There are no prizes for guessing who will be on that subcommittee. It will comprise John Saunderson, Neil O'Keefe and Roger Price, the same triumvirate who were successful in knocking off Senator Evans and any hopes for deregulation under this Government-one of the jewels in the micro-economic reform crown which the Government hoped to be able to parade before the electorate, which was unceremoniously ripped off at the scalp. As a result, we have absolutely no reforms in that area.

It looks as though history is about to repeat itself. The thing which is of most concern is that the Minister will not come clean. On the one hand he is saying that there are no plans to abolish, demolish or fundamentally restructure and deregulate. On the other hand, of course, that does not rule out the possibility that there may well be plans in the not-too-distant future. I think we are entitled to know, in the run-up to the election, whether this Government is going to propose any such thing or whether it is simply off the agenda. We should know whether Caucus, Mr Saunderson and a number of Mr Willis's other like-minded friends, have decided that enough is enough and there will be no further reform this side of the election, or whether there are those who share the concern and frustration of Mr Keating.

It is quite clear from a report in the Sydney Morning Herald only two weeks ago that Mr Keating was very upset at the total lack of progress in this area. One can understand Mr Keating's frustration because he is probably aware of the words of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in the June 1987 election campaign when he promised urgently to reform this nightmarish legislation. Of course 2 1/2 years having gone by, precisely nothing has happened. The proof of that-because Mr Willis, I presume, would deny it and say, `Well, we've had policy reports and reviews and we've considered this and that'-is a press release put out over the Minister's name, but which states that further information can be obtained from Mick Trimmer. I suppose that suggests that it is really Mick Trimmer's press release, but nonetheless it is issued under Mr Willis's name. It begins with this headline: `Hawke Government begins reform of broadcasting laws' and is dated 1 November 1989. If the Minister had bothered to look at the press release that his principal officer was pumping out, he would have realised that that was a horrible concession of failure. To announce, 2 1/2 years later, that the Hawke Government was to begin reform of the broadcasting laws is a damning indictment of all that has taken place over that period.

There have been any number of calls. One would have to say that Mr Saunderson and his crew have beavered away manfully-usually pretty much in the wrong direction, although some of my colleagues on the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure have endeavoured to maintain the pace of deregulation, but Mr Saunderson's propensities are precisely in the opposition direction. As a result, the most that Mr Saunderson has contributed to the debate so far has been comprehensively to bucket the policy review document that appeared in July this year. Mr Saunderson branded it as totally inadequate, defective in many respects and precisely contrary to the deregulation proposals that it purported to embrace.

Mr Saunderson was very critical of the fact that the Chairman of the ABT was a member of that committee of review. I share that concern because the end result, not only in that document but in a second go via the current broadcasting amendment proposals, is a vastly increased set of powers for the ABT. I think that is quite unjustified and certainly has not been rationalised in any way by the Government. All we had in the Minister's second reading speech was a few vacuous words about what long-term changes there will be and how they will be introduced in the first half of next year. We know, and blind Freddy knows, that the Parliament is most unlikely to resume once it rises and that we will not be looking at any more broadcasting reform policies introduced by this Government at all. All the Minister is doing is deferring. That is a tragedy but I hope we will have the opportunity to rectify it in the near future.

Senator Gareth Evans, who is in a position to understand all that has gone on because he presided over this policy of drift for 12 months or more, knows full well that commitments have been given in terms of reforms. He knows the furore that erupted when that article appeared in the Sydney Morning Herald and that there had to be demotions and at least one cosmetic replacement of a certain person. Despite Mrs Kelly pretending that all of these reform items were off the agenda, all Mr Willis said on 3 November was that there are no plans of this order. If there are no plans will there be any plans in the run-up to the election? Is this Government contemplating any further forms of substantial deregulation? If it is not, what is the fundamental review doing? Why is there any need for it? If it is, we are entitled to know what is on the agenda and what is not. I strongly suspect that all these items are very much on the agenda. They have simply been put on the back burner so that the Government can pretend to those in the community who have a vested interest in the regulation that nothing will be touched but back there it is business as usual and that that review committee will continue to contemplate a number of the very necessary deregulatory proposals that have been widely canvassed in the industry.

Unless Senator Gareth Evans and Mr Willis-when he finally gets back and decides to address these issues once more-are prepared to come clean, the Australian public will inevitable assume that what is really going on in the Department is a significant deregulatory approach, one that we on this side of the chamber think is long overdue and one which the Government does not have the intestinal fortitude to embrace prior to the election. The challenge is stark: either the Minister comes clean and explains what is going on in the review process or we will assume that in any event.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose I should be bowled over by the fierceness of that rhetorical onslaught and the formidable character of the dilemma with which Senator Alston has presented me in his concluding words, but I am afraid, for all the rhetorical huff and puff we have had from Senator Alston, I am going to disappoint him. I understand this issue well enough to know how complex and sensitive matters of broadcasting policy are and how extremely difficult technically they are in a context in which the Government is wrestling these days with multiple different modes of transmission, multiple different kinds of subject matter and a legislative apparatus that is manifestly not well equipped to cope with the current technical reality. The dilemma has been stated often enough and there may well be scope for significant changes in the way in which the regulatory arrangements operate to deal with that new reality.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not, however, going to pre-empt in any way the course of the Government's inquiry into these difficult and delicate matters. We acknowledge, and no doubt we will continue to acknowledge, the legitimacy of the Australian content provisions and provisions so far as children's television is concerned. It is difficult to imagine in any conceivable legislative reordering scenario that kind of regulatory structure disappearing. But beyond that it really is a matter for close attention by the Government over whatever time frame is necessary for sensible conclusions to be drawn and communicated to the community and appropriate discussion held. No assumptions should be made at all in any direction about the nature of the Government's preliminary thinking on this matter based on the kinds of anxieties about timetable and so on that Senator Alston has sought to articulate. We have just experienced a bit of an all purpose rave which Senator Alston can turn on and off like a tap for these occasions. It is not one that moves us to respond in any more detail than I have.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could we be given some enlightenment as to whether Caucus is proposing to or has formed the same sort of body that overrode the telecommunications task force? I ask that question because despite the fact that I imagine the Minister's instinctive reaction will be to say that Caucus matters are of no concern to the public, the fact is-and I was amazed that the press did not fasten onto this when it first surfaced last time-that that three-member committee had more power than any Senate committee. It met with departmental officers. It reshaped the whole structure of that task force as Senator Gareth Evans well knows. The task force was very much in favour of removing Telecom's first phone monopoly. It was in favour of allowing a second cellular network licence operator to come into the business and I think there was even a time when it contemplated some serious competition on the basic network. All of that was turned around and Senator Evans had his head metaphorically kicked in by that three-member committee which was able to walk the corridors of the Department and was able to influence Ministers in a way that no public servant could do-certainly in a way that no member of the Parliament would be able to do. I doubt that any other backbencher on the Government side, let alone any frontbencher on our side, would have had any sort of access to the task force deliberations in the way that that three-member committee did.

SPEECH.PARA: If we are going to have that sort of outfit riding side-saddle on broadcasting review policy in this country, it should be pretty clear that it will be calling the shots. We accept that it will be headed by John Saunderson from the Left who is very much in favour of regulations. He has made it clear on a number of occasions that he wants to extend the powers of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. Mr Roger Price, the second member of the Committee, like Mr Saunderson, is a former Telecom Australia employee who is steeped in trade union folklore. He is very much a public sector advocate and very much a regulator. Neil O'Keefe, who is the third member of the committee, is an old trade union advocate. So the three members of the committee are all tarred with the same brush, all have the same view of the world and all were immensely successful in overturning deregulation in that area. Therefore, I suggest to the Minister that the public has a right to know whether the broadcasting policy will be suborned in the same manner that the telecommunications policy was undermined. If newspaper reports are correct, there is a very serious public policy issue at stake. I believe that the community is entitled to know the score. If Caucus has not decided to let them loose on this occasion, maybe a few minds can be put at rest quite simply by telling us, `It ain't so'. I fear the worst. I invite the Minister to inform the Committee as to the current state of play.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Alston will develop a rather perverse view of the world if he bases it upon what he reads in newspaper reports, and highly coloured and breathless reports at that. I make no concessions about the nature of the exercise which was embarked upon in the consultative process in the context of the telecommunications review. I make no concessions to the kind of fantastical description that Senator Alston offered of that particular process at work.
—You will not deny that.
—I am not in the business of confirming or denying anything to do with internal party processes.
—Fantastical, therefore, is a little grotesque.

—It is just a little over the top in terms of the picture Senator Alston paints of a posse riding shotgun around the halls of power and determining the way in which policy is made. There are a number of inputs that determine how policy finally emerges from the governmental process and that particular committee was one of them. I have acknowledged that on the public record and I have acknowledged the very positive contribution it made in helping us get that policy right. Whether any similar exercise is contemplated in the case of the broadcasting exercise I do not know, but I do know that it is none of Senator Alston's business what we do in this respect, however much he continues to huff and puff.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I find it extraordinary that Senator Gareth Evans should somehow pretend that this is just mere media speculation. The Australian Financial Review of 8 November reported:

SPEECH.PARA: Despite Mr Hutchinson's removal as head of the broadcasting review team yesterday, Caucus back-benchers are still planning to establish a Caucus liaison committee to monitor-
I suppose that is a euphemism-
the departmental review.
``You can't just blame one individual. There is a need for Caucus to get involved given the tendency and direction of the review,'' left-wing convener, Mr John Saunderson, said yesterday.

It has to be abundantly clear from that that Mr Saunderson is determined to get deeply involved, determined to bring this review process back under control, as he sees it, and very much to influence the course and direction of policy formulation. If that is not a matter of public interest, I do not know what is. If what Senator Evans said is to be taken at face value, then the public is to be treated with contempt because it will not be informed as to who is really pulling the strings, who is going to make the real decisions and where the influences will come from. If they are not matters that we are entitled to know about, then we might as well not even get press releases or be told what Ministers have in mind until we see legislation in the Parliament.

It is a preposterous proposal. It is probably simply an example of Senator Evans being too tired to concentrate on public policy issues which once were very close to his heart and which no doubt he used to take great enjoyment in debating, but now it is all too difficult; we should all go away and let him get on with making the right decisions and introducing legislation when he feels like it. I dare say that he has not drafted a press release for years. Whilst one can understand that sense of overwhelming tiredness, the fact remains that there is a large body of the community which is deeply interested in the policy formulation processes and reads Mr Saunderson saying, `There is a need for Caucus to get involved, given the tendency and direction of the review'. Given Mr Saunderson's antecedents, they are entitled to presume that his involvement will not be benign as far as deregulation is concerned. I therefore invite the Minister to tell us why it is that the public is not entitled to know whether that committee has in fact been established.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have nothing to add.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been listening with some interest to the debate going on between my colleague Senator Alston and the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans), if I can call it a debate when it has been so one-sided. We have listened tonight, in the latter part of the discussion on the Department of Transport and Communications appropriations, to a series of quite reasoned comments put forward by my colleague Senator Alston and a series of almost discourteous replies from the Minister, in the sense that he has been simply brushing off the points made from this side of the chamber in a manner which does a great deal of credit, I suppose, to his arrogance but nothing whatsoever to his parliamentary performance.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to extend the debate a little. Senator Alston was particularly focusing upon the shambles in the communications area of the portfolio of the Minister for Transport and Communications, Mr Willis, whom Senator Evans represents in this place. The truth is that the communications area is not the only element of shambles in that portfolio. The whole portfolio is one great shambles. Without wishing to be unduly personal to the Minister who is responsible for the shambles, I have to say that that is no great surprise to anybody with any knowledge of the Minister's performance as a Minister. When the Minister in question held the portfolio of industrial relations, that was also a shambles. It still is in many respects, but at least we have some better idea of what is going on there today than we did at that time.

Other areas that the Minister in question is responsible for and which are included in the votes before us are such areas as the waterfront and the Australian shipping industry-for example, the vote for the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority and the vote for the Shipping Industry Reform Authority. I think one other area referred to before I came into the chamber tonight was the air transport industry, another area for which the Minister is responsible, except that he had the carriage of that particular matter taken out of his hands at the outset by none other than the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). In other words, we have got a total record of failure in this whole portfolio area on the part of Mr Willis.

The Minister has to be reminded that earlier this year we had a very good report, although rather long in its preparation, from the Inter-State Commission on the Australian waterfront. When that report was brought down-I think it was about three years in the preparation, with an earlier preliminary report-we first of all got a statement from the Minister saying that he needed three further months to have a look at the recommendations, and then he would consider it and let us know what he thought about it. He exceeded his own initially set time, but we did eventually get a view put down by the Minister. But what did we get? We got a decision to raid the pockets of the Australian taxpayers to the extent of $155m over the course of this and the next two years in order to pay golden handshakes to 3,000 waterside workers, most of whom I think were members of the Waterside Workers Federation, averaging $100,000 per person. I almost said `per man'; I think they are all men who are being asked to retire. This payment is by way of saying thank you to them for retiring when in fact most of them have been retired all their lives, with working weeks of 25 hours or less and on wages or salaries very much higher than the average for the work force and performing in most cases relatively unskilled work. These people are going to be paid, at the taxpayers' expense, on average about $100,000 per person for being good enough to retire and get off the waterfront.

I would have thought that, given the record of service that these people have given to the Australian economy over the course of their lives on the waterfront, one ought to have been asking whether they were prepared to give a bit of it back rather than asking for another $155m from the taxpayers of this country for doing the decent thing and getting out of it.

This is the great contribution that Minister Willis has made, on the basis of the Inter-State Commission report, to the future of this country. In doing so, the Minister has ignored most of the other seminal recommendations in the report, in particular the quite crucial recommendation that the future of the waterfront will be totally clouded until there is an enterprise system of labour operating there instead of one which is actually controlled by the single major trade union on the waterfront, the Waterside Workers Federation. But no, the first loyalty of Mr Willis, who I remind the Minister was himself the advocate for the Australian Council of Trade Unions for many years before what was then called the Commonwealth Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and who in an earlier sense was the acolyte to the present Prime Minister, is not to the people of Australia, not to good government, but to the trade union movement, and always has been.

If one is looking for a consistent thread to explain the appalling performance of the Minister in the execution of his ministerial duties throughout the whole of his portfolio-not just the waterfront, which I have been talking about-one can look at that trade union affiliation, because every time the Minister approaches a policy decision in any area of his portfolio, first of all he asks the relevant trade union what it wants him to do.

Telecom Australia is in a shambles. I am sure that Senator Alston could spend a lot of time talking about that. Perhaps he will do so at a later point. Telecom is in a shambles because it is run by the Australian Telecommunications Employees Association and because when Mr Willis wants to know which policy should be implemented he asks the head of that union. He does not ask the consumers of this country or pay attention to lowering business costs in this country, for example, thereby rendering Australia a more competitive economy, which other Ministers spend their time prating about, as the Treasurer (Mr Keating) did recently in Tokyo. He went there to tell our Japanese creditors that things are not as bad as they look and that if only they will be patient with the Government for a few months longer until the election is out of the way everything will be fine. The fact is that the Minister in charge of the transport and communications portfolio has been a total failure. He was also a failure in the industrial relations portfolio, but that is nothing compared with his performance after he was shifted-I think after the last election-to his present portfolio.

TALK.START.PARA: —He has been a disaster since day one.

—I would be more charitable. Senator Short says that he has been a disaster since day one. I would agree, but he has been a total disaster in his present portfolio. The Government will have to consider whether it is good enough for Mr Willis to go on inhabiting this portfolio because the damage he is doing to Australia is tremendous. Perhaps I should not complain about the fact that he is doing a fair bit of damage to the Government in the process. As Senator Alston said a moment ago, recently he took a fortnight off to go overseas at a time when one or two things were happening back here. For instance, the television industry is falling on its face.
—Rome burning.
—That is right. Yet the Minister was fiddling around in the capitals of Europe or wherever he was.

SPEECH.PARA: I have mentioned the Minister's performance in the waterfront area, but let us look at his performance in the coastal shipping area. We have a disgraceful situation, as everybody knows, in that it is hopeless getting anything transported around the coast of Australia on Australian ships as far as cost is concerned. This is equally applicable to the trans-Tasman shipping trades. If one wants to send a car from Sydney to Auckland, I am told that it is cheaper to send it via Tokyo on Japanese ships. It is cheaper to send it from Sydney to Tokyo and then from Tokyo to Auckland. That is because, once again, the Seamens Union of Australia and one or two other unions in the maritime area-but mainly the Seamens Union-are in charge of the trans-Tasman shipping trades. What has our Minister for Transport and Communications done about that?

We have a closer economic relations agreement with New Zealand which is supposed to be all about integrating the two economies. I have been a strong supporter of this ever since it began, when I was in the Public Service. Doug Anthony was the chief catalyst for the agreement and it was probably one of his proudest achievements, or will prove to have been when the history books are written. While we have been pulling down tariffs, getting rid of quota restrictions and other forms of restraint on trade between the two countries, we have an enormous barrier of transport costs between the two countries imposed by a totally unelected body-a trade union-which Mr Willis is simply incapable of dealing with or even beginning to address because it is not in him to do so. I ask Senator Evans whether he can hold out any hope to the people of this country that the man who is presently in charge of the portfolio which is under discussion now in this Committee might be shifted out of it in order to allow, even in the dying days of this Government, some rather more competent Minister to begin to address some of the problems which the Minister is leaving unaddressed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Having just looked at the second reading speech by the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis) to the Broadcasting Amendment Bill, I cannot resist the temptation to point out what the Minister, I think quite unwittingly, has allowed to be put out in his name. Clearly, it embraces very far reaching policy proposals for deregulation. I suspect that the Minister's total ineptitude is the reason he allowed all this to go through to the keeper. For example, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Present arrangements require the Minister and the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal to be heavily involved in judgments about when a service area needs or can support new commercial services. We need to develop arrangements that provide greater scope for broadcasters to take initiatives and carry them forward on their own responsibility . . . We also need to examine whether community needs are better recognised and met by the integration of planning and licensing arrangements under the umbrella of an independent authority.
In other words, moving well away from the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. He went on to say:

. . . the regulation of programming standards needs to be examined to ensure that quality is maintained . . . It is the Government's responsibility to safeguard the public interest, but this can be achieved by creating the right regulatory environment for industry to provide services of an acceptable standard. The question of whether standards need to be examined by statutory regulation or self-regulation needs to be looked at.

So quite clearly the agenda of the fundamental review is all about deregulation. Yet the Minister, dithering as he is, has the hide to pretend that somehow none of those matters are being addressed. There might have been a bit of shuffling and verbal legerdemain but the fact remains that that review is still ongoing. It will undoubtedly address these issues and provide advice to the Minister along those lines, unless he simply says that he does not want it. I can understand why he would say that. Clearly, the last thing that he wants to do, given his total history of captivity to the trade union movement, is to propose anything that might smack of deregulation. Indeed the only exception to the general rule of kowtowing to the Left side of politics and all those arch regulators was when Mr Willis had the temerity to stick his hand up and support the possible privatisation of the airlines. Honourable senators will recall that he did that only because he was toadying to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), who had tried to float the issue a short time earlier. They both got their heads kicked in and have gone back into the burrows. Therefore we will not hear of privatisation again, although it is a critical ingredient of micro-economic reform.

What we have is a Minister who has acknowledged quite explicitly, by his own statement of 1 November, that he is beginning the reform process 2 1/2 years down the track. It ought to be remembered that in the interim not only did the Prime Minister, some 2 1/2 years ago, make that gratuitous promise to reform urgently this nightmarish legislation but also the Minister for Transport and Communications, Mr Willis, reiterated that sort of promise on a number of occasions. It got to the point where even the Secretary to the Department of Transport and Communications told a seminar in Melbourne that the Broadcasting Act was unwieldy and unworkable. They were his expressions. Subsequently the same Secretary, Mr Evans, wrote a letter to the Canberra Times. I would be interested in Senator Stone's view of this because it strikes me as being quite unprecedented. The Secretary to the Department wrote a letter in which he branded the present Broadcasting Act as a regulatory framework which is excessive and characterised by too many players, overlapping functions and a raft of outdated and unnecessary rules and requirements. He went on to state that if the legislation is fundamentally deficient there are limits to what can be achieved by continually tinkering with it.

That strikes me as being wholly out of court unless authorised by the Minister. One therefore is entitled to assume that this pusillanimous presider over the Department, or the ministerial component of it, was prepared to allow others to get out there and talk about fundamental reform and deregulation but has not had the courage to stand up and embrace it himself. So we have had the Secretary having to be the advance guard. Those in the Department who have been on the review team have also had to carry the burden but this Minister has simply wrung his hands, gone on Face to Face and announced that there will be a fundamental review with the aim of creating a more freewheeling and far less legalistic framework. That is about as far as he has gone.

In introducing the current amendments he has proposed a whole series of utterly irrelevant and unnecessary amendments that simply heighten the complexity and uncertainty that already attaches to the Broadcasting Act. It is a travesty of reform and a disgrace in the circumstances because the industry is crying out for a whole range of new initiatives, a whole dismantling of that structure of regulation which is overbearing the industry, which is making life a nightmare for everyone but the lawyers-and even those, I think, must have second thoughts because none of them can be absolutely sure they are right. No doubt those who advised the Minister that all of these amendments were constitutional have certainly got egg on their faces now that Sir Maurice Byers has thrown a very heavy dead cat into the ring in the shape of his opinion which makes it clear that very many of these sections are quite unconstitutional; that, at their face value, they plainly go too far and will need to be read down.

That is a disaster. We are faced with a dog's breakfast and the Minister, when he gets back into the country and if and when he addresses himself to the issue, should have the courage to say, `Enough is enough. We have gone too far. We ought to call a halt to all of this, put it back into the melting pot and let the fundamental review pass judgment on whether these sorts of amendments are going to contribute one iota to the need for deregulation, for less regulation and for substantive reform in the area'. Instead we have simply had a Minister who is not prepared even to brief the press on what is meant by the very tortuous and complex amendments; and was not prepared to have a press conference, which again was quite unprecedented; and who was prepared only to write a letter to the editor and somehow pretend that he was denying what was going on, that the Deputy Secretary was somehow not saying what he was reported to have said and that he, Mr Willis, was going to pretend that somehow all of this was off the agenda.

This is a charade. It is an insult to the intelligence of the Australian public. It certainly does not fool the journalists who have been writing about the subject. They know that broadcasting policy is in turmoil, that the Minister has left it in tatters, that nothing will happen under the present incumbent. Senator Stone quite rightly echoed a press release of mine some weeks ago in which I said that the only possible hope for meaningful reform was to start again with a new Minister, but one can understand the exigencies of politics close to an election--

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought it was one of my original thoughts.

—Indeed. I suppose when something is so fundamentally obvious it is not surprising that great minds will come from different areas and arrive at the same conclusion. We will be faced with the political expediency of the Prime Minister, who is not interested in reform, despite his own election promise so easily given, but rather in protecting the hides of those who are incompetent and those who have simply failed comprehensively to come to grips with what was involved. Senator Gareth Evans does not escape responsibility. He was the responsible Minister for some 12 months or more. But I would say, most charitably, that he was a victim of this unworkable mega-department structure. Perhaps because of his amazing capacity, if not to stay awake all the time then at least to throw a bit of energy into one particular area at a time, he was actually prepared to tackle some of the issues in telecommunications. I am sorry to disturb him, but how can we possibly expect even someone of Senator Evans's relative competence to address a whole clutch of separate issues, let alone someone with the total lack of competence of Mr Willis. Mr Willis is supposed to be solving the non-existent pilots dispute; he is supposed to be doing something about waterfront reform and fixing up government business enterprises; and he is supposed to be undertaking reform of the Broadcasting Act. In fact, he is doing nothing about any of those things. That is the tragedy in this area.
—Coastal shipping, among others.

—The list goes on but we might as well not have a list at all because nothing will happen with any of it. Whilst it is a screaming indictment of the particular Minister, it is also a reflection on those who were responsible for cobbling together such an unworkable and non-synergistic combination. One of the things that we will do in government is separate transport from communications immediately to allow some of the urgent reforms to get under way. We will start tackling some of these very real problems which the Government simply is not interested in any more.
—We will have somebody competent in charge.

—Even with the very limited pack that is available, I would have thought that a shuffling could only throw up a better card than the one we have got at the moment. The tragedy is that we will be exposed to yet another meaningless debate about a whole raft of amendments to the Broadcasting Act which can only have as their ultimate effect complicating the issue even more. They will not make a skerrick of difference to Bond. They will certainly not make any difference to Skase. The proof of the pudding there is in the remarks that Mr Willis made to Laurie Oakes last month. He was asked whether the proposed amendments would cover a situation where a television proprietor goes broke, or where a network goes into receivership or liquidation. Mr Willis said that that situation is currently covered by current powers. Even the current crisis has flowed directly from the Government's decision to restructure the cross-media ownership rules and open up the floodgates. We now know the catastrophes that are besetting metropolitan commercial television operators and regional network operators-those who have been silly enough to pay fantastic prices for commercial radio licences. I suppose that the only satisfaction we have in all this is that the top bid for an FM licence in Melbourne was the $31m bid by the Australian Labor Party or its surrogate. Bond, of course, weighed in for only $22m, and he probably will not be delivering on that-he will just forfeit his deposit. The third highest bid was $10m. That was in a different climate altogether. At least there will be the satisfaction that the Labor Party will have to cough up its $31m when the real price is probably something like $5m to $10m at most. Perhaps that is not a reflection on the Minister. I doubt whether he was in attendance at that particular administrative committee meeting that decided, as did the media proprietors, that this looked like something too good to refuse.

SPEECH.PARA: So we have a shambles. We have a Minister who is not prepared to do anything about it. It is just a matter of regret that Senator Evans is too tired to try to bring any influence to bear on this situation. I suppose he is just going to limp through to the election and pretend that somehow he is not responsible any more. That is a tragedy for Australia. All I can ask is that he have a word with Mr Willis to see whether he will withdraw the amendments so that at least we can get on with some fundamental reforms rather than pretend that somehow they are not happening up front when we all know that they are happening out the back.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me begin by saying that whilst I could do with a couple of weeks lying in the sun, I do not think I need three years lying in the sun or that Australia would benefit were that fate to be visited upon either me or any of the other Ministers in this Government. I can assure Senator Alston also that flattery will get him absolutely nowhere in terms of the way in which he approached his attempt at comparative injustice in his treatment of our ministerial performance in this very difficult portfolio area. It is a big, sprawling and difficult portfolio, but it is not an unmanageable one, and the formidable combination of Ralph Willis, Bob Brown and Ros Kelly is an ample demonstration of the formidable intellectual and other resources that this Government brings to bear on the resolution of these problems.

SPEECH.PARA: I would not wish my relative brevity to be taken in any way as a willingness to accede to any of the things either Senator Alston or Senator Stone, in his even more vulgarly, rhetorically excessive fashion, said about my ministerial colleague. He has done a first class job in the area of micro-economic reform. On the waterfront, in shipping productivity, massive gains have been realised or are in prospect at the moment as the result of the Commission reports and their implementation. We are talking about 30 per cent productivity gains over a very short period on the waterfront. We are talking about manning levels on shipping under Australian flags being very much up to the highest standards of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development within a three-year period. We are talking about thoroughly competitive rates being applicable in those particular environments. More work remains to be done particularly in areas such as port administration, some aspects of tug boat administration and things of that kind. We acknowledge that and we will continue to keep the focus on those areas because we acknowledge their significance in terms of the overall competitiveness and effectiveness of Australian industry. To suggest that these problems have been mismanaged or are beyond the capacity of this very formidable ministerial team to deal with effectively is simply vulgar, rhetorical, political excess of a kind that regrettably becomes all too familiar around this time and part of the electoral cycle.

It is a rather sad and dispirited Opposition one confronts when we find it deriving its primary ammunition from quoting each other's press releases in the Senate. I would have thought that Senator Alston could do a little better than that. However, I do not want to be taken as encouraging him to do so. I think that sufficient points have been put on the table to make clear the general gist of what is being said.

I turn now to the broadcasting review process. The need for immediate holding amendments to the legislation has been made very apparent by the outcome of recent court proceedings. Some of the penalties in the areas of particular breach are so far-reaching and draconian as to be difficult of practical administration without bringing down potentially the whole structure that we are seeking to keep fundamentally in place. That is why it has become apparent that within the present Australian Broadcasting Tribunal situation, some more flexible sanctions need to be able to be applied, and that is essentially the rationale for the legislation that is coming before us. This is not the appropriate time, nor is it within Standing Orders, to debate the pros and cons of the particular piece of legislation. That is something we can do when that legislation is actually before us. In my earlier reply I said as much as I could about the larger broadcasting review progress that is under way. It is not a matter of putting off until a less volatile period something that is too difficult; it is a matter of wrestling as best the Government and its advisers can with some intrinsically different subject areas and producing viable conclusions as soon as we possibly can. That is what is happening and, in the meantime, it is necessary to put some sort of holding operations together in the way that I have described.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall be brief at this late hour of the night but I should like to continue with a few points raised by Senator Stone on the lack of performance by the triumvirate of Ministers in the other place. It is no wonder that there has been a spate of accidents involving heavy road vehicles in New South Wales and Victoria and a few other places in Australia during the last few months. Of course, quite a few factors contributed to those accidents. Probably the most serious is the state of the roads, especially in New South Wales.
—Senator Walsh says our roads have never been better.
—That is the road out to his property.

—He said it there but maybe he was thinking about the strip of bitumen that runs out to his property. Senator Stone would know the district. I spent three days travelling on country roads in New South Wales when I was locked up in this State by the airline pilots strike and could not get home on a long weekend. The state of the roads is unbelievable. That is because of the lack of road funding for the last four years. It is a well known fact that road funding dropped 40 per cent in real terms in that time. That is one of the reasons. Another good reason is that the truck drivers have had to drive faster and work longer hours because any vehicle three years old would have been financed back in the days when the average overdraft rate was 15 to 17 per cent whereas it has now moved up to 21 to 25 per cent. This results in drivers being more tired and this tends to cause accidents. The third reason is the increased use of roads because of the lack of performance by coastal shipping and by rail.

SPEECH.PARA: Last Friday, in Perth, I attended an Australian Institution of Engineers seminar, which was open to the public. The road engineers, the representatives of road transport and others were at loggerheads and were blaming each other for the problem. One of the points I made was that all modes of transport should be complementing rather than competing with each other. But, in the last few years, road transport has come very much to the fore because of the lack of performance by rail transport. There is no way in the world that trucks should be able to operate profitably from Sydney to Perth, Melbourne, Brisbane or anywhere else in competition with rail, especially where there is standard gauge rail. In fact, road transport is competing and is competing successfully. Goods should be carried, especially across the Nullarbor, by the use of containerisation and fast rail. However, rail transport is shackled by social costs which should be isolated and handed over to the Social Security portfolio to make sure that what rail is charging is truly reflective of costs. That would take a lot of trucks off the road.

Much the same applies to coastal shipping because of lack of competition. Coastal shipping still has a big part to play in the future of Australian transport, but it is doing less and less. The north-west of Western Australia used to have a good shipping system but it has almost disappeared. As Senator Stone pointed out, it is cheaper to send goods to New Zealand via Singapore or Japan than to send them direct. Coastal shipping should be put onto a more competitive basis and the waterfront would need to be cleaned up before that problem could be overcome, because ships have to be loaded and unloaded. The Government has allocated $650m to restructure the waterfront without obtaining a real restructure and probably another $650m will be needed in a few years time if things go the way some people think. If we get shipping and rail modes of transport running as they should, trucks would still be able to do the shorter hauls very well. With fewer of them on the road, we would not need so much funding for roads. That is the only chance we have of getting the roads back in good condition. I do not see how the roads I saw in northern Victoria and especially in New South Wales can be restored to a satisfactory condition without a massive increase in funding. In addition to increasing funding, we must cut down the number of heavy vehicles on the roads.

I venture to give the Ministers whom I mentioned before a bit of advice on how to reduce the number of road accidents. Frequently in the last few weeks, the fitting of heavy vehicles with speed limiters has been mentioned. Any licensed heavy vehicle above a certain category should be fitted with a tachograph. The trucking industry has not welcomed that suggestion too much. It says that the fitting of such devices would not add to safety. However, if used properly tachographs would be safety devices. In Europe tachographs are compulsory. It is also compulsory to keep the record from the tachographs for six months. An inspection can be made and a fine imposed any time in the six months. The industry has said that because we could not know where the vehicle was, we would not know whether it had been speeding. However, if the tachograph showed that it had travelled at a speed in excess of 100 kilometres an hour it would mean that the speed limit had been broken anywhere in Australia. That would be one way to go about the problem.

Speed limiters can certainly be fitted to heavy prime movers. I recommend such a course for already licensed vehicles. In future, however, a certain date should be selected by which no new heavy vehicle would be licensed if it could travel at speeds in excess of 100 kilometres an hour. That would be the way to go about it because a speed limiter can be interfered with. Any electronic gadget can be interfered with; for example, phones can be tapped. Therefore, speed limiters can quite easily be tampered with. If a vehicle were restricted to travel at a maximum of 100 kilometres an hour, the driver would be unable to exceed the speed limit. Everything I have said about heavy road vehicles applies equally to heavy passenger buses, especially interstate passenger buses, which, it is known, are driven at excessive speeds as much as any other heavy vehicles. I paced one last weekend doing 140 kilometres, at least. I know that I was speeding, but I had to try it out to make sure that I knew at what speed the bus was travelling.

Another very important point relates to the drivers of heavy vehicles. Governments should have the courage to make the offence of driving a heavy vehicle under the influence of alcohol a gaolable offence because there is nothing more lethal than a heavy vehicle being driven by somebody under the influence. I know that a certain amount of drinking and driving goes on, especially at night. The same would apply to drugs. Gaol would certainly be a great deterrent for those who are caught, as well as for those who are not. I would like the previously mentioned Ministers to think about these points with respect to trying to reduce the road carnage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —During consideration of Appropriation Bill (No. 1), I want to talk about the situation with respect to the pilots dispute-if I dare use the word `dispute' because according to our Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) we do not have a dispute.
—It is just that no planes are running.
—That is the case. Any estimate that has been given from any source of the proportion of actual capacity that is available is an absolute shibboleth of the truth.
—Senator Evans said it was a lingering problem. Is it still lingering?

—If it lingers any longer-and it probably will, given the performance of the Government and its mates in trying to handle the situation-we will not have an airlines system at all. More significantly, we will not have many other industries and companies either.

SPEECH.PARA: At a time when the pilots have been told that their initial claim is pure greed-I think the Prime Minister and others described it as obscene-and in the absence of any element of productivity in the arrangements, one has to look in a very jaundiced way at the pilots' initial claim. However, debate on the matter is not as clear-cut by any means as some advocates of the Government and the airlines would suggest. At a time when the pilots have been told that their claim is pure greed, it would be reasonable to assume that the executives of the airlines themselves would be fairly modest in the satisfaction of their own financial wants.

TALK.START.PARA: —You would also expect them to know something about how many pilots they employ.

—One would also expect them to know how many pilots they have, how many they need, and how many will be required in the future. In my view, there has been a quite appalling lack of apparent knowledge by some of the senior executives in the industry about the situation confronting them. In relation to the pilots' claim and my expectation, therefore, that the financial requirements and satisfaction of the senior executives of the major airlines would be reasonable, it might be pertinent to look at the financial remuneration of those executives and, in particular, of the chief executive officers.

SPEECH.PARA: The situation in relation to Australian Airlines Ltd is fairly well known and fairly well documented. The Chief Executive of Australian Airlines until recently was on an income, without significant additional benefits, of the order of $120,000 or thereabouts. That figure has now been increased to something like $250,000. That is a significant percentage increase, but by comparison with some executives in other industries it is still not a huge income. I looked at the 1989 annual report of TNT, which is Ansett Airlines of Australia's parent company in the sense that it owns 50 per cent of Ansett. I thought that it would be interesting to compare the figures for remuneration of directors and executives shown in the TNT 1989 annual report with that in the 1988 annual report to see what happened over the intervening 12 months because the latter part of the 12 months covers the period of the pilots dispute. The TNT report is traditionally published in late September or October and relates remuneration figures to a financial year, but is often updated to a little beyond that. The figures that I am about to mention either relate to the period ending 30 June 1988 and 1989 respectively, or to the period closer to the end of September.

It is very easy to do this research, although I have not seen too many other people do it. One has to delve into the notes to the accounts of the company, but it is a revealing and worthwhile exercise. Therefore I thought it might be important to put it into the public record, not just in terms of the intrinsic interest in TNT and its executives alone, but also in relation to some of the comments that have been made in recent days by the Government and some of its acolytes about other leading public figures in the business world.

The Chief Executive Officer of TNT is Sir Peter Abeles and, as I said, TNT owns 50 per cent of Ansett Airlines. Sir Peter is the person who calls the shots on Ansett's policies and actions, as we have seen so clearly in what is now the many weeks of the pilots dispute which, as I said at the outset, both Sir Peter and his puppet, the Prime Minister, deny even exists.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator did contravene standing order 418 and he must withdraw that remark.

—I withdraw it. Sir Peter is described in the 1989 annual report of TNT that has been released in the past month as the Deputy Chairman, Group Managing Director and Chief Executive, as well as the Joint Chairman and Joint Managing Director of Ansett Transport Industries Ltd. According to my reading of the financial accounts and the notes to the accounts of TNT's 1989 annual report, in the course of 1988-89 Sir Peter's remuneration rose from a figure of $4,750,000, in 1987-88-I think at the end of 1988-to a figure 12 months later of $5,350,000.
