On my arithmetic that is an increase in one year alone of $600,000 or three-fifths of a million dollars.
—Is that within the guidelines?

—In percentage terms I have to say that it is not as great as it sounds, in that it is only 12.6 per cent, but I would have thought that 12.6 per cent well exceeds the Government's own guidelines. Certainly, the amount of increase is quite staggering. It is a $600,000 increase in remuneration in a year in which the airlines are accusing the pilots of blatant greed.

SPEECH.PARA: Then I looked at the shareholdings of Sir Peter Abeles in TNT alone and in the course of 1988-89-indeed, on 28 November 1988-there was an allotment of bonus shares. TNT made a one for five bonus offer and Sir Peter, who as at 12 September 1988 owned 4,212,404 shares, as a result of the one for five bonus-which I assume is non-taxable, but that requires clarification-went to a shareholding of 5,054,384 shares, that is an increase of 821,980 shares.

TALK.START.PARA: —Twenty per cent.

—Twenty per cent was the bonus. Today's market price of TNT shares is $2.80 to $2.83. This year it has come down. This year it peaked at a little over $4. Indeed, given the non-dispute that we are involved in at the moment, it is understandable that the shares have fallen. A valuation of those shares at $2.80 would probably be a very conservative valuation. The 821,980 shares that Sir Peter received as a result of that bonus on today's market price are worth $2.3m.

SPEECH.PARA: It is also interesting that the 1989 accounts show that Sir Peter has 19,600 1991 registered options. He did not have any at all 12 months earlier and it does not appear from the TNT accounts outlining the capital changes in the past 12 months that those options came along as a result of the bonus issue, because none of the other directors seemed to increase their options to that degree at all. Of course, he has gone from nil to almost 20,000. Today those 19,600 options are worth something like $1.80 or thereabouts an option.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the point of all this?

—Again, the taxation position of that would be worth clarifying. However, the point that I want to make is that I find a degree of double standards in terms of the pilots dispute; a set of double standards that are really quite sickening. This country is grinding to a halt as a result of the pilots dispute. We have a situation where we have a Government that seems absolutely incapable of bringing sanity or resolution to the problem. We have a situation where it appears very apparent to most Australians that the reason the Government is not able or willing to act sensibly and rationally in this dispute is that it is the puppet of certain leading players in the airlines industry. I say quite unequivocally that Sir Peter Abeles's role in this whole exercise is one that most Australians would have very grave doubts about. Yet, we have a situation where that Chief Executive has gained enormous increases in remuneration and benefits in the last 12 months at a time when the pilots are being told that their situation and demands are ones of pure greed. It is about time that we had a little less of the cant and hypocrisy from not only the Government but also the airlines in terms of the handling of this issue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —If we are talking about cant, hypocrisy, greed and double standards, there is no better place to start than with the Liberal Party's own John Elliott who stands to benefit to the tune of something like $17m as a result of the very deliberate policy which the Opposition has announced and proposes to put in place.
—You know that that was a decision taken 18 months ago.

—Yes, but with implications that are profoundly relevant now, whatever the circumstances of their birth may have been. I do not want to go off on any kind of a tangent in this debate. Senator Short has exercised that prerogative with a long-winded account of the share structures and the managing salary structures of TNT Ltd as he understands them, or as he tries to generate speculation about them. We all know that leading businessmen in this country are very well rewarded indeed for the executive, managerial roles they perform and we all know that there are increasing disparities between the way in which those rewards are in fact enjoyed, with lots of other senior people, particularly in the public sector, not getting anything like the remuneration that arguably they deserve for similar inputs and for work of similar social and national relevance. But that is an issue which simply does not bear upon the merits of the pilots dispute and the matters at issue in that dispute, and Senator Short ought to know that.
—Dispute? What dispute? There is not a dispute.

—There was a dispute to start with. Technically, it has ceased to be a dispute. Nobody doubted at the outset that there was a dispute. That dispute technically ceased to exist when those pilots withdrew their services. That remains the case. As I said in this place the other day, there continues to be the remnants of a problem that arose from that initial dispute.

SPEECH.PARA: The situation, as I have described it, is very different indeed, particularly when one looks at the claims of the pilots, which, because of their flow-on potential, were simply absolutely beyond the capacity not only of the industry to bear but also of the whole community to bear. Every time that Opposition spokesmen get up and huff and puff and twist and turn, and generally perform verbal pyrotechnics and put up puffs of diversionary smoke of the kind that Senator Short has offered tonight, they ignore the fundamental problem which it is. If the Government had not taken strong and resolute action of the kind that it has in this instance, this country would have a wage break-out-a wage explosion-which would make its present economic difficulties absolutely fade into insignificance. No other responsible course of action was available to the Government. The Government made that decision entirely on its own judgment of the implications.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course the Government had other options.

—I say to the honourable senator that we are nobody's puppet, let alone Sir Peter Abeles'. The exact same decisions were taken, and the implications were exactly the same, for Australian Airlines Ltd. They were taken not with the particular immediate interests of the airlines in mind at all, but the larger interests of the Australian economy. That has been the position from day one of this whole affair. It remains the position today and, because the stakes are just as high now as they were at the outset of the whole affair, it remains necessary for the Government to hang in behind the position that it has taken.

SPEECH.PARA: All the nonsense that has been spoken by Senator Short tonight, just like all the other nonsense that has been espoused by him and other Opposition spokesmen over recent weeks and months, has not contributed to the national interest one iota; it is yet another example of irresponsible contribution to public debate. It is irresponsible in policy terms, and it is tinged with irresponsibility in the allegations that are made against individuals, which have so characterised the Opposition's performance and which will guarantee that it remains in Opposition for a long time to come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier today I asked a series of questions and was hopeful of an answer coming forward. I thank the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) for arranging for the answer that I was particularly seeking to be faxed to my office late this afternoon. The questions related to the operations of the Federal Airports Corporation at Darwin Airport, the implications of the airlines dispute on the FAC, and the implications for air traffic control at Darwin.

SPEECH.PARA: I can understand that there has been a six- or seven-week delay in providing these answers. I understand that, at the conclusion of this Committee debate, the Minister will table those answers in the Parliament. However, I appreciate being given advance copies an hour or so ago, because I can now understand why the Government has taken six or seven weeks to provide these answers. I asked the following question:
What cost implications will arise to the FAC as a result of the pilots strike which will impact on charges levied on general aviation and private pilots?
The answer is as follows:
The pilots dispute-
it is acknowledged on the Minister's own fax machine that there is a dispute-

will impact on the FAC's 1989-90 revenue. To offset this reduction in income, the Corporation has taken prudent action to ensure that, where appropriate, operating costs have been reduced and non-essential expenditures deferred.
An admission. My second question asked:

Given the independent financial status of the FAC, what action is required by the FAC to implement the Prime Minister's direction that airport landing charges are to be waived for the duration of the pilots strike?
Quite a comprehensive answer is given by the Department, through the Minister:

Under the arrangements between the Government and airlines during the airline disruptions which provide for the Government to meet the agreed wages costs of the airlines retaining on their payrolls staff who would otherwise have been stood down, the Federal Airports Corporation is directed from time to time, under section 41 of its legislation, to waive a specified amount of landing charges incurred by a particular airline. Pursuant to section 42 of the legislation, this direction is followed by a payment from the Commonwealth of an equivalent amount to that directed to be waived, being reimbursement of the financial detriment suffered by the Corporation as a result of complying with the direction.

What will be the Budget implications of that particular financial detriment? It is not covered in the Budget at this stage. Very obviously it will come back before us next year in the special appropriations. But no-one is addressing what this financial detriment is that is now being reimbursed to the FAC. My third question relating to this particular aspect asked:
Will the loss of income to the FAC caused by the pilots strike have implications on other areas of the FAC's budget-in particular will the capital works program be altered in any way?
Again, a fascinating answer has been provided:
The FAC has advised that it expects the loss of income to the Corporation caused by the pilots strike-
an acknowledgment that there is a pilots strike in the answer given to me by the Minister-

to be relatively small and will, to a large extent, be met by a tightening of the 1989-90 operating expense budget, particularly in administrative areas. There has also been a small reduction in profit expectations for this year. Apart from this, the loss of income from the strike-
I stress `from the strike'-

will, of itself, have no impact on the Corporation's budget or require any alteration to the capital program. However, the FAC will be reviewing its capital program in the light of any changes to future growth forecasts arising from the effects of the dispute on demand for aviation services.
What a tremendous condemnation of the Government by its own answers on the consequences of the pilots strike, dispute, disruption, whatever. The flow-on is quite remarkable.

I would like also to address the answers that were given to me more specifically with regard to the capital works program for the Darwin Airport. As I mentioned earlier today, this saga has been going on since this Government came to office. In fact, in 1984 the proposals put forward to the Public Works Committee were for a much larger program, they were endorsed by that Committee and were put forward. Of course, while Mr Hawke, the Prime Minister, manned a bulldozer at Darwin Airport for the purpose of an election campaign in 1984, pretty shortly afterwards he got off the bulldozer and for five years nothing has happened. I asked the following question:
Can full details be provided of the Capital Works Program of the FAC including design and construction timetables, proposed funding expenditures, and sources of loan funds?

We then have one of these answers which indicates `Appendix A shows details' and then Appendix A, which comprises some three pages, sets out various capital works approvals and programs and many figures relating to various projects. But the question is not answered, including the question about the design and construction timetables. The answers are not provided; rather, the pat answer is given as follows:

The FAC has advised that design and construction timetables and cash flow estimates will, of course, vary with each individual project and have not been determined for projects not yet committed or included on the current budget.

Once again, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) will perform one of his bulldozer exercises a month or two prior to the next Federal election, just as he did five years ago in 1984. The Prime Minister will undertake one of these bulldozer exercises in relation to the Darwin Airport. What confidence can people have when these sorts of answers are given: `No cash flows.' The answer is very conveniently avoided by using bureaucratic language.
The second question I asked in that regard was as follows:
Can you tell me the timetable for letting contracts and the start time for Darwin Airport and Terminal?
The answer was as follows:
As at 10 November 1989 two preliminary contracts for work at Darwin Airport and terminal had been let and site work-
and I stress the words `site work'-
had already commenced on those contracts.
Very minor expenditure was involved in relation to what was a very minor cosmetic work type of attitude. The answer continues:

Tenders have been called for the major contract for the new terminal and these tenders closed on Wednesday 15 November 1989. Together, these three contracts will comprise over 95 per cent of the total work. It is anticipated that evaluation of tenders for the major contract will be completed early in the new year and that site works-
again, I stress `site works'-
on this contract will commence by end January 1990.

However, the questions relating to cash flows, construction timetables and design timetables are conveniently ignored. So, as we are again caught up in an election campaign, we are not provided with proper and satisfactory answers; rather, they provide a way out for the Government so that it can avoid facing its real and proper responsibility.

The third issue raised by my questioning-and it was seven weeks before a reply was given today-related to the reduction in air traffic control operations in the Northern Territory. The Department has now addressed this issue by finally providing the answer that half the staff in Darwin will be transferred to either Adelaide or Perth. Quite a detailed and comprehensive answer is given which sets out various cost savings, et cetera, but the question is really why it took seven weeks for such an answer to be given when it should have been answered by officers on the day of the Estimates Committee hearing. Instead, the Department has provided strange information about Public Service reduction and change. It will reduce the air traffic control staffing over the next year or two but, at the same time, in answer to the other question, we are told that Darwin Airport will be built at a cost of about $60m or $70m and its activities will be built up. Of course, the Government will be there touting its tourism and construction program, but the Civil Aviation Authority is hauling out its staff and moving them to Adelaide or Perth so that it can organise operations a little differently at a cost saving of about $344,000. I find it hypocritical and a strange coincidence of events that, on the one hand, staff of a major aviation authority will be reduced but, on the other hand, the Government has this grandiose commitment to Darwin Airport. I will believe it when I see it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to raise one matter dealt with by Senator Alston relating to the curious activities in the Department about the future control of television, particularly as it relates to the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. The more that one looks at what is happening here, the more it appears that despite what the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) might want to do for his rich mates, or his once-rich mates, who seem to be involved in this area and with whom he so enthusiastically consorted in better days when bathing in champagne at the America's Cup win and so on, despite those intentions, the left wing--

—Mr Temporary Chairman, I seek a withdrawal of those remarks. The Prime Minister's relationship with `rich mates' is derogatory of the Prime Minister and offensive under Standing Orders. I suggest that the remark be withdrawn.

—I withdraw. I did not realise that the Minister was sensitive about any relationship the Prime Minister may have with Mr Bond, which has been so publicly revealed on television and discussed at such length in the media. I am intrigued by that sensitivity, because it does reveal an extraordinary double standard in that a little while ago the Minister stressed, and used to his political advantage, so he thought, the alleged benefits that the President of the Liberal Party of Australia would receive from a proposed change to the taxation laws which would benefit many tens of thousands of Australian small businessmen who would be the great recipients of that benefit rather than the President of the Liberal Party. The Minister was quite happy to go down that track, but when I mentioned Mr Hawke's highly publicised public association with Mr Bond, for example, the Minister revealed an incredible sensitivity. Let me stress to this chamber that this kind of hypocrisy from this Minister is not acceptable.
—Order! That contravenes standing order 418.

—I withdraw whatever it is that contravenes that standing order. That kind of statement from the Minister reveals a set of double standards-I do not know whether that remark is acceptable, but I hope it is-that sits ill upon his shoulders. The fact is that the Prime Minister has said that the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal is structured in such a way that it needs fixing up. Of course, we have in front of us now the Bond amendments. It has been reported that there has been considerable discussion within the Cabinet. The Sydney Morning Herald reported to that effect via someone who seems to hear quite well what the Treasurer (Mr Keating) seems to be saying in Cabinet. It has been reported that the Prime Minister has been keen to remedy the situation which clearly has affected Bondy. I understand that that appellation relates to Mr Bond and I am led to believe that the Prime Minister has occasionally used it.

SPEECH.PARA: If the Minister suggests that the close mateship that appeared to exist when Mr Hawke had a champagne shower with Bondy did not exist, then I can only wonder about the purpose of such a denial. However, there is no doubt that in this area the Prime Minister has sought to improve the lot of the moguls or, in some instances, ex-moguls who have been involved in Australian television. An attempt was made in Parliament, for example, to increase their capacity to have access into markets. The Prime Minister was keen to support that move and the Government endorsed it, but in recent times-in fact, in 1987-Mr Hawke described the Broadcasting Act as `nightmarish legislation full of meaningless red tape and pettifogging inquiries'.

What interests me is that there was the appointment-and this has been detailed in the media; Senator Alston touched on this matter-of Mr Hutchinson, the Deputy Secretary of Mr Willis's Department, to try to hasten the fixing up of the mess in broadcasting that had clearly developed under Mr Willis's ministry in particular. An article by Tom Burton in the Sydney Morning Herald noted:
In early August, Transport and Communications Minister Ralph Willis went to New Zealand. With him was his departmental secretary, Graham Evans.
He is a former staffer, of course, of Mr Hawke's. The article continued:
Both were there to look at how the New Zealanders were coping with the deregulation of their broadcasting industry.
Willis came away impressed by the Kiwis, but disillusioned over the apparent inability of his department to make any progress on reform of broadcasting regulations.

Mr Hutchinson, the Deputy Secretary-who had acted as the boss of the Overseas Telecommunications Commission after the sacking of the head of the OTC, Mr Maltby-was appointed to take over the task of trying to fix up the mess, to bring about some reform of broadcasting regulation. It was pointed out by Tom Burton that Hutchinson was strongly of the view that there was a need for much stronger market influences in both telecommunications and broadcasting. It is a view that the Opposition holds. In fact, Burton reported:
In the department, they have been openly saying that they are doing the work for the next Liberal Government . . .
Burton also reported:

Hutchinson's deregulation stance is being applauded by the commercial TV networks, whose lobbiests, all exministerial and prime ministerial staffers, have been walking Canberra's corridors, encouraging support for Hutchinson.

Hutchinson is also forming a strong alliance with the key co-ordination departments of Treasury, Finance and Prime Minister and Cabinet. All three put in strong comments in the `Bond' amendments Cabinet submission considered this week-
this article is dated 4 November-
calling for the abolition of the ABT as constructed, and for the repeal of the fit and proper person test.
That was the test that involved difficulties for Mr Bond at that stage. Mr Burton's article continued:
In Cabinet, this line was picked up strongly by Treasurer, Paul Keating, who with other ministers attacked Willis for the delay in bringing forward any meaningful reform.

What is interesting about all of this is that there was clear pressure to go down the quite sensible and practical track of the Opposition's policy on deregulation. This Government has been pinching such large sections of Opposition policy that one would not be surprised to see it pinching more of it. But the intriguing thing is what happened next: Mr Mick Trimmer, Mr Willis's senior personal adviser, substantially rewrote Mr Hutchinson's proposed second reading speech for Mr Willis. He rewrote it at the last minute, I understand, with the result that it was nearly incomprehensible, so Mr Hutchinson then rang up the media to explain what the hacked-about speech really meant. One of the reasons why he did that is that Mr Willis, apparently, has some reticence about discussing matters with the media, which I suppose is appropriate for a Minister who is supposed to be in charge of communications; the Government works in mysterious ways its wonders to perform. As a result, Mr Hutchinson apparently briefed the media quite fulsomely about what the move towards deregulation was all about and what the Minister's speech really meant, when translated into some kind of coherence.

The Australian Labor Party left wing backbencher, Mr John Saunderson, from Victoria, has clearly been seeking to abort this move towards deregulation and the proposals that not only the Prime Minister but also apparently, according to Mr Burton, the Prime Minister's Department, have been supporting in interdepartmental gatherings. Of course, he also sought to abort what Mr Hutchinson was doing. This is quite significant because what is happening in broadcasting under the influence of a left wing Victorian member, Mr Saunderson, is that the left wing is triumphing. People seem to think that this is a government of moderates who simply do what is best for the friends of Mr Hawke. That is simply not so. This Government still has to kowtow to the left wing of the Labor Party on a remarkable number of occasions. This is one of them.

The real power in this area appears to lie with the left wing, which has managed to get Mr Hutchinson sacked and which has managed to put on hold any suggestion that there should be any diminution in the power or, if you like, a restructuring of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. All the brave sounds on deregulation that we were hearing appear to have gone by the wayside, to the extent that Mr Willis has even written a letter to the Sydney Morning Herald denying its earlier stories, in which it quoted Mr Hutchinson. Mr Willis said that there are no plans to abolish the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, to abolish or amend the ownership levels, to relax foreign ownership rules or to allow self-regulation in areas such as the Australian and children's content requirements. While no plans may have yet been presented to the Cabinet, and no plans have yet been presented to the Parliament, it is nonsense to pretend that there are no plans unless Mr Saunderson has succeeded, with his left wing supporters, in removing those plans, which were clearly and readily acknowledged by the media to be in place, from the Government's agenda.

If that has happened, the people of Australia should be aware of the continuing significance and influence of the left wing of the Labor Party in these major matters of control over and, if you like, interference in the marketplace relating to television in Australia. There is no doubt that television in Australia is in a serious mess at the moment. Heaven knows what the future will bring. But the big question of whether there should be maintenance of the sort of control which obviously has not prevented these problems occurring, or whether there should be deregulation, which would allow a genuine marketplace to exist, is a major issue. It is an issue which, as I said, heightens the clear fact shown by the evidence-that the left wing is dominating media policy in Australia at the moment.
Proposed expenditure agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a few matters that concern me. The Australian Audit Office, which is under the control of the Department of Finance, took on notice several questions I asked in the Estimates Committee hearing. To my knowledge I have not received an answer to them. If the officers have some knowledge of the stage of those answers I would be grateful if they could let me know. The reason this is so significant is that it relates to the lack of resources in the Audit Office because of its inability to provide adequate salaries to retain many officers, particularly in the middle range, with auditing skills. I raised this matter at some length with officers of the Audit Office and with Senator Walsh. There is no doubt that matters of serious concern did emerge. For example, Mr Jacobs of the Audit Office said:

SPEECH.PARA: Our essential problem is that we feel our base has got too low in terms of being able to do performance and efficiency audits.

That is its skill base. It has had a very high turnover level; something like 20 per cent. There is no doubt that some measures have been aimed at allowing the Audit Office more flexibility in its employment patterns. The Audit Office says that it is slowing down the trend towards greater problems. In the Senate Estimates Committee hearing I pointed out in regard to the Auditor-General's response to the recommendations of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts:

If it should be decided that the AAO will continue under present arrangements and general funding levels, I believe it must inevitably fall further and further behind, which is in no-one's interest. Does that mean that if this trend continued for much longer you would not even be able to undertake mandatory, regulatory-type tasks?
Mr Jacobs responded:

The trend has been that way. It has been redressed to some extent by the mandate adjustments that we have negotiated with the Department of Finance on a year-to-year basis. The trend has been slowed by that process.

The important point I want to make to the Committee now is that the trend may have been slowed but it is still going on. As there is a greater and greater requirement for fuller and more detailed activity from the Audit Office, the capacity to fulfil the full role of Audit Office functions is being diminished. On page 32 I pointed out:
At page 129 you say that the Priorities Review Committee approved 381,359 regulatory audit task hours and that of these 81 per cent were completed.

In fact, in the latest year that involved a slight increase in the previous period when the achievement rate was 80 per cent. In other words, it was a failure rate of something like 20 per cent. Mr Hay from the Audit Office replied:
One of the reasons why we managed to do slightly more would be taking resources from our performance area and applying them to the financial statement area.

In other words, the only way the Audit Office can achieve even a reasonable rate of completion is by taking staff resources away from other areas where they are supposed to be doing another job which while perhaps of less immediate significance is nonetheless very significant and is a statutory requirement. I raise all these matters because in the Estimates hearing I asked:
At page 126 of the explanatory notes the comment is made:
Despite a significant loss of experienced audit staff and the difficulties in recruiting suitable staff the AAO was able to achieve 71% of the workload planned for the year.
Firstly, that suggests a 29 per cent failure rate in terms of the target. How does that compare with, say, last year and the year before?
Mr Hay from the Audit Office said:
I am sorry, I do not have that information with me. We could take that on notice and get it back to you.

To my knowledge I do not have that information. It seems to me that when there is a 29 per cent failure rate in terms of the workload planned for the year, some pretty good explanation is required. I think some fairly significant action has to be taken. I would be grateful if the Minister could let me know when I could get an answer to that. I also asked about the extent to which the Commonwealth Auditor-General was losing staff to State government auditors who appeared to be providing substantially better salaries and other packages. Mr Jacobs said:
We do have details of people who have gone into State audit offices which we can supply to you. We are losing people to those.
I have not had that information supplied to me, to my knowledge. I would be grateful if that and the other questions I asked could be answered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak tonight about the very important issue of the continued visits of nuclear warships to Australian ports. On Friday, 10 November, Battlegroup Alpha entered Fremantle. Its lead ship was USS Midway, one of the oldest aircraft carriers in the United States naval armoury and, of course, one loaded with nuclear weapons. It is the largest ship ever to tie up alongside the passenger terminal at Fremantle quay; it is unprecedented for an aircraft carrier actually to tie up right alongside in Fremantle. Battlegroup Alpha also included USS Reeves, which went to Stirling naval base. This was one of the ships which had suffered an accident in the previous 10-day period. Other ships went to Bunbury and Geraldton. Between them, Battlegroup Alpha warships carried over 200 nuclear weapons. However, there were no nuclear reactors as part of this battlegroup.

SPEECH.PARA: This visitation of another United States battlegroup is not remarkable, but is very significant at the moment because of a string of accidents that highlight the unsafe record of the United State Navy. In the last three weeks 11 serious accidents have taken place with United States Navy vessels, which prompted the Navy to call for a complete shutdown of operations on 16 November. I shall just run very quickly through the accidents that have occurred to get them on the record. On 29 October, a pilot making his first landing on the aircraft carrier USS Lexington crashed and killed himself and four others. A videotape of the crash will not be made public because it is part of the current internal investigation. On 30 October, an aircraft from the aircraft carrier USS Midway dropped a bomb on the USS Reeves, which I mentioned was part of Battlegroup Alpha, in the Indian Ocean, injuring five sailors. On 30 October, a sailor fell off the aircraft carrier USS Carl Vinson into rough Pacific seas about 998 kilometres north of Wake Island. An air and sea search was commenced but the body of the sailor was not recovered. On 31 October, a wave swept three sailors and 38 missiles off the aircraft carrier USS Dwight D. Eisenhower about 145 kilometres south-east of Cape Hatteras, North Carolina. Two sailors were rescued, one in a serious condition. The search was abandoned for the missing sailor. There are no plans to salvage the missiles due to salt water damage.

On 1 November, a fire on board the naval vessel USS Monongahela in the eastern Atlantic injured nine sailors. Sailors were trying to start a boiler when it caught fire. The blaze disabled the ship. On 13 November, USS Kincaid, a Spruance class destroyer, collided with merchant ship Kota Petani in the Malacca Strait 386 kilometres north-west of Singapore. One Navy crewman was killed in the pre-dawn collision, five Navy crew were injured and fires were started on both vessels. On 14 November, fire broke out on board the amphibious assault ship USS Inchon when it was dry-docked for maintenance work at Norfolk, Virginia. At least 24 people were admitted to hospital, at least one in a serious condition. On 14 November again, two A6 attack bombers from the naval air base at E1 Centro, California, dropped 12 bombs about 300 metres from a camp site, injuring one civilian. The pilots overshot their target by five kilometres and dropped the 120-kilogram bombs, igniting fires over 1.5 hectares of the California desert conservation area.

Accident No. 9 took place on 16 November, when a Navy Reserve pilot flying an A-7E jet crashed into an apartment complex in Smyrna, Georgia, killing two civilians and injuring two others, including the pilot himself. Accident No. 10 took place on 17 November, when a fire aboard the submarine USS Finback broke out in insulation around an engine on the attack submarine, forcing the vessel to cut short sea trials. Accident No. 11 took place on 17 November, when mechanical problems forced a TA-4J training jet to ditch in the Gulf of Mexico south of Pensacola, Florida. The two pilots ejected safely, but presumably the training jet went to the bottom of the ocean.

This was a very serious string of accidents, which resulted in the Chief of Naval Operations at the Pentagon, Admiral C. Trost, and Navy Secretary Lawrence Garrett requiring all US Navy operations to cease within the next 72 hours from 16 November. A 48-hour safety check was ordered. The accidents that caused this unprecedented and very dramatic action on the part of the United States naval command ranged from collisions to fires and accidental bombings, and have taken place on land, in port and at sea. They have involved civilians as well as US Navy personnel. These accidents have been quite serious but there has been no admission of nuclear weapons being involved, in keeping with the United States Navy's tradition of secrecy.

It is known that there are already seven nuclear reactors and 49 nuclear weapons from previous accidents corroding on the ocean floor. I might add that they are not all the responsibility of the United States Navy, but they are the responsibility of nuclear navies in general. They are the collective legacy of the world's nuclear navies. Yet our Government blithely assumes that accidents will not happen here, or so our Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) very clearly said on the ABC's 7.30 Report during the Bicentennial Naval Review. It might well have been called the United States naval review because there were lots of US ships here, in company with French and British nuclear weapons-bearing ships. The Minister said very clearly that accidents will not happen in Australian ports. I do not know how he dares to assume such a God-like role and say that accidents will not happen when three accidents have happened in recent times in Australian ports.

In 1981, at Stirling naval base, USS Pintado was rescued from rocks during a severe storm by tugs of the Seamen's Union of Australia, averting a disaster. The second accident was in 1987 in Brisbane, when USS Texas crashed into the wharf when leaving port. The third accident occurred in 1988 in Cairns when USS Berkeley collided with the pleasure craft Coralita, causing extensive damage to the pleasure craft. I do not know how much more evidence the Government needs before it finds the commitment to prioritise the safety of the Australian people and the Australian environment above the so-called needs of United States Navy personnel. It seems to me to be absolutely extraordinary that the Minister can continue with a blithe absence of interest in the lack of safety of the United States Navy.

I asked a question on this subject today in this chamber. In response Senator Richardson, speaking for the Minister for Defence, although he was also speaking on his own behalf-he was not reading from briefing notes-was very rude and arrogant and showed total Government irresponsibility on this question. In light of this unprecedented shut-down of United States naval operations the Minister for Defence should at least have been interested in the status of Battlegroup Alpha while it was in the port of Fremantle during that 48-hour safety review period. The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories said that he would not even bother to pass my questions on to the Minister for Defence. That is how arrogant his response was.

I think it is absolutely essential for our Defence Minister to know what is going on with United States vessels when they are visiting Australian ports. It was as though he did not know and did not care-and did not want to know, which is even worse. I find that really extraordinary. It is my judgment that the Minister for Defence ought to know whether there was a check of all weaponry, for example, while those ships were in port. That would have included nuclear weaponry being checked while those ships were in port, but of course the Minister chooses not to know. We needed to know what form the safety review check took-whether all United States personnel were called back to their ships from their rest and recreation in the ports of Fremantle, Geraldton and Bunbury to undertake the safety check. It was meant to involve the entire United States Navy and all naval personnel.

I can tell the Senate more than the Minister was prepared to tell the Senate this afternoon in response to that question, because I have been checking up on this, which is more than the Minister bothered to do. Evidently, personnel were not called back. The United States Navy might have had a mutiny on its hands if personnel had been called back from their precious rest and recreation to conduct the safety checks. So what kind of safety check was it? Our Government did not even bother to find out. I think it is also incredible that Senator Richardson fails to understand the importance of this United States naval shutdown and fails to link the environmental aspect of this question to his own portfolio area. He very assiduously seeks the vote of people who are concerned about environmental issues, but he does not seem to have made the connection for himself that this also is an environmental issue. These ships pose an enormous risk to us in light of the kinds of accidents that could take place-I hope they never do-in an Australian port if nuclear weapons or nuclear reactors were involved.

The Minister also needs to know that he is out of line with the majority of the Australian population on this issue, presumably many of those who support his environmental moves which generally are in a good direction. In fact, only 26 per cent of Australians continue to support such visits. That figure comes from a Small and Associates Pty Ltd poll conducted in September this year. So the Minister, who wants to keep the environmentalists on side, is extremely foolish to be such an enthusiastic advocate of nuclear warship visits as he has demonstrated twice in this place by saying that he would be among those queuing up to go and look at the warships that come to visit us.

Of course, the military gawkers will always crowd on board. I wish that the silent majority was not so silent on this issue. I wish that more people would take part in demonstrations, but they were certainly there during the Bicentennial review. For years we have demonstrated against the visits of these warships to Fremantle. We could compare the military gawkers who crowd on board with the Romans who watched the Christians being fed to the lions. That did not make that action any more right than the action of our Government inviting these nuclear weapons-bearing warships into our ports.

There is a very strong conditioning in our community to accept military propaganda. It is extremely effective, but it is also true that millions more people stay at home disgusted by the display of military might. Their opposition to the visits of nuclear-armed vessels coming to our ports is not based just on the environmental risks which they pose and on targeting opportunities for the enemy. By that I mean that whenever these nuclear weapons-bearing ships come into our ports, those ports are targeted by the so-called enemy. However, more importantly, people's opposition to the continued visits of these nuclear warships is that they send a message of welcome to nuclear nations. They give our approval to the dangerous nuclear posturing which the nuclear navies undertake. That is a very important moral question. I do not believe that our Government addresses it seriously.

It is extremely hypocritical of the Government to talk about disarmament and to rejoice in the intermediate-range nuclear forces (INF) treaty and welcome into our ports on board ships and submarines the same weapons that are being dismantled in Europe. The Tomahawk cruise missiles are the direct replacement of the INF weapons which were signed away towards the latter part of 1987 in Europe. It is extremely hypocritical to welcome those weapons into our ports.

The nuclear navies which are not monitored and not subject to any disarmament agenda are increasingly unpopular wherever they go. Wherever the nuclear navies go in the world-not only the United States Navy but also the French, the Soviet, the Chinese and the British navies-they are increasingly unpopular because people see that nuclear weapons at sea are a great risk to the whole of humanity. There are now 16,000 nuclear weapons deployed at sea. Looking at it mathematically, nuclear accidents involving those weapons are inevitable. As I have said, there are already 49 nuclear weapons at the bottom of the ocean corroding away. One day their nuclear payloads will be distributed on the ocean floor as will the nuclear contamination from the seven nuclear reactors already rotting away on the ocean floor-the legacy of nuclear navies. Increasingly, the world's people are calling for a revision of the welcome that has previously been given to nuclear navies.

In these days of glasnost and perestroika and the breaking down of Cold War barriers, which was the subject of an earlier discussion in this chamber today, there is a great opportunity for Australia to rethink its unpopular longstanding invitation to nuclear navies in light of the changing international climate and in light of this unfortunate spate of accidents which has dogged the United States Navy in recent weeks. But no, we now expect another huge battle group, including the USS Enterprise with eight nuclear reactors on board, as well as over 100 nuclear weapons, to come into Australian ports in December.

Once again we will get the popular version presented by the media and silence from the Government. The media will say that the Navy is coming here just for rest and recreation and that it will spend lots of dollars. It was even reported in the Western Australian media last week that we were having a United States Navy-led tourism recovery; that because the pilots dispute has caused such havoc for the tourist industry in this country, we were welcoming the sailors because they would inject much-needed tourist dollars into the country. People do not seem to see past the dollars and cents of this or the flag waving opportunities from the Government point of view. They do not seem to see that an important moral question is involved. We are literally giving harbour to the most destructive weapons known to humanity every time we allow vessels bearing nuclear weapons to come into our harbours. So it is business as usual; business in every sense of the word. Lots of dollars will be made. The usual negative social consequences involved with the visit of a large number of sailors to any port at any time, for whatever reasons, are there to see. We need to look at sexually transmitted diseases much more carefully than we have in the past when such visits have taken place.

The business as usual approach is being adopted despite the 500-page report of a Senate standing committee concerning the accidental release of ionising radiation from the visits of either nuclear-armed or nuclear-powered warships coming into Australian ports and despite the excellent dissenting report by Senator Dunn. Even the limited reforms that were suggested by that committee are being totally ignored by the Government. Those very limited reforms related only to plans on paper. They did not make any difference in substance whatsoever to the risks which Australian ports are subjected to every time a nuclear navy comes into port. The Government did not have the guts to make the hard decisions that need to be made. The Government has not even responded to that committee's report.

The Minister has already been proved wrong in saying that accidents will not happen in Australian ports. As I have pointed out, we have already had three accidents relating to United States naval vessels in Australian ports. I hope that the Minister will not be proved wrong in relation to nuclear weapons accidents in Australian ports. If he is proved wrong it will be too late to count the cost. It will be too late then for any accusations or expressions of sorrow. If a nuclear weapons accident or a nuclear generator accident occurred in an Australian port there would be little that anyone could do about it, notwithstanding the long awaited Senate report. I fervently hope that we never see that day because, if we do, it will be too late to reverse the Government's blind spot on this issue. Much wringing of hands will take place. It will not give anti-nuclear campaigners any satisfaction to say, `We told you so'.

The point is that this is an unnecessary risk. We do not have to take it. We are not obliged to invite these vessels into our ports. Inviting them into our ports is not part of the ANZUS Treaty. It is not part of that written agreement that was signed in 1951. We need to rethink our commitment to that agreement as well and to the unwritten millstones which it ties around our necks. The visits of nuclear warships is one of them.

Now is the time for a rethink. It is an opportunity for the Government to change its policies. My plea is that the Government listen to the wisdom of the people. Remember that I said that only 26 per cent of Australians support the continued visits of these nuclear-armed and nuclear-powered vessels into our ports. The Government should listen to the wisdom of the people who are so often ahead of the Government on these important moral questions. The Government should follow the New Zealand Government's lead to ban the visits of these potentially dangerous and militarily threatening warships into our ports. It is high time we took a very brave decision. I hope that with the changing international climate it will give the Australian Government some impetus to rethink its policy and to change its mind. What we need is an immediate and permanent ban on all visits of nuclear-armed and nuclear-powered warships from Australian ports.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I want to mention the death at the weekend of Mr Jim Bradfield, the Federal member for Barton from 1975 to 1983. His passing was noted when we met earlier today. However, I would like to take this opportunity to outline to the Senate the role that Jim Bradfield played in a very important part of Australian political history. I refer, of course, to the enormous swing to the coalition parties in 1975 and the ending of the extraordinary period of the Whitlam Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Jim Bradfield was one of the people who came in in that election. I was one of them, too. We were called `oncers' by our Australian Labor Party colleagues because they took the view that we would be here for one term only, and we were continually subjected to that jibe in our first term in office. Most of us survived for at least three terms, including Jim Bradfield. He was, if you like, unfortunate in coming in with such a large group of highly competent people. He was a successful businessman and after he left Parliament he also became a successful farmer. He was a thoroughly decent, honourable man with a very sound knowledge of economics and he made excellent contributions to economic debates. He was a member of the treasury committee during the Fraser Government's period in office. Had there not been so many highly skilled people, there is no doubt that Jim Bradfield would in normal circumstances have become a Minister of the Crown. Certainly his talents deserved that reward but there were many people in that group, like Murray Sainsbury and Maurice Neil, QC, who were unable to get what they deserved in politics, which was the reward of becoming a Minister, before unfortunately they were beaten-in Jim's case in the big swing of 1983.

Jim Bradfield regularly attended our `oncers' dinners-which were always held, by the way, as close as possible to 11 November, the day the 1975 change in government initially took place-and was always a very friendly contributor to what were always joyous occasions. At our recent `oncers' dinner we were all very distressed to hear how unwell Jim was, although we were told that he had maintained the enormous spirit and courage that he had shown all through his illness.

Jim Bradfield is the second of our 1975 group to have died. The other was Senator John Knight, who died, as you would remember, Mr President, in office as a senator. I certainly know that all my colleagues who came in in 1975 join with me in regretting the passing of our very good friend Jim Bradfield. Our sympathies go to his wife Jill and to their children, and to other members of Jim's family, with whom he was very close. He was a person whom it can quite properly be said was beloved by his family and admired and respected by his colleagues.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 10.54 p.m.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 25 May 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: Following the passing of the close corporations legislation in the Senate, does the Commissioner of Taxation intend to extend, via his rulings, roll-over relief to close corporations free of capital gains status which is currently available to individuals or partnerships rolling-over to companies.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Section 160ZZN of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936, subject to certain conditions being met, grants capital gains tax rollover relief in respect of assets transferred, by an individual or partnership, to a wholly owned company. The Commissioner of Taxation considers that a close corporation is a company for the purposes of the Income Tax Assessment Act. Consequently, the Commissioner considers that capital gains rollover relief is available under section 160ZZN on the same conditions as apply in respect of assets transferred by individuals or partnerships to other types of companies.

There will, no doubt, be cases where it is desired to convert a ``traditional'' company into a close corporation. Where the requirements of section 24 of the Close Corporations Act have been met, the newly formed close corporation is deemed to be the same legal entity as the former ``traditional'' company. (Section 24 requires, among other things, that the ``traditional'' company not be a holding company, and that all its shares be fully paid up, be of the same value and have the same rights.) The Commissioner has indicated that, where section 24 applies, rollover relief would not be necessary as there would, in those circumstances, be no change in ownership of the relevant assets.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 7 September 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) With reference to articles in the Canberra Times on Monday 29 May 1989 by David Ives which reveal further disturbing aspects of the Department of Defence DESINE Project, was the Minister advised, or was he aware, that the final contract signed with the prime contractor made IBM the sole supplier of computing hardware and software to Defence.
(2) Did the Minister approve the DESINE contract before its signature.
(3) Is such a monopolistic contract usual for the Commonwealth.
(4) Does the Minister believe that the final contract, in fact and in spirit, is consistent with the requirements expressed to the industry in the RFT.
(5) Can the Minister cite examples where there has been such a departure from the RFT for a contract worth up to $500 million in five years.
(6) Is it true that the Department of Administrative Services had not released tender documents to Defence because of unsatisfactory evaluation methodology.
(7) Were Defence personnel given access to the tender documents prior to an evaluation methodology being agreed.
(8) Did the Minister or his Department formally approve an evaluation methodology; if so, was this in a formal document.
(9) When was the document signed, and can a copy be made available to me.
(10) Can the Minister guarantee that all the tenders were fully evaluated and that the short-list of tenderers was not determined before other tenderers were evaluated in detail.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) IBM Australia has not become the sole supplier of computer hardware and software to the Department of Defence. IBM was selected as the Prime Contractor for DESINE after the invitation of public tenders on the basis that it offered the most cost-effective Total Solution. IBM supplies the equipment in conjunction with twenty-one selected subcontractors. In addition to fulfilling computer contracts which were already in existence at the time the DESINE contract was awarded, other companies will be given the opportunity to bid for requirements which are exempt from DESINE, in accordance with the criteria which Defence has made publicly available.

(2) The Minister for Defence consulted the Prime Minister, the Ministers for Finance, Industry, Technology and Commerce and myself concerning the decision to award the contract to IBM Australia Ltd. I was advised by my Department that the selection of IBM Australia Ltd as the successful tenderer would withstand public scrutiny. Officers of my Department followed normal procedures and arranged the contract with advice from the Australian Government Solicitor. These procedures did not require any further approval from me before contract signature.

(3) The contract is consistent with the guidelines contained in the Commonwealth Purchasing Manual, Chapter 13, Section 2, which provides that if the Commonwealth wishes to bind a contractor to fulfil orders placed under a period contract, this may be achieved by guaranteeing that all of its requirements for items covered by the contract will be obtained from that contract.

(4) The RFT sought to establish a prime contractor to supply hardware and software which would be the basis for a standard computing environment. The final contract is consistent with that expressed objective.
(5) The final contract for DESINE is consistent with the Request for Tender.

(6) At the time tenders closed, agreement between my Department and Defence had not been reached on certain aspects of the evaluation methodology. In accordance with normal procedures, the tenders were not released by my Department until the evaluation methodology had been approved.

(7) Defence personnel were given access to the tenders for the purposes of registration and sorting only. It was a condition of providing access to the documents that the Defence officers would not commence a technical evaluation of the tenders. The tender documents remained in the care of officers of my Department until they were formally released.
(8) My Department formally approved the evaluation methodology in the form of a memorandum to Defence.
(9) On 21 August 1987. A copy can be made available to the honourable Senator's Office on a ``commercial-in-confidence'' basis.

(10) I was advised prior to the approval of the shortlisted tenders that all the tenders were evaluated in accordance with the predetermined criteria for shortlisting of the offers. Only those total solutions which were shortlisted (from Digital Equipment Corporation, IBM Australia and Unisys Australia Ltd), were evaluated in detail. All the remaining tenders were assessed as part tenders in the final phase of the evaluation.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support, upon notice, on 7 September 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that the Corby Starlet is the only Australian designed aircraft approved for construction by amateurs; if so, when was this approval given; if not, what other Australian designs have been approved, and when was approval given.
(2) Is it a fact that Australian designers and builders of aircraft for personal or recreational use are obliged to conform to stricter regulations than those in the United States or Britain.

(3) What justification can the Minister provide for the continued existence and application of clauses 3.3 and 3.4 of section 101.28 of the Civil Aviation Orders, which discriminate against Australian aircraft designers and builders.
(4) What steps will the Minister take to remove section 101.28 (clauses 3.3 and 3.4) from the Civil Aviation Orders.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) A person or group of persons may design, build and operate a single place aeroplane for their own use under the provisions of Civil Aviation Order (CAO) 95.10. The only requirement placed upon the designer/builders is that the aircraft must be fitted with occupant restraint. The aeroplane class is restricted by weight limits, but unlicensed persons may fly the aeroplane for recreational purposes.
The Corby Starlet is currently the only Australian designed aeroplane type eligible for a Certificate of Airworthiness under the amateur construction rules of CAO 101.28.
The type was first accepted for construction by amateur builders on 27 September 1972. Issue 2 of the construction package was accepted on 20 June 1980.

(2) For personal or recreational use, the only significant regulatory requirement applicable to Australian CAO 95.10 aeroplanes, beyond the requirements of the United States, is the fitting of the occupant restraint. The Australian weight limitation is more liberal than that of the United States for similar aeroplane classes. The United Kingdom requires compliance with the British Civil Airworthiness Requirements Section S for the class of aircraft similar to the Australian CAO 95.10 types.

Australian amateur built aeroplanes, with a type certificated engine, can be eligible for an unrestricted Certificate of Airworthiness. The aeroplane may then be flown in any mode dependent upon the pilot's qualifications and the fitted communications and navigation systems. An amateur built aeroplane with a none type certificated engine may be restricted from flight over populated areas. The amateur built aeroplanes in the United States and the United Kingdom are not eligible for an unrestricted Certificate of Airworthiness.

Commercially sold recreational aeroplanes, with a maximum take off mass less than 450 kgs, are to comply with the requirements of CAO 101.55 as the result of the adoption of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport Safety Report. These aeroplane types are eligible for Certificates of Type Approval and Certificates of Airworthiness, but are restricted from flight over populated areas unless they are fitted with a type certificated aircraft engine.

Because the Australian amateur built aeroplane, (built to comply with CAO 101.28), may be operated in a more liberal operational environment the airworthiness rules must be appropriate to the operational envelope. The United States imposes operational restrictions upon amateur built aeroplanes but has a more liberal design and construction environment. The United Kingdom has a more restrictive operational environment in that a Certificate of Airworthiness is not issued, but has design and construction rules which parallel the Australian requirements.

(3) The continued justification for the existence of CAO 101.28 paragraphs 3.3 and 3.4 is the requirement for the primacy of safety of civil air operations in Australia. The brief descriptions of the various classes in Part 2 of this question indicate that amateur built aeroplanes are eligible for a wide spectrum of operational freedom.

If amateur built aeroplanes are to be eligible for an unrestricted Certificate of Airworthiness, then the issuing Authority must be sure of the structural integrity of the aeroplane as well as satisfactory handling and performance.

Designs of aeroplanes for amateur construction which originate from overseas must demonstrate a history of safe operation for several examples of the aeroplane type. The drawings and other construction directions are examined for structural integrity and flight trials are conducted to verify handling and performance characteristics.

An Australian, or foreign, design example which has never flown cannot have a safe history of operation and therefore be eligible for a Certificate of Airworthiness under the ``safe history of operation'' requirement.

The opportunity for an Australian design to accumulate a history of operation exists through the application of the CAO 101.31 provisions for developmental flying. A submission for developmental flying has minimal assessment requirements before permission is granted to conduct operations according to an agreed flight test schedule. Assessment of the aeroplane structure is accomplished at the same time as the developmental flying. If the structure and handling are satisfactory the aeroplane may be granted a Certificate of Airworthiness, with or without restrictions, on the basis of only the engine certification status.

The Australian regulatory position for paper designs is neutral, dependent upon the chosen class, and the discrimination, if any, is in the realm of aviation safety for the public and the aeroplane occupants. There is no discrimination against Australian builders who wish to construct an established aeroplane design.

(4) All of the CAOs are under constant review but the programme's priorities are dependent upon the available technical resources. The current priority is directed toward the regular public transport category which exposes the most people to the risks of aviation. The review of the amateur-built category certification requirements will deal with paragraphs 3.3 and 3.4 of CAO 101.28.
I have received representations on alleged discrimination caused by paragraphs 3.3 and 3.4 and have asked the Air Safety Regulatory Review Task Force to specifically examine this issue.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, upon notice, on 7 September 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that persons wishing to build aircraft in Australia in the `amateur-built' category must produce designs in conformity with Civil Aviation Orders (previously Air Navigation Orders) section 101.28.
(2) Is it a fact that clauses 3.3 and 3.4 of section 101.28 impose stringent conditions on Australian aircraft designers and builders, which do not have to be met by equivalent overseas projects.
(3) Is it a fact that over 98 per cent of aircraft built in Australia for personal use are of foreign design.
(4) Is it a fact that the most recent Australian design to go into production (the Corby Starlet) was in 1962.
(5) Does the Minister accept that section 101.28 (clauses 3.3 and 3.4) acts effectively as a tariff on Australian light aircraft design and manufacture.
(6) What steps will the Minister take to remove section 101.28 (clauses 3.3 and 3.4) from the Civil Aviation Orders.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. A person who wishes to commence amateur construction of an aircraft is not required to produce a design. There is a range of designs of aircraft types already accepted and suitable for amateur construction.

(2) The Australian Light Aircraft Industry Study Group Report noted the discriminatory aspect of Air Navigation Order 101.28. However, in practice clauses 3.3 and 3.4 do not impose any conditions upon Australian amateur builders of aircraft to which overseas builders are not obliged to conform.

(3) The Civil Aviation Authority does not keep a complete register of all aircraft built for personal use in Australia. However, the Light Aircraft Industry Study Group Report noted that construction of amateur-built aircraft in Australia began in the early 1950s. Since then approximately 260 aircraft were believed to have been completed. The Report noted a total of 440 ``active'' amateur-built projects in Australia. These projects involved a total of 77 approved Aircraft types, while 22 types were under consideration. Of these 99 types, 80 were of US origin. Only two types, the Corby Starlet and the Paleto Maverick, were of Australian design.

(4) Yes, as far as I'm aware in regard to aircraft falling under the provisions of section 101.28. However information from Jane's All The World's Aircraft 1987-88 indicates the Corby Starlet was first built in 1972. Information from the Department of Transport and Communications also confirms the later date for the Corby Starlet.

(5) No. The Australian Light Aircraft Industry has well over twenty active light aircraft projects and while most are still in the development phase a few have made the transition to production and sales. In some cases early export shipments have been achieved. This can be seen as indicative of some of the strengths of the Australian Light Aircraft Industry which includes:
pockets of design capability and expertise coupled with great enthusiasm;
high levels of innovation and research and development;
a high rate of growth (though care must be taken to ensure that this does not result in an unacceptable degree of fragmentation);
sizeable home market which can be used as a springboard for exports.

(6) I have accepted Recommendation 7 (``the study group notes and supports the House of Representatives Committee on Transport Safety (HORSCOTS) recommendation 17 (a) that the Department of Transport and Communications remove the discriminatory aspect of ANO 101.28. The distinction between aircraft of Australian design and those of overseas design should be withdrawn while ensuring that the Australian requirements are no more complex than those existing for imported aircraft.'') of the Australian Light Aircraft Industry Study Group Report and I wrote to my colleague, the honourable Ros Kelly, Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation, on 24 January 1989, drawing this recommendation to her attention. Her response was ``The Government accepted this HORSCOTS recommendation and this CAO, which deals with amateur-built aircraft, will be reviewed as part of the general review of airworthiness Orders.'' She went on to say that ``discussions are underway with The Sport Aircraft Association of Australia regarding an appropriate level of self-administration of the amateur-built aircraft sport.''.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 28 September 1989:

(4) How many were mothers.
(5) How many were fathers.
