QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 29 September 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What length of lease or terminal space have both Ansett and Australian Airlines been granted from 1 January 1990.
(2) At which Airports have such leases been granted.
(3) Has any decision been made regarding terms and conditions for the granting of leases for new entrants once deregulation takes effect; if so, what are those terms and conditions.
(4) How many new entrants are to be provided for.

(5) If the reply to (3) is no, what steps is the Government taking to ensure that satisfactory arrangements for the leasing of terminal space to potential new entrants to the airline industry will be made quickly and on terms which will not place these new entrants at a severe disadvantage vis-a-vis existing operators.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport and Communications has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Under the terms of the domestic terminal leases, which took effect from 1 January 1988, Ansett and Australian Airlines were granted leases for a 20 year term with provision for an extension of around 10 years subject to certain specified conditions.

These leases supersede the previous agreements which generally gave Ansett and Australian Airlines exclusive rights to their terminals until 1993, well beyond the start of deregulation on 31 October 1990.

The Government recognised that the success of deregulation would depend on the ability of new entrants to gain access to airport facilities. The Government therefore took the initiative, and decided in the absence of other available facilities to renegotiate the leases held by Ansett and Australian Airlines, with a view to allowing other operators access to terminal facilities after deregulation.
Copies of the terminal leases have been made available to potential new entrants on request.
(2) Leases have been agreed with Ansett and Australian Airlines at the following Airports; Sydney, Melbourne, Brisbane, Perth, Adelaide, Hobart, Coolangatta and Launceston.

(3) Yes, under the terms of the terminal leases, Ansett and Australian Airlines are required to provide new entrants with a full range of passenger processing facilities, including access to baggage check-in and handling facilities, passenger assembly areas, aerobridges, where appropriate, and aircraft parking positions.

The leases require Ansett and Australian Airlines to provide facilities at Sydney and Melbourne to handle two passenger aircraft each at any one time. At Adelaide, Perth and Coolangatta, facilities for the handling of one passenger aircraft by both Ansett and Australian Airlines are to be provided. Ansett is required to provide facilities at Launceston to handle one passenger aircraft. At Brisbane, the Federal Airports Corporation (FAC) has alternative accommodation that can be made available to new entrants. At Hobart, new entrants can be accommodated in the international terminal.
Use of facilities by new entrants will be on either a dedicated sub-lease or common use basis, depending upon the needs of new entrants.
The process to allocate terminal facilities to new entrants will commence by 1 January 1990, when Ansett and Australian Airlines must advise the FAC of the facilities that they are to make available.

On 1 February 1990, the Secretary to the Department of Transport and Communications will arrange for public notice to be given of new entrant facilities available at airports and call for applications for their use.
On 1 March 1990, these applications will be opened in the presence of Ansett and Australian Airlines representatives by the Secretary and the facilities will be allocated on a priority order:
Highest Priority-regular interstate public air transport services commencing after 30 October 1990
Second Highest-regular intrastate public air transport services commencing after 30 October 1990
Third Highest-new interstate public air transport services commencing between 1 January 1988 and 1 February 1990
Lowest Priority-passenger charter operations.

If there are more applicants of an equal priority than available space, the determination as to who will have priority will be made by the Minister for Transport and Communications in the public interest.
(4) It is not possible to determine the specific number of new entrants that the terminal leases provide for as the arrangements contain considerable flexibility for new entrants.

The renegotiated terminal leases are designed to provide new entrants with a minimum level of access following deregulation. It is open to the FAC to provide for the longer term needs of new entrants by the FAC constructing additional facilities or allowing new entrants to develop their own.
In this regard, the FAC is discussing with potential new entrants their requirements following deregulation.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 6 October 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Given that the Government has recently introduced a new policy governing the entry of Chinese students to Australia for the purpose of studying English, and that this new policy was introduced to curb an alleged overstay problem among Chinese students, can the Minister explain whether these new restrictions on entry have been formulated on the basis of proved overstay patterns of Chinese, for instance has it been established that Chinese students over 35 years of age have a greater propensity to overstay than do those under 35.
(2) If the new regulations are not based on objective evidence of overstay patterns, can the Minister explain how they were determined.
(3) Would it not be preferable to delay introduction of retrospective regulations until some objective criteria can be established.
(4) Would it not in fact be preferable to improve the efficiency of compliance and deportation procedures.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The new policy governing the entry of applicants wishing to undertake non-formal study courses of less than 12 months duration and ELICOS (English Language Intensive Courses for Overseas Students) has been introduced to curb a real overstay problem. The overstay rate for students from all countries in these programs is 23.3 per cent. (In 1988/89 21,483 persons were issued visas to undertake ELICOS.) By way of contrast, the overstay rate for visitors is 1.8 per cent and over 1.3 million visas were issued in 1988/89 under this program.

The overstay rate at the end of May 1989 for students from the People's Republic of China (PRC) was 40 per cent. Since 1 January 1986, 15,111 PRC students have arrived in Australia and up to the end of May 1989 only 1,685 (or 11.2 per cent) had left Australia.

The Government's new measures were introduced to address the overstay problem as well as the ``pipeline'' of 25,000 applications lodged with the Embassy in Beijing. The ``pipeline'' processing measures are less stringent than the global measures (which will apply to PRC applicants from 1 January 1990) in that ``pipeline'' applicants will be assessed against a lower education level criterion (year 10 compared with year 12 for the global measures) and will not be subject to more extensive immigration bona fides testing (required under the global measures). Immigration bona fides tests are applied to assess the applicant against the stated purpose or reason for wanting to come to Australia and likely compliance with the entry conditions (ie the applicant will leave Australia at the expiry of the entry permit).

The under 35 years of age stipulation is an education rather than immigration criterion. In general terms, it is expected that by age 35 people will have undertaken the education offered by the ELICOS program. There are exceptions to this and the Government has recognised these in framing the measures to apply to the ``pipeline'' processing.
(2) The new measures are based on objective evidence of overstay patterns.
(3) Not applicable. Objective criteria have been established and further delay in implementation would worsen an already intolerable situation.

(4) It is more efficient and considerably less costly to apply immigration checks prior to visa issue. The statistics referred to in (1) above illustrate the efficiency of immigration bona fides testing-the visitor program is subject to immigration bona fides testing, the ELICOS program has not been. Compliance activity in Australia plays a role but it is very expensive. The average cost (excluding court costs) associated with locating and deporting a prohibited non citizen is $9,000.

Part of the new measures introduced to address the student overstay problem is the introduction of an application fee of $130. Monies raised by this fee will offset the cost of location and removal of student overstayers.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 10 October 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) With regard to a report in the Australian of 13 September 1989 headed ``Strict genetic engineering controls demanded'', does this refer to a report of the Law Reform Commission of Victoria, tabled in the Parliament of that State the previous day, which claimed some types of work associated with genetic engineering contained significant or unknown risks.

(2) In view of claims that voluntary notifications of such work are the only current requirement, are any measures contemplated to impose greater controls on genetic experiments, coupled with compulsory notifications to any supervisory body.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) While notification of proposed genetic manipulation work to the Genetic Manipulation Advisory Committee (GMAC), and compliance with their guidelines and advice, is non-statutory, a number of legal constraints apply to this kind of work and sanctions are available for non-compliance with GMAC's advice. These are canvassed in the report of the Law Reform Commission of Victoria referred to in the Senator's question.

Consideration of the adequacy of present controls on innovative genetic manipulation technologies is one of the functions of the Group of Officials on Biotechnology Regulations (GOBR). This group consists of officers from the Departments of Industry, Technology and Commerce, Community Services and Health, Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Primary Industries and Energy, and Administrative Services. GOBR is the responsibility of Senator the Hon. John Button, Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce.

The Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business, the Hon. Barry Jones MP, recently proposed an investigation by the Parliamentary Committees on Environment Recreation and the Arts, Industry Technology and Commerce, and Legal and Constitutional Affairs, of the ethical legal and environmental problems associated with genetic engineering. The question of controls for genetic manipulation will be addressed in the light of advice from these groups.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 10 October 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Minister noted the findings of the Auditor-General's Audit Report No. 11, 1989/90, into the Department of Defence's recruiting practices which suggest annual recruitment target figures have been affected by:
(a) adverse media comment on wastage rates and conditions of service;

(b) level of advertising and travel funding, including the observation that funding is not guaranteed and cut backs in recent years have presented difficulties for the Defence Force Recruiting Branch in achieving its targets; and
(c) difficulty in competing for qualified staff, particularly in officer and technical recruitment.
(2) What measures have been taken or are being contemplated to overcome the difficulties outlined by the report.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The findings of the Auditor-General's Audit Report No. 11, 1989/90, into the Department of Defence's recruiting practices have been noted by the Minister, particularly the first key finding that the Defence Force Recruiting Branch has been effective in substantially achieving annual recruitment targets despite a number of difficulties. The Honourable senator's question quoted three of the difficulties identified in the Auditor-General's Report. The report also noted a decreasing target population, competition with civilian employers, changing recruitment targets which require long lead times for achievement and constraints on recruitment targets.

(2) Not all of the difficulties outlined by the report are capable of being overcome. Recruiting is conducted to meet the personnel requirements of the three Services. Decreasing recruitable age population, competition with civilian employers, changing recruitment targets, constraints on recruitment targets (if a target is not met at a particular time it is difficult to make up the shortfall later because of limits on the number of recruits that can be trained at any one time) and difficulty in competing for qualified staff have to be accepted as part of the recruiting environment. Media comment will always contain both adverse and favourable aspects depending on the viewpoint of the journalist concerned. The need for and the value of advertising is recognised as is the need for adequate travel funds. These areas are accorded an appropriate level of priority for funding within the Department of Defence. In times of economic constraints all areas of operating costs are subjected to scrutiny and when considered appropriate, cut-back. The matters raised in the Auditor-General's Audit Report will be among the factors taken into consideration when funding is next being considered for recruiting.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 27 October 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: Can the Prime Minister confirm that his reply to my Question on Notice No. 1153 (see Senate Hansard of 26 September 1989, page 1362), translated into simple English, means that his Government does not know its all-up expenditure in the individual States; if so, what is the reason for denying this information to Parliament.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: In my replies to the honourable senator's previous questions relating to expenditure by the Commonwealth in individual States, I have explained that:
(a) I consider Commonwealth expenditure in the States a legitimate and pertinent subject for a Parliamentary question by a Senator but within the context of a number of accounting limitations;
(b) Commonwealth accounting systems have been designed to record expenditure against the source of payment;

(c) in the case of programs for which client location is a significant factor in judging program performance, information about client location is routinely collected, although not necessarily in an accounting context. That information may allow expenditure under the program to be calculated by individual States; and
(d) for those programs for which client location is not significant in evaluating program performance, information about client location is not routinely collected.

Neither this Government nor previous Governments have sought accurately to calculate Commonwealth expenditure by individual States. This information has not been denied to Parliament since it has not been requested. As previously advised, considerable resources would be required accurately to calculate Commonwealth expenditure by individual States and, in the case of my own Department, I determined that I would not authorise the use of the considerable resources involved e.g. each salary transaction for Central Office in Canberra would need to be examined to determine whether payments were made to a bank in Canberra (Australian Capital Territory) or Queanbeyan (New South Wales). In the same way, payments to suppliers would need to be examined to determine whether the supplier was located in Canberra or inter-State.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 17 October 1989 (Hansard, page 1981), Senator Bjelke-Petersen asked me the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: I refer the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce to press reports that pineapples valued at more than $1m, representing about 8,000 to 10,000 tonnes of fruit, were left to rot on Queensland farms because of a market glut triggered by cheap Asian imports. In view of the fact that imports of canned pineapples from countries such as Thailand, Indonesia and the Philippines have jumped 50 per cent in the past year to the equivalent of about 25,000 tonnes of fresh fruit, would the Minister consider supporting the industry in mounting a case to have dumping duties imposed on these imports-
The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

Provisions exist under the anti-dumping legislation for an application to be made for the publication of a dumping duty notice if dumped goods are causing or threatening material injury to an Australian industry. I would advise the industry to lodge a dumping complaint with the Australian Customs Service (ACS) if it considers it is being materially injured by dumped exports of canned pineapples from South East Asia. Officers of the ACS are available to advise the industry on the procedures to be followed when lodging a dumping complaint and the evidence required to support an application for a dumping duty notice.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 3 October 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: What is the estimated dollar value per annum of the indirect subsidy provided to the Australian tobacco industry by the Government's `Australian Tobacco Industry Stabilisation Plan 1989-1993' and the policy of maintenance of general tariffs on tobacco leaf and refuse.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: There is no estimate available of the level of indirect assistance provided to tobacco growers under the terms of the 1989-1993 tobacco industry stabilisation plan. While the first year of the plan ended on 30 September 1989, import statistics necessary to calculate assistance are not yet available.

The 1989-1993 tobacco industry stabilisation plan is underpinned by the local leaf content scheme. Under this scheme, concessional tariffs apply to leaf imported by domestic manufacturers of tobacco products who purchase at least 50 per cent of their leaf requirements domestically. As all manufacturers participate in the local leaf content scheme, price levels for domestic leaf under the plan will be influenced by the extent of the differential between the general and concessional tariff rates on imported leaf.

The level of assistance provided to tobacco growers during the term of the 1989-1993 plan will be affected by a number of factors. These include changes in the price of Australian leaf relative to that in overseas countries supplying tobacco leaf and exchange rate relativities.

In accordance with the 25 May 1988 Government decision, the general tariff on tobacco leaf is being progressively lowered from 25 to 15 per cent by 1992. The concessional tariff is to remain at the current level until 1 October 1995, at which time it, and the local leaf content scheme, will terminate.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 10 October 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to an article in the Department of Primary Industries and Energy's newsletter Primary Resource of 5 September 1989, in which the Australian Horticultural Corporation Marketing Manager (Mr John Baker) claims that the financial viability of the Australian citrus industry is being threatened by the loss of tariff protection and the imposition of sales tax on Australian juice, will the Minister make the appropriate moves to rectify the situation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The major issue currently facing the Australian citrus industry is the need to develop a comprehensive marketing plan taking into account forecast large production increases over the next few years. These forecasts are derived from new plantings of citrus which will come into production and higher yields from existing plantings.
A critical element of the marketing plan will be to establish export market strategies for fresh fruit to reduce the present reliance on the domestic processing market.
In these circumstances it is not appropriate for the Government to be considering increased levels of assistance to the citrus industry.

Under the general tariff reduction announced in the May 1988 Economic Statement, the tariff for most citrus juices is being phased down to 15% by 1 July 1992, with a 5% margin for developing countries. The tariff applicable for the 1989-90 financial year is 24% general rate and 19% developing country rate. This rate provides substantial protection for the industry. No exemptions to these general tariff reductions have been granted as to do so would run counter to the aim of encouraging a more competitive industry structure throughout the economy.

Under the current sales tax arrangements for citrus juice, beverages with a minimum Australian or New Zealand juice content of 25% incur a sales tax rate of 10% rather than 20% which applies to other juices and aerated and carbonated soft drinks. The IAC has claimed in its report on the Fresh Fruit and Fruit Products Industries that these arrangements provide substantial assistance to the industry. The Commission also pointed out that they encourage too great a reliance on processing at the expense of fresh fruit and other activities. This reliance has an adverse flow on effect on planting decisions, horticultural practices and marketing. The IAC recommend that the local content provisions be removed and sales tax on fruit based drinks containing not less than 25% of fruit juices be increased to 20% by 1994.

The citrus industry has made further representations to the Government on this issue and has also approached the IAC in the context of their current inquiry into the Food Processing and Beverage Industries. The Government has not made any decisions on the sales tax or local content issue pending further assessment of the evidence provided by the citrus industry.

The citrus industry recognises the challenges which lie ahead and is developing a marketing and promotion strategy in conjunction with the Australian Horticultural Corporation (AHC). Mr Baker's comments are made in the context of his role as Chairman of the Citrus Marketing Committee established by the industry and the Corporation to implement the strategy.

The AHC was established by the Government in August 1988 to help Australian horticultural industries reach their full export potential. The Government has provided a total of $5.85m to the Corporation over its first five years to assist in its early operation. I commend the citrus industry on its decision to become a founding participant in the AHC and its willingness to plan for the future.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, upon notice, on 10 October 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to the amnesty introduced by the Australian Customs Service in June and July 1989 on unpaid import duties and tariffs as a prelude to a crack down on such fraud:

(2) How much money was recovered as a result?
(3) In view of the invitation to `dob in' neighbouring companies and individuals that went out as part of the amnesty announcement, how successful was this aspect of the campaign?
(4) What measures are presently in train or under review to tighten up detection procedures on a permanent basis to avoid serious financial leakage?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Australian Customs Service received 63 responses to the amnesty which applied from 1 June to 31 August 1989.

(2) A minimum revenue recovery value of $6,046,215 resulted from the amnesty. The amounts for some amnesty claims are yet to be resolved as further information is being sought from the claimants involved.

(3) The Fraud Awareness Campaign launched in Queensland by the Australian Customs Service in July 1989 was a separate initiative to the amnesty offer. The campaign generated a number of investigations into commercial fraud which are still proceeding.
(4) In general the measures derive from provisions contained in the Customs and Excise Legislative Amendment Acts of 1989; specifically, and under the headings asked, they include:
(a) In train:
Application of the new administrative penalty provisions (under S. 243T of the Customs Act) as an incentive to encourage greater accuracy in the preparation of entry documents by Importers/Agents.
Initial use of the new audit powers (to facilitate the auditing of information given by importers).

Development of a national audit plan to make the most appropriate use of the new audit powers.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 10 October 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What broadcasts of the events in China in June 1989 were made by Radio Australia to the Chinese mainland.
(2) Were such broadcasts audible in all parts of China.
(3) Is the strength of the Radio Australia signal such that its broadcasts can be received on suitable equipment in all parts of central and northern China.
(4) Are any plans in train to improve reception of the excellent Radio Australia broadcasts in all parts of China and elsewhere in Asia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport and Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question, based in part on information provided by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The ABC advised that, in response to the events which took place in Beijing in June, Radio Australia's standard Chinese broadcasts were extended from six and a half to eight hours per day.

(2) and (3) The answers to these questions are quite complex. Radio Australia broadcasts on the high frequency (HF) or shortwave bands of the radio frequency spectrum. In order to achieve long distance transmission, these high frequency radio waves are deliberately directed above the horizon-so that they are reflected from the earth's ionosphere and come back to earth many thousands of kilometres away. Each such transmission path, involving one reflection from the ionosphere, is known as a `hop'.

For extremely long distance transmission, it is necessary to rely on multiple `hops', where the transmitted signal is reflected once from the ionosphere, returns to earth and is re-reflected at the earth's surface-to be reflected once more again by the ionosphere.
Unfortunately, the signal-reflecting properties of the ionosphere vary diurnally, seasonally and over the sun spot cycle.

It is thus necessary to transmit very high levels of signal power, if reasonable signals are to reach the target audience, and it is necessary to change the transmitter's frequency during each day, to compensate for the changes in the ionosphere.

In the case of high frequency transmissions from Australia to China, the separation distance is so great that two-to-three transmission `hops' are necessary. Thus, using RA's most powerful transmitters, signal coverage of Southern and parts of Central China is reasonably reliable, but signals into Northern China are relatively weak and become very variable due to the cumulative influence of the ionosphere over the number of `hops'.

(4) There are no immediate practical options for significantly improving Radio Australia's signal coverage of Northern China from within Australia. This could only be achieved using transmitters sited in a country much closer to Northern China. The establishment of such transmission facilities would not be a simple matter and would not be a short-term project. It is intended that the Government will consider the future role and responsibilities of Radio Australia later this year, as a necessary preliminary to any upgrade of the transmission system for the overseas service. The Department of Transport and Communications will undertake a study of optimum transmission sites and equipment.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: The People of Australia: Sharing Our Future

(5) How many copies of the booklet have been printed and how many have yet to be distributed.
(6) What is the distribution list for the booklet.
(7) To which newspapers was the booklet provided for inclusion and were there any fees involved; if so, how much.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The cost of producing the booklet was $130,355.83, less advertising revenue of $83,505; that is, a net cost of $46,850.83.
(2) The booklet was printed by Hannan Print in Sydney at a cost of $97,600.
(3) 1,015,000 copies were printed.
(4) The advertising revenue was as follows:
(ii) Shell Australia: $6,525
(iii) Australian Bicentennial Multicultural Foundation: $6,725
(iv) Lend Lease Corporation: $22,585
(v) Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs: $10,035
(vi) SBS Television: $12,545
(vii) Qantas: $12,545
(5) 1,015,000 copies were printed and approximately 5,000 copies have yet to be distributed.

(6) In addition to the distribution to newspapers, the booklets were provided to the State and Territory offices of the Office of Multicultural Affairs for general distribution, as part of the Office's ongoing community information role. The distribution list includes Commonwealth, State and Local Government agencies, ethnic community organisations and other community organisations, educational institutions and church groups. Booklets have also been provided to conferences and to individuals on request.

(7) The publication was provided to The Age and The Sydney Morning Herald for insertion in the Good Weekend magazine at a cost of $42,120, and to The Australian for insertion in The Australian Magazine for circulation in Queensland, Western Australia, Tasmania, South Australia and the Northern Territory at a cost of $11,100.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business, upon notice, on 1 November 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) In regard to the Co-ordination and Services sub program of the Australian Customs Service, what was the actual appropriation for administrative expenses in 1987-88 and is the figure quoted on page 273 of Budget Paper No. 3, 1988-89 of $12,825,000 correct.
(2) Is the figure of $16,916,000 the actual administration expenditure for 1988-89.
(3) Does the estimate quoted for administrative costs for 1989-90 represent a 59 per cent increase over 1987-88 and a 29.7 per cent increase over 1988-89.
(4) What is the reason behind this increase in administrative outlays.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The actual appropriation for administrative expenses in 1987-88 in regard to the Co-ordination and Services was $12,843,000. The figure of $12,825,000 quoted on page 273 of Budget Paper No. 3 is correct and reflects actual expenditure against the appropriation of $12,843,000.

(2) The figure of $16,916,000 is the actual administration expenditure for 1988-89. It should be noted however that the expenditure in 1988-89 for Staff Housing (funded from Appropriation Bill 2) was included in the actual administration expenditure for 1988-89. Under revised running cost arrangements for 1989-90 costs for the purchase of minor repairs and maintenance of staff housing are to be funded from administration expenditure (Appropriation Bill 1). In order to present expenditure for 1988-89 and estimates for 1989-90 on a ``like'' basis the expenditure for staff housing in 1988-89 was therefore included as administration expenditure in the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce Budget Explanatory Notes.

(3) The estimate quoted for administrative costs for 1989-90 does represent a 59% increase over 1987-88. The 1989-90 estimate on the same basis is 21.1% above expenditure in 1988-89. For the first time in 1988-89 details were provided in the Explanatory notes of receipts credited pursuant to Section 9 of Appropriation Bill No. 1. When these are included in administrative costs the increases on 1987-88 and 1988-89, though the figures are not strictly comparable, become 71% and 29.7% respectively.
(4) The major variations between 1987-88 and 1988-89 are attributed to the following:
supplementation to cover introduction of ``full cost'' charges for services provided by the Department of Administrative Services (DAS) +$263,000
supplementation to cover the transfer of responsibility from DAS for staff housing, design and construction fees and office guarding +$504,000
additional funding associated with increased levels of staff in Passenger Processing +$235,000

transfer of funds to Co-ordination and Services from other Sub Programs to reflect changes in responsibility for ``corporate overhead'' items associated with fine tuning of new ACS Sub Program structure +$2,508,097
increase to reflect inflation (cash limiting allowance) +$1,052,903
The major variations between 1988-89 and 1989-90 are attributed to the following:
supplementation to cover the introduction of premiums for Comcare +$4,223,000
increase to reflect inflation (cash limiting allowance) +$1,061,000

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Industrial Relations: Funding of Local Government

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations, upon notice, on 2 November 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How much and under which program did your Department appropriate moneys for the use of local government authorities in the 1988-89 financial year.
(2) How much and under which programs does your Department estimate will be appropriated for the use of local government authorities during the current financial year.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industrial Relations has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Department did not grant any financial assistance in 1988-89 for the use of local government authorities.
(2) The Department has received and has under consideration an application for a grant of $47,500 under the Work Change Assistance Program.
Other proposals for funding under this Program are anticipated but cannot be quantified at this time.
